PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 1.45 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Treasurer. I draw his attention to an article in the Bulletin of last week which related to the growth of sales tax minimisation schemes. Is it a fact that the Chamber of Automotive Industries of New South Wales approached the Treasurer last month? Did the Chamber point out that schemes for tax evasion among car dealers are being touted throughout Australia? Is it a fact that dealers are paying sales tax according to their level of morality? What is the Government doing to stamp out tax evasion activities which are placing the tax burden on pay-as-you-earn taxpayers?

—The Government has already taken a number of specific legislative measures against sales tax avoidance schemes. I will see that the particular article to which the honourable member has referred is in turn referred to the Commissioner of Taxation, although I imagine that he is already following up, if that needs to be done, what was referred to in the article. In the last part of the honourable member's question he asked me what the Government was doing to stamp out tax evasion. We are doing a great deal, and it is about time the Australian Labor Party changed its attitude towards indirect taxation so that we could really be given a lethal weapon against tax evasion and the cash economy.

—I address my question to the Minister for Primary Industry. It concerns the Australian Wool Testing Authority. Is it true that the change in corporate structure is responsible for a 4 per cent increase in costs to the producer. Has the Minister heard of further rumours to the effect that additional increased costs--
—I will not allow a question to be based on rumours.

—Has the Minister heard or read of such a potential increase in costs? Can he differentiate between the costs of the transfer of the corporate structure on the one hand and any increased costs that may be applicable in the future on the other?

—There can be no truth in the story that a 4 per cent increase in the Australian Wool Testing Authority's costs has occurred because of the transfer. The fact is that the transfer does not take place until 1 July and any level of costs that might be incurred will be worked out in detail by the AWTA and the Australian Wool Corporation. I think the 4 per cent figure comes from the fact that I have said that we can ensure that the cost of the transfer will be no more than 4 per cent. That transfer has not yet occurred. As to the figure of 14 per cent, I think that the report by Hill Samuel Australia Ltd for the Australian Wool Corporation identified that the AWTA had run into cost increases of some 14 per cent that were not yet in place. They were normal cost increases totally unrelated to the transfer of the AWTA to the private sector. It is a matter for the AWTA to increase the costs by that 14 per cent when it wishes. That is a matter for the Board of the AWTA. It is a cost that is totally related to the cost increases for the running of the organisation.

—I ask a question of the Minister for Administrative Services. I preface it by referring to a statement I made in the House yesterday in which I quoted from a document subtitled 'Nugan Hand' in which the then Director of the Narcotics Bureau directed in March 1978 that until further notice 'no active external inquiries are embarked upon' in relation to the activities of the Nugan Hand bank. I ask the Minister: Is it a fact that during yesterday's debate he attacked my assertion that the Narcotics Bureau investigation of Nugan Hand had 'stopped dead' after this directive was issued? Did the Minister describe the statement as 'a total exaggeration'? Is the Minister aware that five months after the directive was issued a confidential information report within the Narcotics Bureau dated 4 August 1978 referred to Nugan Hand's involvement in the importation of heroin and said that 'further information would be available from a reliable and discreet source should this investigation ever be resurrected'? Does the Minister know the meaning of the word 'resurrected'? Does he still insist that my assertion that the Bureau's investigation of Nugan Hand was stopped dead in March 1978 is a total exaggeration? If so, how does he explain this information report which was written five months later?

—I certainly do not change any remarks that I made in the debate yesterday. I just confirm again to the Leader of the Opposition that, on the advice that I have received on the basis of the letter which I quoted from and then argued about, the information certainly was that the investigation was to change from the overt investigation to a covert investigation. I have no doubt that there is about a lot of information or documents that can be brought to the notice of the Government. I was not in charge of the Narcotics Bureau and I can only say to the Leader of the Opposition once again that if he has information which will help particularly the joint task force investigation he really does have a duty to give that joint task force the information so that it can act upon it. I remind the Leader of the Opposition that when I got stuck into him yesterday about his exaggerations I pointed out also that the Leader of the Opposition, when he moved the original motion in this House, very carefully changed the allegations made by Mr Volkman so that they read totally differently in this House. It was a very subtle change, but it was a very vital change.

—The Minister for Transport will be well aware of the recent tour he made of the national highway between Rockhampton and Townsville at the invitation of the honourable member for Herbert, Senator Collard and me. Will the Minister confirm that he expressed the opinion that this section contains some of the worst parts of the Commonwealth national highway system? Will the Minister advise whether the joint study by the Queensland and Commonwealth road authorities into escalating the Bruce Highway construction program has been completed? When will the proposal be placed before both governments?

—Yes, I recall my two-day trip between Rockhampton and Townsville travelling with the honourable member for Dawson and the honourable member for Herbert, in addition to Senator Collard and my friend Mr Russell Hinze. I certainly had a very interesting two days. We had a number of meetings along the road. I was surprised to read in the Courier-Mail the day after the event that I was supposed to have travelled in an air conditioned limousine while the Queensland Minister travelled in a four-wheel drive Toyota. Actually, that was not quite true. I was most concerned to see that lengths of the Bruce Highway were in a very bad condition, but I do want to pay a compliment to the Queensland Main Roads Department for the work that it has done on the Bruce Highway. Some very significant improvements have been made to it since the period when the honourable member for Newcastle was Minister. In fact, they have some very interesting--
—I wish to raise a point of order. I did that trip in 1975. The Minister has been in the chair for as long as he has and it has taken him all those years to get around to doing it.
—There is no point of order.
—Hinze was then the Minister for Main Roads but he has been too damn lazy to get off his big fat backside and do the trip himself.
—There is definitely no point of order.

—I must say that Mr Hinze came forth with a very constructive suggestion at the end of the two days. He said that under present levels of funding it would be 30 years before the Bruce Highway could be brought to a safe and reliable standard between Brisbane and Cairns. Of course, that highway is eligible for 100 per cent Commonwealth funding.
—If it had not been for the Labor Party it would have been 100 years.
—I ask the honourable member for Newcastle to cease interjecting.
—I am just trying to help him.
—He does not appreciate the help.

—The Bruce Highway is eligible for 100 per cent Commonwealth Government funding. Mr Hinze proposed to me that, in view of the importance of the road to Queensland, his State was prepared to consider making a sizable financial contribution towards its upgrading, provided both Queensland officials and Commonwealth officials could get together and prepare a plan for presentation to the two governments. Those officials are getting together and I expect to receive a report from them within three months. The proposal by the Queensland Government is quite unique and shows a degree of self-help that few other States have shown so far. I conclude by saying that road funding is not just a Commonwealth Government responsibility; it is a joint responsibility of the Commonwealth, State and local governments. There has been far too much buck passing in this area and a little more co-operation from the States would be more constructive than the buck passing we are witnessing all over the nation.

—I preface my question, which is directed to the Treasurer, by referring to a statement made by him this week at the conference of the Institute of Chartered Accountants that tax avoidance and the cash economy posed a big threat to government revenue. Did the Treasurer announce in his 1978 Budget Speech certain measures to curb the avoidance of tax liabilities by persons who are paid in cash without deduction of tax instalments? If the Government is concerned at the loss of tax revenue in this area, why were these proposals not proceeded with? If the Government has been alarmed at the extent of this problem for at least the last four years, why has no other action been taken to stop tax avoidance in this area? I want an answer to the real question.
—The honourable member for Chifley will resume his seat.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Chifley is in some error in asserting that nothing has happened in this area. As I recollect it, the 1978 Budget Speech drew attention to cash payment practices in certain sections of industry, in particular the building industry. Arising out of what was said in that speech, the Government has been engaged in discussions with the industry and has also taken note of representations put to it by building industry unions, many of which have adopted a very responsible attitude to this problem, although some others, particularly in this industry, have adopted a rather different attitude. Arising out of that the Government has discussed in some detail some possible improvements of the taxation administration in this area. Depending on the further outcome of discussions with the building industry, I hope to put some proposals to the Government in the very near future.

ANSWER.PARA: I remind the honourable gentleman that there will never be an effective assault upon tax evasion through the growth of the cash economy in Australia until there is a greater reliance on indirect taxation. I know that the Australian Labor Party is sensitive about this matter because its inconsistency has been totally exposed. It preaches abhorrence of tax evasion but when it comes to doing something effective it votes against it. The Labor Party has voted against a broadening of the indirect tax base and it has threatened to vote against some tax avoidance measures which I foreshadowed on 18 December and which will prevent the ordinary Australian taxpayer being ripped off to the tune of $120m or $150m through a very contrived arrangement set up by the New South Wales Government which will transfer those dollars from the pockets of ordinary Australian taxpayers into some of the largest company profits in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Foreign Affairs to the Soviet Union's announcement that it would halt installation of medium range nuclear missiles west of the Urals. What is the Government's reaction?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the House would know, the United States and the Soviet Union commenced negotiations on, I think, 30 November last year in Geneva on a reduction in intermediate range nuclear missiles in the European theatre. Shortly before those negotiations commenced the United States President announced that the United States was prepared to agree to what has become known as the zero option; that is, the United States and its North Atlantic Treaty Organisation allies would cancel the planned deployment of Pershing II and cruise missiles in Western Europe if the Soviet Union would remove the SS4, SS5 and SS20 missiles at present targeted on Western Europe. This United States proposal is fully supported by NATO and especially emphasised by the Government of the Federal Republic of Germany.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I regret to say that since the negotiations commenced the Soviet Union has shown that its approach is to engage in a propaganda campaign rather than enter into substantive negotiations. President Brezhnev's statement of 16 March, to which the honourable gentleman referred, is the latest example of that campaign. Specifically, his offer is to stop any further Soviet production of the SS20 missiles. But I point out that that would leave no fewer than 300 such missiles, each capable of carrying three nuclear warheads, targeted on Western Europe. President Brezhnev's suggestion that these weapons systems should be removed from the European section of Soviet territory is quite meaningless because, even if they were, they would still have the range to reach Western Europe from outside the European section of Soviet territory. In any case, the vehicles on which the missiles are mounted are mobile. It is the Government's view that the cause of reducing intermediate range nuclear weapons would be much better served if the Soviet Union addressed itself seriously to the zero option.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Treasurer to his speech this week to the Institute of Chartered Accountants in which he said that it was widely accepted that indirect taxes were difficult to avoid. Is the Treasurer aware that, in the first year of operation of a value added tax in Britain, the equivalent of $60m to $70m in revenue was estimated to have been lost due to avoidance? Is it a fact that all European countries with heavy reliance on indirect taxes have experienced similar problems in attempting to ensure compliance and that this often involves enormous administrative costs for the collection authorities and a similar burden on tax collecting businesses? Has the Treasurer been made aware of these details and, if so, why does he believe that such problems would not arise with a wider reliance on indirect taxes in Australia?

—I have been made aware of the fact that in those countries that have a greater reliance on indirect taxation than does Australia there is nonetheless some evasion of taxation and there are schemes which are designed to avoid tax. To be realistic-no matter what views we may have on this subject-it has to be accepted that we will never have a tax system which is totally proofed against tax avoidance and tax evasion. It is very much a question of degree. A two- pronged attack is needed. On the one hand, we need effective legislative response to sophisticated and artificial schemes, of the type contained in the new Part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which was put together after receiving some of the best taxation advice around Australia. Secondly, in order to respond to the cash economy, we need a greater reliance on broadly based consumption taxes. It is only through that that we can make a serious assault upon the growth of the cash economy. That is not to say that it will ever be totally eliminated. I go back to what I said earlier. There is an utter inconsistency when a party that abhors tax evasion votes consistently against the most lethal weapon that could be at the hands of the Government to deal with it.

—Has the Prime Minister seen the report of the Senate Select Committee on Government Clothing and Ordnance Factories entitled 'The future of Ordnance Factory Bendigo'? Can the Prime Minister advise the House as to what action the Government intends to take in regard to the recommendations of this report, in particular that recommendation which states that the factory should be closed if it is not sold?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the report on the future of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory. The Government will be looking at the report quite closely. I note that the main part of the report recommends that the Ordnance Factory still be sold. That is consistent with the Review of Commonwealth Functions recommendation of a year ago and the Government's efforts since then which in a sense had been suspended during the Senate Committee inquiry. The Government will evaluate the various proposals, or offers of tenders and, when that process is finished, it will come to a final decision as to whether or not the factory will be sold.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government would much prefer that the factory could be sold to private enterprise so that new investment could be attracted to Bendigo and to the Ordnance Factory. This would provide opportunities for expanded activity. More money would flow through the factory and into the city, providing expanded employment opportunities. That is a large part of the basis of the original decision, because we believe that enterprises that ought to be commercial enterprises are best run by private enterprise people rather than by governments . The record of government-run enterprises would seem to support that view.

The effort of the trade union leaders in the Bendigo area, by contacts, as I understand it, with potential purchasers to try to dissuade them from continuing with their interest, is really an action that is very much against the best interests of Bendigo and of employment in Bendigo. They ought to be roundly condemned by the councillors of the city of Bendigo and by everyone who is interested in the advancement of a great provincial city in Victoria. Having examined all the options and in particular the impact on Bendigo, the Government , if it is not successful in its efforts to sell the Ordnance Factory to a vigorous and vital private enterprise concern, will continue to operate the factory as a government operation.

I have to say that the honourable member has shown a very consistent interest in this matter, as one would expect. He has spoken to me about it on many occasions. He has spoken also to the Minister for Industry and Commerce on many occasions about the well-being of the city and about the possible consequences of action in relation to the Ordnance Factory. It was necessary to make this position clear as a result of one part of the recommendations of the Senate Committee which recommended that if the Ordnance Factory could not be sold, as is the Government's intention, then it ought to be dismantled. The Government believed that its reaction to that part of the recommendations ought to be made known quickly so that the concern that would be felt as a result of that recommendation could be put completely and absolutely at rest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. It should be made clear to the House that the recommendation for sale was made only by Government members of that Committee.
—There is no point of order.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. It is supplementary to that which he has just answered. In the event of a sale to the private sector of the Bendigo Ordnance Factory, will the Prime Minister give a firm undertaking that there will be no asset stripping or other action which would lead to a wind -down or even a close-down of the activity of that factory? In the event that he gives that undertaking, will he give a further undertaking that the first undertaking stands, even after the Victorian election?

—Perhaps the Leader of the Opposition did not follow what I said earlier. I said that it was the objective of the Government to dispose of the factory to private enterprise so that there can be investment put into the factory, so that it can expand and be modernised, and so that it can have the kind of life that a vigorous private enterprise concern is expected to have in Australia. The Government has made it clear that any sale would require the continued operation of the Ordnance Factory. Sale for asset stripping has never been part of the Government's philosophy in this matter, and the Opposition knows it.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: EXPORTS OF DRIED FRUIT TO THE EUROPEAN ECONOMIC COMMUNITY

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade and Resources will be aware that the European Economic Community is the largest market for Australian sultana production. Is the Minister able to advise whether the entry of Greece into the EEC in 1981 has changed the export outlook for Australian dried fruit? What can the Government do to ensure that this vital decentralised industry and its producers are not disadvantaged through the imposition of trade barriers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that the industry has a carryover from last year of 7,000 tonnes and a pretty substantial crop coming in this year. One of the principal markets has been the EEC. Something like 30 per cent of Australia's dried vine fruit has been sold in that area. It is to the credit of the Australian Dried Fruits Corporation that it has been an aggressive seller around the world, in Japan, Canada, New Zealand and the EEC. Unfortunately, the accession of Greece into the EEC has jeopardised the Corporation's opportunity to be able to sell to the same extent as it previously could. Greece is a large producer of dried vine fruits. The preference it gets on that market now, being a member, certainly gives it a distinct advantage.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government is concerned also about the open-ended forms of industry assistance and the guaranteed price arrangements which will be a major incentive to increased production in Greece which we will then have to compete against. This is quite unfair and unjust to a country such as Australia whose fruit industry has been a long term supplier. This point of view was made very clear to the President of the Commission of the European Communities, Mr Thorn, and some of the members of his Commission when they were here recently. I hope they might moderate some of the approaches they have taken towards industry assistance as a result of our concern being expressed. However, if we find that we are meeting unfair competition we will have to use the facilities of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade to be able to lodge a challenge against EEC action. I assure the Australian dried vine fruit industry that the Government is concerned and will be watching this matter very closely.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for National Development and Energy. The Minister would be aware of the proposal to construct a pipeline from the Cooper Basin to a fractionation plant to be erected at Stony Point near Whyalla, South Australia. In view of the most recent major oil discoveries in the Cooper Basin, is the oil flow available from that region now sufficient to justify the establishment of an oil refinery at Stony Point and, if so, is the Minister aware of any developments towards that end?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —About a year ago when I had the opportunity to go out to the Cooper Basin I had explained to me the possibilities of petroleum being piped to and facilities being built at Stony Point. At that time arrangements had not been finalised with the South Australian Government, mainly because the company concerned could not get involved in major capital investment decisions until the Commonwealth gave export approval for the sale of liquefied petroleum gas from the plant. This approval was given and the company then proceeded to go ahead and make the necessary plans. I believe this project will go ahead. I hope that at this stage there is sufficient oil, although I am not able to speak off the cuff on this, to warrant a separate pipeline. But certainly there is encouraging exploration going on within the Cooper Basin region and I hope that this region can become another source of oil and hydrocarbons for Australian industry.

ANSWER.PARA: Certainly this Government wants to give all the encouragement it can to further exploration in this region. I think the fact that exploration in Australia is now 10 times greater than it was when we took office is conclusive evidence that our policies are working in relation to trying to encourage more development of our hydrocarbons in this country. But I again say I cannot give the honourable member a definite answer whether an oil pipeline will be constructed. I can get those facts and give them to the honourable member.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Treasurer recall my drawing to his attention a recent radio broadcast by the Leader of the Opposition in which the said Leader made a brief reference to a barrister who had assigned a debt to him of $74,000 to his wife so it could be regarded as a gift and non-taxable? Does the Treasurer recall since advising me that the Commissioner of Taxation has advised him that a debt due could be validly assigned at law and in equity but that he, the Commissioner, does not concede the effectiveness of these arrangements and is taking action to detect their implementation and, if appropriate, to amend the assessments of those taxpayers who have omitted income from their returns? Can the Treasurer tell me how one detects that a person is involved in such an arrangement if the amount of money is not mentioned in the return in the first place and, secondly, if the wife, the recipient, does not even have to submit a return?

—I recall the honourable gentleman's question and I also recall the response that I gave. I repeat that so far as the generality of this position is concerned, the Commissioner of Taxation is contesting the effectiveness of these devices which are being employed by some people who currently have the privilege of returning their taxable income on a cash receipts basis as distinct from an accruals basis which applies to the great number of people who are liable to pay provisional tax. Without obtaining some technical advice from the Commissioner of Taxation I cannot tell the honourable gentleman precisely all the methods that the Commissioner might use in order to ascertain what assignments have taken place and, if so, in what quantities.
—Would you like me to help you?

—The honourable member for Adelaide interjects that he would like to help me. I would be very grateful for any assistance from the Opposition in further stamping out tax evasion in this country. I would be very happy to receive it. I hope that that is translated into a few more constructive votes in this and in another place. If members of the Opposition were prepared to do that we could be a little more effective. In answer to the honourable member for Fadden, I would have to get some advice on the administrative and technical sides of his question in order to give him a more complete answer. I will undertake to do so and see what further information I can provide.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Trade and Resources. Is he aware that the New Zealand Minister for Foreign Affairs yesterday informed the Press that a closer economic relationship-CER-between New Zealand and Australia would be operating early next year and strongly implied that the Agreement would be concluded in June of this year at a meeting between our Prime Minister and Mr Muldoon? As there has been no statement by the Minister on this very important matter, can he give the House an assurance that he will make a statement next week? In particular, can the Minister provide details of how this closer economic relationship will affect Australian manufactured goods, the whole range of dairy products and the range of New Zealand goods coming into Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anthony The Rt Hon J.D.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; TRADE AND RESOURCES

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not right to be categorical as to when negotiations might be concluded or when a new closer economic relationship might commence. I did answer a question in the House about a week ago. I said that the objective was to try to achieve a commencement of a closer economic relationship for 1 January 1983. That is still an objective, but it will depend upon satisfactory arrangements being settled between the two Governments and also between industries of both countries. Very extensive consultations have been going on for two years between different sections of Australian industry within the industrial area and the manufacturing sector. The Confederation of Australian Industry has been working in close collaboration with its counterparts in New Zealand. After extensive investigation and an assessment of the worth of a closer economic relationship, they have come down strongly in favour of it.
—Do you support it?

—I will answer that in due course. The Australian New Zealand Businessmans Council Ltd has been looking also at the merits of such an arrangement and it too believes that a CER ought to come into operation as quickly as possible so that the benefits of the combined resources of both countries can be utilised and can produce a greater economic dimension and activity between our two countries. Discussions have taken place between some of the agricultural groups. Already the dairying industries have had initial discussions and there will be more within the next few weeks. The Australian wine industry and the New Zealand Wine Institute have got together and have reached an amicable agreement to phase out completely the import licensing and the tariff arrangements on wine. That is a major step forward.

ANSWER.PARA: Because some areas have not been resolved between the governments it is very difficult for me to be able to bring forward a catalogue of the progress that has been made. Certainly I will not be able to make a statement next week because I will be in Malaysia. When the next ministerial round of discussions takes place-we hope that that can be done some time in April-I will be in a position to state what the exact progress is. It will be brought to this House. Australian industry will be notified before any final propositions are considered by both governments. That point will conclude with discussions by the two Prime Ministers. I for one hope very much that we can reach a conclusion, because I believe that it is in the total interests of both countries that we find a way of being able to harmonise our economic circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Housing and Construction. Is any evidence available to suggest that the Government's site allowance policy in respect of government building contracts is effectively reducing the incidence of site allowances in the industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McVeigh The Hon D.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Available statistics indicate that on government works, as opposed to private enterprise works, the incidence and value of site allowances are a lot lower. The most recent statistics available, based on a survey of 91 major government projects, indicate that there were site allowances on only 11 of them. Quite obviously, the responsible policy of the Government of not reimbursing site allowances granted has done several things. It has indicated to contractors that we are not Father Christmas. It has put a bit of muscle in them and they have fought the cases before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. Additionally, it has been acknowledged that certain members of the Commission have been prone to grant increased site allowances on the basis that they are aware that the Commonwealth Government will pick up the tab. The Commonwealth Government, of course, is aware of the fact that there is not to be set the bad example of automatic flow-on to private works and to Commonwealth works by virtue of the fact that it has this policy.

ANSWER.PARA: Finally, notwithstanding some criticism from specialist building contractors, when we call tenders for government projects, whether major projects or minor projects, we are always embarrassed by the great number of tenderers who tender for the projects according to the Government's guidelines and policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. Is it a fact that 70 per cent of the 1981-82 national developmental roads allocation for New South Wales was for roads associated with the mining industry, while the remaining 30 per cent-an amount of $1.5m-was allocated to sections of trunk road 68 and main road 343 in the Minister's electorate, against the wishes of the New South Wales Government? Further, what were the special criteria followed in arriving at a decision on this matter? Why were the standard criteria for national developmental roads not followed? Is it, again, a case here of a Government Minister giving preference to his own electorate, and, in this case, preference to near relatives who live along the road? Finally, will the Minister explain how he expects his over-ruling of the New South Wales Government's road priorities to ease the pressure on that State's road resources? Is this the latest example of the kind of co-operation, to which he referred during an earlier answer, that he is seeking from the State Ministers for Roads?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been waiting for this question from someone of the Opposition for some time, because this matter has been the subject of considerable discussion in the State Parliament. The Minister for Roads in New South Wales made a false accusation that the road between Wee Waa and Burren Junction actually went through my brother's property-which is an absolute lie. It does not go through it or past it, nor does that road serve it. The truth of the matter is that the route of the road was decided by the Department of Main Roads in 1978, when Mr Jensen was the Minister for Roads in New South Wales.

ANSWER.PARA: I have with me quite a lot of correspondence and documents that I wish to table for the benefit of honourable members that will clarify the position quite satisfactorily. Mr Jensen, the New South Wales Minister for Roads during the Castlereagh by-election, made a statement that there was a necessity to have a remote area development category to assist those people in the remote areas of New South Wales and elsewhere. Indeed, we discussed this matter at Dubbo after his visit to Bourke. Mr Jensen pursued the issue. He required additional funds rather than to see them taken from the national roads category. But for some years there has been a development roads category covering commerce and export industries using the roads. The Government decided that to try to assist those industries and the remote areas of Australia the definition of such categories should include remote area industries, which incorporates agriculture.

This particular road is a very important one, serving one of the most productive areas of New South Wales. That it happens to be in the electorate of Gwydir is just too bad. Gwydir happens to cover one-third of the State of New South Wales. I am surprised that the Minister for Roads in New South Wales would single out the people in northern and north-western New South Wales for this sort of attack and treatment. The area has been neglected over a long period by successive governments in the State of New South Wales. Mr Jensen accepted the fact that the road was important and, as the correspondence will indicate, actually recommended for approval this particular project which the honourable gentlemen mentioned. So it is not a question of Mr Jensen, who was then the Minister, disapproving of it. The truth of the matter is that Mr Whelan in New South Wales is trying to make a political issue out of it.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received letters from the honourable member for Eden-Monaro ( Mr Sainsbury) and the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) proposing that definite matters of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion today. As required by Standing Order 107, I have selected the matter which in my opinion is the most urgent and important, that is, that proposed by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The inequitable tax burden imposed on wage and salary earners by the artificial tax avoidance industry and the cash economy.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Speaker--
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—Here is sour grapes.

—No. It is not sour grapes. Mr Speaker, I realise that there is no provision for me to challenge the exercise of your discretion in this matter and I do not complain. But I do feel that it is important to point out that, as I had a matter of public importance, of which I gave you notice, which involved the Prime Minister and involved--
—The honourable member will resume his seat. I have exercised my option under the Standing Orders. I will not allow the matter to be debated.

—At the present time there is an increasing awareness amongst the population of Australia that, under the tax structure that is set down under the Acts of Parliament, some people are paying too much tax and some people are paying too little tax. In this context of increasing understanding by the population I believe it important to raise this matter today. I want to do three things. I want first of all to talk about the inequities which are imposed on wage and salary earners in particular by people who are engaged in tax avoidance or tax evasion. I also want to stress the problems that the Government has in coping with those inequities and I hope to say one or two words about exactly what this Government has done. Also, as a corollary-this will not take very long because it is so obvious-I want to expose the miserable performance of the Australian Labor Party in this field.

SPEECH.PARA: There is certainly a very big problem in this area. As I have intimated already there are two parts to it. There is a tax evasion problem, mainly in the cash economy-the so-called black economy-which is a very strong and growing economy in many countries. There is evidence that it represents perhaps as much as 10 per cent of our total gross domestic product. Under those circumstances, of course, the amount involved could be as high as $14 billion in productive effort . Even on the basis of one-third of that figure being tax payable, the amount involved would be something like $5 billion. It has also been estimated by the Taxpayers Association of Australia to be a $7,000m industry. By way of comparison, in the United Kingdom in 1979 it was estimated by the Chairman of the Board of Inland Revenue to represent about 7.5 per cent of the gross domestic product of that country. So, whatever one might say about the exact figure, from a number of comments made by people who have some sort of knowledge of this from a research point of view-including, for instance, the Monash Centre of Policy Studies-it appears to be a very big industry.

I move from the cash economy to the tax avoidance economy, in which people act within the law but, through contrived schemes in the main, manage to avoid paying the taxation which in every sense of the law ought to be paid. We are told by the Commissioner of Taxation in his sixtieth report for the year 1980-81 that that industry is worth at least $973m in a single year. That is only for those schemes that were at that time under challenge; it does not include schemes which were not challenged but which were nevertheless legislated for later.

The Government has been very active in this field. One of the reasons I raise this matter today is the many allegations that one hears from one's electorate and also from the Opposition that the Government is not active in this field. I want to point out how active the Government has been. When the Government came into power it noted very quickly that the previous Government had done absolutely nothing in three years of office, despite the fact that it was well known that the tax avoidance industry-I am talking about tax avoidance-had grown rapidly. That was shown up very clearly by the famous Curran case in 1973. We noted that nothing had been done between 1973 and the end of 1975. Nevertheless, since 1977, when we have been able to get legislation forward, we have outlawed 36 tax avoidance schemes. Recently we announced a couple more that will be outlawed and shortly legislation will be brought into this House as I understand it relating to section 136 of the Income Tax Assessment Act, which relates to transfer pricing, a very important part of the system. I will mention just a few of the schemes that we have outlawed. We have outlawed schemes to counter five specific forms of sales tax avoidance; schemes involved in the trafficking of current year loss companies; dividend stripping; schemes under which one party obtained a deduction while the other party did not bear tax on the matching amount in the same year of income; the so-called Curran schemes; trading stock schemes; schemes involved with technical deficiencies governing taxation of royalties derived by non-residents; other trust stripping schemes; the exploitation of income of certain charitable organisations, and the list goes on and on. When one reads the list, as I have again recently, of the work that the Government has done in this area, one sees that it is very impressive. But I am not running away from the fact that there is still much more to be done.

In addition to these specific schemes, the Government has introduced two very important measures. One is the new Division 4A of the Income Tax Assessment Act which tries to get at the sense of the Act and replaces the old section 260 which, in the light of the attitude over many years of the High Court, turned out to be quite ineffective for the job that the people who had framed the Act obviously meant it to do. We have also, of course, put through the Parliament a complementary Act to the Income Tax Assessment Act called the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act so that it is now a criminal offence to act or to aid and abet someone else to act to prevent the actual collection of income and sales tax by private companies and certain trusts, the so-called bottom of the harbour scheme , which scheme I understand was brought to light as a result of the inquiry into the activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union.

All of these, I think, add up to a rather impressive list, but people go on and on. When one looks back at some of the things that have been done one wonders whether there are in the community thousands and thousands of people who just do not believe they ought to share any sort of tax burden. Some of the schemes in the past few years have been so audacious and bizarre that they have become newspaper headlines and tax avoidance industry bywords such as the so-called Curran scheme and the bottom of the harbour scheme that I have just mentioned and the scheme under which a group of businessmen were able to claim a tax deduction of $3.7m after donating an art collection to the Victorian National Gallery. I understand that one promoter alone stripped more than 2,000 companies and in 733 of those cases was able to deprive Federal revenue of more than $128m in uncollected tax. All this adds up to a horrible picture, a picture which, as I have said, the Government is tackling. The Taxation Advisory Committee was set up two or three years ago by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in order to get advice from private sector practitioners on the best way of framing anti-avoidance legislation. According to that Committee, from the discussions I had with it a few months ago, there is now a real break in the growth of taxation avoidance.

I want to mention that the cash economy is the biggest area in this industry. It is not just the fancy schemes under which people, who would normally be described as people on high income, avoid tax. Cash economy is engaged in by perhaps millions of Australian individuals, often in a small way, such as the tradesman who works on Saturday and who gets paid cash money and the person on unemployment benefit who accepts cash money in a small way to keep his full entitlement to the unemployment benefit. I do not denigrate any particular group of people in this respect, but we all know that this activity exists and I am quite sure that all of us know of many instances of this sort of thing happening . Some people have said, of course, that cash economy activity is not terribly bad because, they say, if people could not get as it were overtime work without having to pay tax they would not be prepared to work. In that sense people say that the cash economy can be an incentive to people to work harder and therefore increases productivity in this country. One of the corollaries of that, of course, is that it makes it very difficult for the government to know just what the productivity of this country is.

In the last few years, if there has been a great increase in the cash economy, our rate of increase in productivity has in fact been greater than the statistics might show, reflecting, I suppose, even greater credit on the Government in those terms. But the problem is-this is the essence of this matter of public importance-that the cash economy and the tax avoidance economy place a burden on the wrong people. They place a burden in the sense that the Government must collect, to cover all its spending programs, a certain amount of taxes from the people already in the system who cannot avoid tax or who do not want to avoid or evade tax. This year, if we are to collect the $40,000m-odd provided in the Federal Budget, we will have to collect it from those people in the system. If we miss out on $5 billion, $6 billion or even $2 billion in tax avoidance or evasion schemes, in general that money is raised from wage and salary earners who in general are not in a position to avoid or evade taxation.

We all know-certainly we on this side of the House know-of the great increase in the tax burden in Australia on wage and salary earners. The proportion being paid by these people through direct taxes has increased markedly year by year and we have to do something about it. One of the first things we have to do is to look at how we can discourage, penalise or talk people out of avoiding or evading taxation. It is an area which is highly technical but I want to talk about one or two things which we must do or continue to do. I do not have very much time to expand on this. But, obviously, the Government will have to continue vigorously its anti-avoidance measures. Heaven forbid that we should have a change of government so that that rigorous and strenuous effort by the Government in the past few years might stop. I include in those anti-avoidance measures any relating to sales tax that might need to be taken, something touched upon in Question Time this afternoon. A little while ago I touched on the fact that we have had some amendments in that area.

One might ask whether a lower tax base overall might discourage people from wanting to avoid tax or wanting to get into the cash economy. I have always doubted that logic. It seems to me that, even with a direct tax rate of 20 per cent, the smarties would still engage in tax avoidance if they could pick up 10 per cent by their efforts. I do not think a lower tax argument fits. Nevertheless we do know that this Government, which is committed to the smallest possible government, is the most likely to have lower tax anyway in the long run . I ask this question in terms of the cash economy: Ought we not to examine what some of us, especially liberal people in our society, have always worried about; that is the possibility of identity cards. It seems to me that, in a country where people obtain so many rights and privileges, some degree of obligation ought to be on them.

If a cash economy is rife, perhaps it would not hurt if people, when going for a job or accepting money, were put under an obligation to show a card so that they would find it far more difficult to provide a fictitious name. I have not thought that all the way through but it is certainly a matter which I think we should have a very close look at. On top of all those ideas-I know that they are only partial solutions even if they are successful-we cannot avoid the fact that indirect taxation, as has been mentioned in Question Time by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) this afternoon, must be a way to force people into paying taxes through their discretionary purchases. It is quite obvious that, say, a rich person who has to pay a high rate of indirect taxation on a luxury good cannot avoid that tax if he buys the good. On the other hand, he may be wealthy enough to employ smart tax agents to help him avoid direct taxation through tax avoidance schemes . All this has been well documented in the report of the Mathews Committee of Inquiry into Inflation and Taxation and I hope that other people in this debate will have something to say about it.

Finally I want to emphasise that the Australian Labor Party took no action when it had a three-year chance to do so. I have not heard it address the matter at all. I am certainly looking forward to the next two Opposition speakers to see whether the Labor Party has changed its mind, to see what they have to say about the cash economy-whether they are prepared to present policies that would endeavour to act against and penalise, people who are ripping off those who are co-operating with the tax system. Given that the Labor Party is the high tax party, under its jurisdiction the cash economy and the tax avoidance industry would prove an even greater burden to wage and salary earners. Let us just hope that by airing this matter and by having the debate publicised throughout the community we can appeal to the morality of the Australian people and ask those who are offending to improve their attitudes.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a remarkable irony in the Government bringing on today this matter of public importance. It is one which, I remind the House, discusses:

SPEECH.PARA: The inequitable tax burden imposed on wage and salary earners by the artificial tax avoidance industry and the cash economy.

One would think that this was something for which the Government had no responsibility whatever. Of course, the fact is that since it has been in office there has been a massive explosion of tax avoidance and evasion, and the burden on wage and salary earners as a result has become a matter of national concern. That is not to say that there was no tax avoidance or evasion prior to 1976; but it is to say that there is no doubt whatever that there has been a massive explosion of such activity while this Government has been in office. It is also utterly untrue to say, as did the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Sainsbury) on two occasions, that the former Labor Government did nothing about tax avoidance when it was in office. This is a lie which is perpetrated time and time again by speakers on the Government side, despite the fact-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind the honourable gentleman that he must couch his remarks in parliamentary terms.

—I withdraw the term and say that it is a massive untruth that has been perpetrated time and time again by the Government, knowing it to be untrue. It is continually putting it forward, despite the fact that on several occasions we have shown what the Labor Government did about tax avoidance. For the Hansard record, let me yet again cite what was done.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, we eliminated Norfolk Island, the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island as tax havens for the avoidance of personal and company tax. Dividends and interests paid to Papua New Guinea were made subject to withholding tax in order to prevent the use of that country for the avoidance of such tax. The payment of dividends to artificial companies in Papua New Guinea and other tax havens was ended. Also, the Labor Government introduced the system of tax clearance certificates and the use of exchange control by the Reserve Bank to limit the employment of tax havens for tax avoidance purposes. Restrictions were placed on the purchase and use of companies with accumulated bad debts for similar purposes. Restrictions were placed on the purchase and use of companies with accumulated losses. Restrictions were placed on the carrying forward of excess distributions by private companies to avoid undistributed profits tax. Subscriptions to pseudo-exploration companies as a form of tax avoidance were ended. The avoidance of withholding tax on interest payable to overseas residents through an overseas branch of an Australian company was stopped.

Does that look like a list of non-action? Of course it does not. It represents a whole series of actions taken, mainly in the early stages of the Labor Government's term of office, because the previous Government had been lax and had left these loopholes, which the Labor Government proceeded to close off, in the main during 1973-74.

The honourable member for Eden-Monaro, who has now left the chamber, also said that the former Labor Government did nothing in respect of the so-called Curran scheme, stating that it was introduced in 1973 and the Labor Government did nothing about it from 1973 to 1975. That was also untrue. The Curran case was decided in December 1974, only one year before the Labor Government went out of office. At that time the Treasurer Mr Crean, made it clear that legislation would be passed against the scheme. Admittedly it was not done in 1975, but neither was it done in 1976 or 1977. It was not done until 1978. So if the Labor Government can be accused of some slackness in 1975-I remind honourable members of the circumstances under which it was trying to govern at the time-what of the succeeding Government effort in 1976 and 1977? It did absolutely nothing about this scheme while it was being used, and demonstrably so, in massive tax avoidance.

There was an explosion of the use of the scheme in the first two years of this Government's period of office, yet it comes in here and says: 'Look at the slackness of the previous Labor Government. It did nothing about the Curran scheme. The present Government presided over the period during which the scheme was used massively as a form of tax avoidance and hundreds of millions of dollars of tax revenue were lost by its use. Therefore, we repudiate entirely the totally false accusations which have been made here today that the former Labor Government was slack in respect of tax avoidance. We have repudiated them many times before but I repeat that statement because I am sick and tired of these nauseating accusations being made for which there are absolutely no grounds whatsoever.

As I said, there has been a massive explosion of tax avoidance since this Government came into office. There is no doubt whatsoever about that. The annual report of the Commissioner of Taxation gives a fairly good indication of this fact. It gives the number of identified participants in tax avoidance schemes although, as he points out in his annual report, that is only the tip of the iceberg. It specifies that the number of people who were involved last year in tax avoidance schemes was 26 times higher than it was in 1975-I repeat, 26 times higher. Does that look like this Government has been effectively combating tax avoidance? Of course it has not. There has been this massive explosion, as shown by this statistic, of a 26-fold increase in the number of identified participants in tax avoidance schemes.

The amount of money involved is now in the order of at least $3,000m and maybe much more. People like Mr Risstrom of the Australian Taxpayers' Association say the figure lost through tax avoidance and evasion is more like $7 billion per annum. Other estimates, by such people as Professor Mathews, put the figure at somewhere around $3 1/2 billion. Whether it is $3 1/2 billion or $7 billion, an enormous amount of revenue is being lost principally because of the slackness of this Government in dealing with the explosion of tax avoidance and evasion. The Government knows that to be true; yet it brings on this kind of matter of public importance and says it is doing everything that can be done about it when in fact that is not the case.

Of course, we acknowledge that particularly since 1978 there has been a whole stream of legislation brought in against particular tax avoidance schemes. We do not in any way deny that that has occurred; it is an undeniable fact. We do say that that does not show that this Government has been effective in its actions against tax avoidance schemes. It has not been effective. That is shown by this massive explosion in the amount of revenue being lost and by the number of participants in tax avoidance schemes. The Government has not been effective because it has lacked the sense or the guts, or whatever is needed, to undertake retrospective action in regard to tax avoidance schemes, thereby putting a real end to the tax avoidance industry. This is the one measure which can be undertaken by this Government which will damage the tax avoidance industry more than anything else. The Government knows that to be true.

We understand and appreciate fully the general undesirability of retrospective legislation but in this case we have to balance that against the massive inequity in the tax system being brought about by this explosion of tax avoidance, which is making tax optional for the wealthy and putting the burden on wage and salary earners. When we balance off the general undesirability of retrospective legislation against the massive inequities being created by tax avoidance, we come down on the side of retrospective action in this limited area of tax avoidance cases. If the Government were to introduce such legislation, most certainly it would have a massive dissuasion effect on the tax avoidance industry because people would know when they got involved in a scheme that, even if it took the Commissioner three years to catch up with them, eventually they would have to pay all the tax and the promoter's fee as well, and so would be worse off at the end of the day. That is why retrospective action is most important.

We cannot get that effect through a case by case approach. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) time and time again has come into the House and said he has found out about a new scheme-often it is a variation of an old scheme-and as from today the Government will knock off that scheme. By that time the scheme has been used for one, two or maybe even more years and that revenue has been lost forever. The industry then goes on to a new scheme, and following that another new scheme . It plays a cat and mouse game which the Taxation Commissioner can never win. The Government must always be on the losing side.

The only effective action that the Government has taken in respect of tax avoidance-how effective it is is yet very unclear-is in respect of Part IVA, which was mentioned by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro. Part IVA seems to have had at least for the time being an inhibiting effect on tax avoidance schemes, on the proliferation of paper schemes. Whether that will continue we do not know. If the industry can find a way around Part IVA-I have no doubt it is working feverishly hard on doing so-we can expect paper schemes to proliferate once again and we will find that we are back to where we were a couple of years ago. At the moment it seems as though there is a temporary lull but that might not be the case for very long. It may well turn out to be a very temporary lull indeed.

Along with the ineffective action on tax avoidance through the legislation which has been undertaken there has also, of course, been no action taken in respect of some schemes which have been allowed to continue. The Treasurer said last Budget that he would legislate against transfer pricing by multinational companies, that is, channelling money around to avoid tax in Australia so that the tax is paid in another country where tax rates might be lower. But we have not seen that legislation. There has been no legislation brought in about that. One would think he has had enough time to produce it since the Budget of last year but we still have not seen it. He has done nothing about the tax avoidance scheme which is available in respect of foreign earned income through the fact that income which is earned overseas and brought back into Australia is currently tax free in Australia once it has been taxed overseas. That, of course , leaves a massive tax loophole which the Treasurer in 1978 said he would close off, but in fact he has not done so. When he raised the possibility of doing that there were screams from those who were involved in those schemes and he therefore backed off doing anything about it. So tax avoidance through that kind of device continues.

He has done nothing about tax avoidance through internal superannuation funds which have been pointed out by others to be a prolific form of tax avoidance. Although remedies are available-they have been pointed to by Asprey amongst others-nothing has been done in respect of closing off tax avoidance loopholes through internal superannuation schemes. I refer here to the setting up of pseudo superannuation schemes which on the face of it appear to be for the superannuation of the employees but which in fact only exploit the tax deduction provisions of the superannuation part of the tax Act to get the deduction. In the end the money is not used for superannuation at all; it is just used for the benefit of those who are the operators of the scheme. These sorts of schemes are being allowed to run on; nothing is being done about them. So we say that the Government's action in respect of tax avoidance has been demonstrably, massively and culpably lax because it has allowed tax avoidance to increase to the massive proportions that exist today.

In respect of tax evasion, the Government also, of course, gathered up its strength in 1978 to look as though it might do something about this problem, but then it backed off. In 1978 the Treasurer said he would do something about the cash economy. He came into the House and discussed the possibility of taking action to require employers of sub-contract labour to deduct pay-as-you-earn tax before payments were made to subcontractors. Nothing was done about that because there were screams from those who were involved. Therefore the Government backed off. It backed off on the one action it has ever proposed in respect of tax evasion and the cash economy. Government members should not come in here then and say to us that we have suggested nothing about tax evasion. The Government backed off from the one scheme it had gathered up the strength actually to announce something about. It did so at the first barks from those involved. It has allowed tax evasion to run on at greater and greater levels.

Of course, now we have the absolute absurdity of the Treasurer saying time and time again, principally at Question Time, that the way around the tax evasion problem is through indirect taxes. What a massive joke that is. He is saying that if there is tax evasion on a wide scale this makes the tax system inequitable. That is certainly true because it means that some people pay little or no tax and others have to pay more, and they tend to be the wage and salary earners. We accept that part of the argument-there is no doubt about that. But then he goes on to say that therefore the way around that is not to stop the tax evasion but to have indirect taxes. He says that we will increase indirect taxes which are generally inequitable or regressive-that is, they bear most heavily on people on lower incomes-as a way around the problem which is created by tax evasion. What a ridiculous idea that is. In other words, he is saying that we will overcome this process which is making the tax system more regressive by adopting another approach which will make the tax system even more regressive. What an absurd and ridiculous argument. It is one that this side of the House absolutely and totally rejects as a solution to the problem.

If the Government wants to do something about tax evasion it should deal with it directly. It should undertake the kind of action which was proposed in 1978. The Government needs to get a lot more tax officials on the ground instead of using staff ceilings to reduce the number of people who are employed in the Taxation Office. It was absurd that this occurred at the beginning of the year. Admittedly, that situation has since been considerably redressed. The Taxation Office, if it is going to overcome tax evasion, needs a lot more tax investigators rather than having staff ceilings imposed on it in a way which inhibits and limits its ability to overcome the problem. To suggest that the answer to tax evasion is increased reliance on indirect taxation is a massive delusion, just as is the suggestion that we cannot afford income tax cuts unless we have indirect tax increases; in other words, we cannot afford to reduce our tax payment from our pay packet unless the Government can take more out of our pay by taxing the goods and services which we buy. What an absurd argument that is. This whole argument about indirect tax is one which has no weight whatsoever . As a solution to tax evasion it is just a delusion.

—The honourable member sought to avoid it by saying that it was only one of the many points he was making. It is worth while dramatising the fact that when he complains about the massive explosion in identifiable avoidance he has to recognise that the Government has to know what is going on before it can identify it. —The honourable member says temporarily. I am intrigued to note that in the honourable member' s speech the one mention he made of the cash economy was where he discussed subcontractors and the statement of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) about them in 1978 . TALK.START.PARA: —That is untrue.

—In this debate the honourable member has not expressed concern about the enormous volume of revenue which is being lost. As I understand it, estimates place it at as much as the identifiable loss through the schemes on which he concentrated all but 30 seconds of his speech.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a vital need for us to recognise that the cash economy has generated an immense tax problem. It means, very simply, that those people who do not pay a reasonable amount of tax, who do not pay what they are supposed to pay, are imposing an immense burden on those who cannot avoid payment. This evasion occurs at both ends of the scale. It occurs at the rich end-on which the honourable member for Gellibrand likes to concentrate, almost exclusively-and at the other end, the cash economy end. It is an economy which is supported by people who are equally culpable when they pay cash without requiring receipts on the acceptance of a cheque, for example, or some other identification or recognisable document. People who seek cash services are as culpable as the person who is evading tax by undertaking for cash only services which are not reported. There is no doubt, as the honourable member for Eden-Monaro (Mr Sainsbury) said, that there is an incredible volume of cases now coming to light of people, having avoided tax, having evaded tax by not stating their income, doubling up by assaulting the taxpayer by claiming social security benefits.

Let us look at the incredible claim of the Labor Party that the only reason that we are suggesting the imposition of indirect taxes is that we cannot collect direct taxes. What an incredible misstatement. What a nonsensical proposition put forward by the honourable member for Gellibrand.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not say that.

—Of course the honourable member said that. His proposition that we find indirect taxes very attractive because we cannot raise money in direct taxes misses one basic point that he and the Labor Party will never be able to understand. Indirect taxes give freedom to the person who is being taxed to decide whether he wants to be subjected to that tax in a very real way. If he wants to consume taxable items, he pays tax. The degree of that tax depends both on the extent to which the item attracts tax and on the price of that item. If, for example, the person is a pensioner and wishes to spend very little on, say, a pair of shoes, those shoes will attract less tax than a very expensive pair of imported shoes. The same applies to dresses.

SPEECH.PARA: It is incredible that this freedom for people to decide what to do with their money, how they will dispose of it, is something that the Labor Party finds so unattractive. Naturally, it is not a party that is in favour of freedom of action on the part of the individual. It is worth reminding the House that the allegation that the sales tax proposals that we have introduced are regressive is deliberately deceptive. The reality is that the bulk of lower income group expenditure patterns relates to items which are not subject to sales tax under the Government's proposals, which the Labor Party is blocking in the Senate by joining with the Australian Democrats. This is costing the revenue something like $330m in a full year.

It seems to me incredible that although it is self-evident that the more people have the capacity to consume and to spend money the greater their expenditure and their taxes will be. To dismiss that situation as regressive and unfair to lower income groups is absurd. It seems to me incredible that the Labor Party would adopt this approach. But it is not incredible to me that the Labor Party opposes the concept of freedom of individual action. It seems important to me that the Australian Government follows the lead set by overseas countries. It should spread our tax base and not be continually accused of being a high tax country simply because our direct taxes are high when the reality is that the tax rate in Australia overall is very low.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kelly Mrs R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it quite appropriate that on St Patrick's Day of 1982 the Government should bring on for discussion as a matter of public importance the question of tax avoidance in which it has demonstrated total hypocrisy over the last five years. The Irish have always been known, I can say this as the only member of the House wearing green today and because of my surname, for their blarney. We have seen that throughout the speeches from Government members today. Unfortunately the Government members who have spoken today have not had the positive assets of the Irish, which are: Intelligence, integrity, honesty and above all a belief that they have to take responsibility for their actions. Today in the debate we have heard the continual berating by the Government of any suggestion that it is at fault. It has said: It is not our fault. It is not our responsibility. It all goes back to the Whitlam Government. How much longer is this going to continue and how much longer is the Government to try to avoid responsibility for its actions? We can see this quite clearly in the taxation area.

SPEECH.PARA: In the debate today we have heard the most amazing hypocrisy. The Government has raised this issue of the inequitable tax burden imposed on wage and salary earners by the artificial tax avoidance schemes and by the cash economy. I agree with that statement, but it is members of the Fraser Government who have caused that situation to arise. It is because of the Government's policies over the last seven years that tax avoidance is a reality. What gross hypocrisy it is for the Government to raise this as an issue. I hope that it will serve at least one useful purpose, that is, that all Government members, particularly those on the back bench, will see that tax avoidance is a reality and will agree that the Government should accept some responsibility for its actions and do something to resolve the situation.

Let us look at what the reality is. Let us look at the burden on pay-as-you- earn taxpayers under the seven years of Fraser Government. As a percentage of total taxation revenue, the taxation paid by PAYE taxpayers has increased from 41.7 per cent in 1975-76 to 45.7 per cent in 1981-82. Therefore, if PAYE taxpayers were to pay the same proportion of total taxation in 1981-82 as they paid in 1975-76, they would be paying $1,506m less. That is over $6 a week for the average household. That is the increased burden that PAYE taxpayers are paying. Why are they paying it? They are paying it because of the direct policies of the Fraser Government. If the proportion of the gross domestic product absorbed by taxation and the proportion of that tax paid by PAYE taxpayers had remained at the 1975-76 levels during the 1981-82 period, PAYE taxpayers would be paying $2,931m less in tax.

It is all very well for me to stand up and quote these huge figures, but what does this mean to the ordinary wage and salary earner and to the ordinary family in Australia? A huge proportion of the people in my electorate are making a massive contribution through PAYE. What is the effect on the ordinary family in Australia? Any person who does normal shopping and who tries to live a normal life in Australia knows what those figures mean in terms of take-home pay. The PAYE taxpayers are bearing the brunt of the disastrous economic mismanagement of this country. They are getting sick and tired of continually paying more tax while businesses, industries and the self-employed are able to take advantage of tax minimisation and tax avoidance schemes and while the less scrupulous are able to get away with tax evasion on a grand scale.

As far as we have heard from this debate there is no tax relief in sight for the wage and salary earners under the Fraser Government's policy. All they can expect is greater financial strain on the family budget. Not only are taxes being increased but also, when these PAYE contributions are added to everything else that is coming out of the family budget-including interest rates, increased health insurance premiums and increased charges for almost all the necessities of life-is an enormous burden placed on the ordinary family. That is what we are talking about today. That is what this matter of public importance really means to ordinary families: It means that they are paying much more and getting less back in their pockets as well as a decline in services and a reduction in ordinary family living standards.

On top of all this, the Government now wants to impose a further tax in the form of sales tax. We recently heard the honourable member for Macarthur (Mr Baume) trying to give a justification for this. But this proposed tax would be imposed on such a wide range of goods, which are required by everyone in the community. Let us hope that this Government sees the error of its ways in this proposed sales tax legislation and does not try again in the next Budget to introduce further tax burdens on the ordinary family in Australia.

The net result of all this is that ordinary Australian families are losing badly under this Government's taxation policies, because not only are they paying more tax but also are they receiving less services. They have received no compensation for their reduction in buying power. Inflation is still as high as ever and the economic forecast is gloomy. That is the reality for the ordinary family after seven years of Fraser government, when all we have heard are promises. But there is a very big gap between each promise and the reality. I ask honourable members to listen to these promises and to compare them with the reality that I have just spoken about and that every Australian family knows about. In 1975, the Prime Minister said:
The Government is not in the business of hitting the pockets of the working men and women of Australia. The Government will bring taxes down further, not increase them.
As we have seen, that has not happened. In his 1977 election speech-elections are a great time for promises-the Prime Minister said:
We have ended the big tax ripoff.
Honourable members should ask the families of Australia about the big tax ripoff . Further, in his 1980 election speech the Prime Minister said:
We are clamping down on tax avoidance.
I look now at that last promise of clamping down on tax avoidance.

The honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) quoted from Professor Russell Mathews' estimate on how much tax avoidance is going on in this country. Eric Risstrom, the Secretary of the Australian Taxpayers Association, estimates that tax avoidance and evasion cost the country approximately $7 billion a year. Now there is no doubt that it is difficult to estimate the amount of money we are losing from revenue in tax avoidance. Nevertheless the facts speak for themselves.

Let us look at the number of taxpayers identified as being involved in tax avoidance. In 1975-76, the number was identified at 861. In 1980-81, the number had grown to 22,366. The 1979-80 Budget made provision for $160m of revenue shortfall for identified but successfully defended tax avoidance schemes by indivuduals and $120m for schemes by companies. In 1980-81 the provisions had grown to $170m and $130m respectively. In 1981-82 the provision has grown to $ 220m for individuals but has reduced to $80m for companies. This growth has occurred despite the Government's claim that it is taking effective action against tax avoidance.

What we have said in our argument today is that the Government has taken this action to try to clamp down on tax avoidance but not for enough. We believe that a great deal more action should be taken in that direction because currently we have in Australia a situation in which the massive burden of taxation falls on the wage and salary earners, on those people who cannot practice tax avoidance and tax evasion. It is not sufficient to get up in this Parliament and attack the carpet layers, the paper boys, the plumbers and the housewives. What we want is a fair and equitable taxation system for Australia.
