TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:

PETITION.TITLE: Sex Discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
(a) that the Australian Government signed the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination Against Women in Copenhagen in 1980;
(b) that the Convention came into force on 3 September 1981;

(c) that Australian women suffer serious disadvantage in employment, education, accommodation, membership of licensed clubs, provision of goods and services including services relating to banking, insurance and the provision of grants, loans, credit or finance;

(d) that this disadvantage could be overcome by (i) making unlawful certain discrimination on the grounds of sex and marital status, (ii) eliminating discrimination on the ground of sex and marital status and (iii) promoting affirmative action for women in employment.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament pass the Sex and Marital Status Discrimination Bill 1981.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Dr Blewett,Mr Robert Brown,Mr Morris and Mr Uren.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :

That the Government's decision to impose a tax on books, magazines and newspapers is abhorrent to the notion of the right to information, and that no such tax is levied on any other country with which Australia is usually compared .
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw its announced intention to impose a sales tax on books, magazines and newspapers.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Darling and Mr Goodluck.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the proposed sales tax of 2.5% on books, magazines and newspapers represents a tax on knowledge which should not be contemplated in a civilised country. Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that this proposed sales tax be withdrawn from the Budget proposals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
We the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth do humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government:

2. Uphold the principle that the seeds and cuttings of plants are a public resource and a common heritage to all and that accordingly seeds should be freely available to all, freely multipliable, able to be sold, exchanged, exported and imported by anyone who wishes. This is seen as a matter of national food security.

2. Recognize that plant breeding is a highly co-operative venture often involving private enterprise at the very last stages after basic seed collection , storage, and research has been publicly funded.
3. In view of the aforementioned paragraphs, recognize that any system giving ' property' or ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises is inappropriate and unjust.
4. Recognize that legislation establishing plant patenting schemes overseas has had serious adverse effects namely:
(i) a slowing-down of scientific information exchange and exchanges in basic plant breeding materials, that is, germ plasm,
(ii) subordination and/or curtailment of public breeding programs,
(iii) farmer unrest at seed prices,
(iv) monopoly control of seed production and sales has passed into the hands of giant petrochemical and drug corporations also marketing crop chemicals,
(v) increased uniformity of crop varieties leading to a vulnerability to pest and disease attack.
5. Reject any proposal to legislate for any system such as the drafted Plant Variety Rights Act, which gives exclusive ownership rights over seeds to individuals, organisations or enterprises.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Burr and Mr Cunningham.

PETITION.TITLE: National Estate Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives, in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned at the lack of effective Federal environmental protection legislation and urge that suitable legislation be enacted immediately.

Your petitioners are concerned that National Estate areas such as South West Tasmania, the Great Barrier Reef and the Western Australian Jarrah Forests cannot be fully protected until adequate legislation exists and is enforced. Your humble petitioners therefore call upon the House of Representatives to ensure that all provisions of the Heritage Act and the Environment Impact of Proposals Act are fully complied with in respect of National Estate Areas. In particular your petitioners call upon you to adopt the recommendations of the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Environment on South West Tasmania. Your petitioners believe that this is a national issue and must be resolved by the action of the Federal Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr MacKenzie and Mr Ruddock.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Land Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in the Federal Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the humble petitioners respectfully believe that the recent report of the World Council of Churches team which visited Australia, June 15 to July 3, 1981, emphasises the central importance of land rights to the Aboriginal people and noting that all attempts by white Australians to manage Aboriginal affairs for them have failed.
Your petitioners therefore pray:

That the Federal Government will accept its responsibility and use its powers under the Constitution to over-ride racist state legislation, particularly to provide Land Rights with freehold title, and

That in addition the Government fulfil its stated policy of self-determination and self-management for Aboriginal people, by funding all housing, health, education, legal, employment strategy and welfare matters concerning Aboriginal people directly through Aboriginal Community-based Community-controlled organisations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Day
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker, and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the 26th January, 1788 is the date of first white settlement in Australia, and therefore marks the beginning of modern Australia, and this event marks the most appropriate date on which to celebrate our national day.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will determine that Australia Day is to be celebrated on the twenty-sixth day of January each year, and that a public holiday will be declared on that day, regardless of which day of the week is the 26th.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Interest Rates
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned that the Government is not protecting family home buyers from the severe effects of increased and increasing rates by interest on home mortgage loans.

Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action through tax relief and other measures to avert any further effects of increases in interest rates on home mortgage loans which cause detrimental financial, social and psychological pressures on families, and in many cases, positive hardship.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Land Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the projected repeal by the Queensland State Government of the Aborigines Act 1971-1979 and the Torres Strait Islanders Act 1971-1979 will almost certainly lead to the degazettal of all Aboriginal reserves in Queensland, as has already been the case with Aurukun and Mornington Island.

That if, as is likely, the Aboriginal communities from these reserves are placed under similar shire council legislation on fifty years leases, they will be exposed to serious encroachment on their land by mining and tourist interests .

That it is also quite clear, on past evidence, that these interests will have the full backing of the Queensland Government and the rights of Aboriginal people to land rights and self-management will not be granted by that Government .

That the Commonwealth Government has the power to legislate and acquire land for Aboriginal people under its constitutional powers since the amendments to the Constitution in 1967, but it is your Petitioners' sincere belief that it failed to act in 1976 and thus, failed in its duty before the people of Aurukun and Mornington Island.
That the Aboriginal people of Queensland have stated that they want land rights and self management.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government make use of its constitutional and legislative powers to grant full land rights and self-management to the Aboriginal people of Queensland.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That the Government's Sales Tax legislation imposes an unreasonable burden on the community generally, especially pensioners, families, those in receipt of smaller incomes and small businesses.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government will withdraw or repeal its Sales Tax Legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioner Non-interest Bearing Accounts
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

The proposals announced by the Minister Senator F. Chaney to amend the Social Services Act limiting the sum of money to be retained in a current/cheque account to $2000 for a single pensioner and $3000 for a married couple are unacceptable in that:

both single and married pensioners are, at regular intervals, faced with meeting recurrent expenses in connection with home maintenance, insurance, motor vehicle repairs and so on, for which no financial provision or assistance is given
that such recurrent expenditure, when coupled with unexpected or unplanned expenses arising from family crises, health or funeral costs, may quickly exceed the proposed new limits
no other repository, except a current/cheque account, is able to provide funds as conveniently, or at short notice to pensioners

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to consult with the Australian Pensioners League and other pensioner groups in order to arrive at just and equitable legislation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Broadcasting Licences
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :
That Family Radio Ltd represents the largest single interest group in the community-i.e., christians-who do not have a voice in public broadcasting commensurate with their representation;
that prime time access to existing broadcasts by christian groups is virtually non-existent, and access at other times is fast disappearing;
that, by comparison with other capitals, Brisbane is entitled to at least one more category 'S' FM broadcasting licence;
that there appears to be no prospect of the release of further category 'S' FM licences in the near future for Brisbane;
that satisfactory fulfillment of the aims of Family Radio and its expansion can only be achieved by broadcasting in its own right under licence;

that Family Radio has a responsibility to the large support groups which have contributed substantially to its development, to achieve the aims in broadcasting and community work for which it was established;

that there is an urgent need for the kind of service and support that family radio can provide to other community groups through the particular type of integrated programming proposed by the company under a full-time licence;
and that pruned Government resources are obviously insufficient to advance the development of public broadcasting as originally intended.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the government will support Family Radio's application for a broadcasting license and will enable more category 'S' FM licences to be made available in Brisbane.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of citizens of the Commonwealth submits:

That the mining of uranium in Australia, the proposed development of a uranium enrichment industry in Australia, together with the possibilities of resumed atomic weapons testing in the Pacific and dumping of radioactive waste in this region, constitute a serious threat to the health and well-being of all Australian and Pacific people for many generations to come.
Your Petitioners request that your Honourable House will:
1. Stop the mining and export of Australian uranium, except for medical and research purposes.
2. Actively oppose the development of uranium enrichment and nuclear power plants, the testing of nuclear weapons, and the disposal of radioactive waste in the Australian and Pacific region.
3. Significantly increase research into alternative energy sources.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telegram Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :

That the Government and Telecom management have presided over the deliberate scaling down of Australia's telegram services, to the disadvantage of those poorer people in the community who cannot afford telex or telephone facilities and rely on the telegram service in time of emergency;

That the Government and Telecom management have undermined the telegram service by increasing the unit cost of telegrams by over 130 per cent in four years with the result that the use of telegrams as a form of communication has fallen by approximately 60 per cent in that time.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government and Telecom management retain the telegram service at a standard and cost that will not disadvantage the ordinary citizen.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

(i) the financial situation of students enrolled at Australian post-secondary institutions is already extremely difficult (as indicated in the Commonwealth Department of Education's 1979 survey of student incomes and expenditure) and any substantial increase in the financial commitments of students would gravely worsen their financial difficulties.

(ii) the imposition of post-secondary tuition fees of comparable levels to those imposed prior to 1971 would force many currently enrolled students to discontinue their studies and deter many persons willing and able at present to undertake post-secondary study from doing so.

(iii) those students and potential students from social groups currently under- represented and disadvantaged in the post-secondary education system would be most severely affected by the reintroduction of fees for post-secondary education.
Your petitioners therefore pray that:
1. post-secondary tuition fees not be re-introduced for any courses or for any category of students
2. the visa charges upon private overseas students be removed immediately
3. the Minister for Education immediately clarify the government's attitude to the re-introduction of post- secondary tuition fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioner Non-interest Bearing Accounts
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth :

That any proposal by the Government to threaten pensioners' entitlements to fringe benefits by establishing a ceiling on the allowable amount of savings in non-interest bearing accounts is completely unfair and does not take account of the natural need of all pensioners to maintain some savings for occasional expenses such as house maintenance.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Government will not proceed with any such proposal, and should instead direct its attention to those pensioners who enjoy extremely high levels of extra income yet manage to remain with pension eligibility guidelines.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

The concern of the Federation of Parents and Friends of Catholic Schools of Tasmania at the effects the recently introduced 2 1/2% SALES TAX on essential educational items such as school clothing, books, publications, etc.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should request the Government to abolish the tax impost.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the Budget imposition of additional sales tax to both existing sales taxed items and to previously exempt goods:
(a) will add to the regressivity of the tax structure by imposing a similar burden on all sections of the community-regardless of the capacity to pay tax;
(b) will be highly inflationary and a disincentive to economic performance in key sectors of manufacturing industry, e.g. car manufacturing; textiles and footwear; boat-building;

(c) is yet another breach of Government promise, given the Treasurer's undertaking in the Parliament on March 12 of this year that there would be no increases in indirect taxation (without at the same time giving personal tax relief).

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to repeal the budget amendments to sales tax legislation and to withdraw its sales tax amendment bills which add sales tax to presently exempt goods.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That Moreton Island has been listed on the Register of the National Estate because of its exceptional scientific, ecological, heritage and recreational values; and
(2) That any sand mining of Moreton Island will result in the destruction of the exceptional scientific, ecological, heritage and recreational values of the Island; and

(3) That Moreton Island has been the subject of detailed investigation resulting in the adoption of a Management Plan by the Brisbane City Council the main aims of which are to conserve in its natural state the quality of its scenery and natural environment and to enhance public enjoyment of it for recreation purposes; and
(4) That Moreton Island represents the last significant area of wilderness close to Brisbane; and
(5) That there is an acute deficiency of National Parks within a 150 kilometre radius of Brisbane; and
(6) That Moreton Island contains Aboriginal Relics of immense scientific and cultural importance; and
(7) That the Island represents a major potential tourist resource specifically because of its unspoiled natural scenic attractions; and

(8) That public opinion actively demonstrated over a number of years clearly indicates that most citizens of Brisbane are strongly opposed to any sand mining on the Island, and desire that the whole of Moreton Island with the exception only of existing Townships, Tourist Resort, Airstrips and Lighthouse Reserve should be declared a National Park.
Your Petitioners, therefore, humbly pray that the Parliament of Australia will:

(a) accept the wishes of the Petitioners and the citizens of Brisbane generally and take whatever action is necessary and available to it to prevent sand mining of any description taking place on Moreton Island; and

(b) request the Government of the State of Queensland to take immediate action to declare the whole of Moreton Island to be a National Park with the exception only of existing Townships, Tourist Resort, Airstrips and Lighthouse Reserve.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Export of Live Animals
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That (a) the export of live animals for slaughter overseas and (b) the shipment of live horses to Japan sentences such animals to cruel and inhumane treatment in the export process and at the hands of foreign importers.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to ban the export of live animals for food and allow only carcass trade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Use of Live Animals in Research
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.
2. That no central records exist on such inhumane use of live animals for experimentation purposes, yet research institutions in several Australian States engage in such a practice.
3. That there exists no uniform legislation between the States concerning responsible standards of research conduct, indeed, in some States there is a complete lack of legislation altogether.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will enact legislation to require:
(a) the Australian Bureau of Statistics to produce annual statistics on the numbers of live animals involved in research, and provide information as to research purposes; and

(b) the National Health and Medical Research Council to develop humane and responsible standards of conduct for researchers using live animals in all Government, Industry and Educational Research Laboratories.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Westernport Youth Refuge, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned about the possible closure of the Westernport Youth Refuge because of inadequate funds made available under the Youth Accommodation Services Program (a joint Department of Community Welfare Services and Department of Social Security Program).

Over a 12 month period more than 500 young people have been assisted by the refuge. If it is forced to close then many homeless young people in the Westernport Region will be left without any assistance at all.
Your petitioners, in duty bound, humbly pray that additional funds be provided under the Youth Accommodation Services Program.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of Australian Parliament assembled.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Parliament assembled take action as it deems appropriate to ensure that the present Federal Government children's services program is maintained and improved, and the Child Care Act is retained as a legislative base for this important program.
In considering the recommendations of the Spender report, no recommendations put forward should be implemented without full consultation with community groups.

The present subsidy system to Child Care Centres should be retained. The proposal that moneys be made available to subsidise child care in commercial centres is viewed with grave concern. The proposal to alter the present guidelines for subsidy in different programs and introduce a common means test is also viewed with grave concern, as the present arrangements are effective.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action on the abovementioned issues.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Registration Fee for Periodicals
PETITION.PARA: To the Right Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the recently introduced annual registration fee for periodicals considerably adds to the administrative costs of small clubs and organisations, whose activities are non profit and are directly involved in community activities. With many periodicals produced for distribution to members in small numbers only, this new impost, together with the recent increases in postage rates, considerably adds to costs.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Government request Australia post to review the recently introduced annual registration fee for periodicals, with a view to smaller clubs and organisations, at least, being exempted from the requirements of annual registration.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

That Federal funding of children's services which is currently almost 50 per cent reduced in real terms should be restored forthwith to at least the 1975-76 level in real terms so that children's services are distributed more equitably throughout Australia.

That current plans to impose a standardised means test throughout Australia on users of children's services does not recognise the differences of local areas with the potential to disadvantage the bulk of users in areas of economic need such as Marrickville and should be dropped forthwith.

That the stated intention to use public funds to supplement private sector children's services which operate for profit conflicts with the community orientation of the Children's Services Programme and should not be implemented.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nambour Lions Club Emergency Centre and Shelter, Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the decision not to refund the Nambour Lions Emergency Accommodation Centre will cause serious hardship and distress to many already disadvantaged families on the Sunshine Coast.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth and State Governments continue to fund the Nambour Lions Club Emergency Centre and Shelter .
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Sales Tax Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That Australian families will be seriously affected by the budget announcements which include the raising of, or imposing of, Sales Tax on the many items which must be provided by parents for their children's schooling.
We condemn the proposals as a regressive tax measure which will seriously affect Australia's students.

Sales Tax increases will affect the price to parents of a variety of items including school clothing, school footwear, exercise books, books and magazines for reading purposes, stationery, sports equipment, and other school requisites and will seriously disadvantage parents who are already finding it difficult to provide essential educational items.
Your petitioners request that the Government (or Senate) will not impose any further tax on these items which are needed for the educational progress of Australia's students.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Plant Variety Rights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth concern over Plant Variety Rights (PVR) legislation.
We agree that:
1. PVR will aggravate the free exchange of genetic material for plant breeding.
2. PVR will not enhance Australia's access to improved plant varieties developed overseas but will encourage the dumping of unsuitable varieties on the Australian market.
3. PVR will restrict the public plant breeding program to basic research for exploitation by private enterprise and discourage breeding for disease and pest resistant varieties.
4. PVR will lead to the domination of the seed industry by foreign interests not responsible to the Australian people.
5. The proprietary rights granted by PVR will encourage the introduction of seed distribution and marketing monopolies and lead to seed price increases.
Your petitioners therefore pray that Parliament:
1. refrains from enacting any legislation on PVR,
2. calls for a public inquiry into the impact of existing overseas PVR Schemes on the Australian seed industry and the international seed trade.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned that the Government is not fulfilling its responsibility in ensuring an adequate standard of living for all Australians, which is causing untold hardship on relief agencies' limited resources, and require the following steps to be taken as a matter of urgency:
1. That the Commonwealth Government raise the level of all pensions and benefits at least to the Poverty line.
2. That the Commonwealth Government reconsider its recent decisions in relation to the health system and cuts to Commonwealth activity.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert further poverty and suffering in our community by implementation of the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Highway, Queensland
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned electors of North Queensland respectfully showeth:
That the National Highway is the responsibility of the Federal Government,
The Bruce Highway in North Queensland is of inferior standard for a National Highway,
Queensland has suffered a 15% disadvantage over other states during the past ten years in road funding,
and the state of the Highway is deteriorating as maintenance expenditure is insufficient to maintain even the present standard.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament will allocate sufficient expenditure, to raise the standard of the National Highway in North Queensland to Department of Transport standards, in conjunction with the Queensland Government, within ten years.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Commission: Melbourne Showband
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the Australian Parliament as in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Victoria respectfully showeth that:
As regular viewers and listeners of the ABC Melbourne Showband we were disappointed to learn of the dismissal of seventeen members of this outstanding orchestra.

We have had a great deal of pleasure over the past eight years viewing and listening to this band's fine music. It is the only full-time light orchestra in Australia and we are disgusted to think that such talented musicians should be dismissed in this manner.
We therefore call on the Federal Government to rescind this decision and make more money available for the continuance of the full Showband.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Minister for Communications
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled, the humble petition of the undersigned members of the Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union respectfully showeth:

That the Prime Minister of Australia should seek the resignation of the Minister for Communications. Failing this the Prime Minister should dismiss the aforementioned Minister. We seek this action following the Minister's apparent lack of concern for the welfare of his employees in the Australian Postal Commission and the Australian Telecommunications Commission.

Staff ceilings imposed as directed by the Minister show that the future employment security of Australian Postal and Telecommunications Union members is jeopardised. It is our educated estimation that these staff ceilings will also affect the standard of service provided to the public by the two Commissions.
Your petitioners therefore pray that the Prime Minister will take immediate action to abide by our desire.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Motor Vehicle Industry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. This Petition of the undersigned electors of the Division of Burke respectfully showeth that:
1. the automotive products industry is vital to the livelihood and well being of many thousands of Australian workers and their families.
2. if imported automotive products are allowed to flow freely into the Australian market it will deprive over 100,000 workers in the industry of their work opportunities.
Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Parliament recognise the rights of Australian Workers in this industry and that proposals to reduce the level of protection in the future be rejected.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 25 February, on motion by Mr Moore:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hurford Mr C.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Bill before the House, the Bounty Acts Amendment Bill, is to extend for another year the payment of bounties to two industries, the drilling bits industry and the non-adjustable wrenches industry. We can tell of what riveting interest this matter is by the number of honourable members present, but I know that there are many others working hard at their desks, moving paper, who cannot wait to hear that the Opposition supports this Bill. Their suspense is now removed and I am able to say more about the Bill and also about these industries, which are of importance to our country. The bounties, or subsidies, for these industries were introduced as a short term assistance measure, initially at double the rate provided in this Bill. The extension of the bounty scheme until the end of this year at half the rate can be seen as a phasing arrangement towards frankly a lower rate of assistance. From the beginning of next year the form of assistance will revert to tariffs-25 per cent for the non-adjustable wrenches industry and 15 per cent for the drilling bits industry.

SPEECH.PARA: We on the Opposition side of the House believe that both of these industries, despite their small size, are very important to our country. They confer benefits of the type that only local manufacturing industry can. Some of the benefits include advanced technology, the employment of skilled labour, security of supply of strategically and industrially important items and also the spreading of the benefits of developments in the minerals industry to a wider range of occupations.

These two industries are also not likely to require heavy assistance in the longer term. The nominal rates of tariff which apply to the industries are not unduly high. The tariffs of 25 per cent for the non-adjustable wrenches industry and 15 per cent for the drilling bits industry are not high by any standard, particularly in comparison with many other industries, or indeed in comparison with the average for the manufacturing industry. Incidentally, the average for the manufacturing industry which is about 15 per cent and the average for the metal industries which is about 20 per cent are a lot lower than many people in our community think they are.

The provision of additional short term assistance has been justified as necessary to allow the firms engaged in these industries to improve their competitiveness through new investment and improved quality. In respect of drilling bits, there has also been a problem of alleged dumping, and action has been taken by that industry on imports of bits from America. Although bounties and general tariffs are not designed to counter the impact of dumping, it is a matter of concern to the Australian Labor Party that Australia, being a very small market in comparison with so many other countries, is so vulnerable to dumping activities. The present government machinery to identify and act against dumping is, in our view, inadequate and it is far too slow moving. Our tariff, quota, and bounty assistance in part is necessary because of Australia's vulnerability, as a small market, to dumping. When people criticise the levels of protection for Australian industry they should be more aware of these types of problems such as the dumping problem. There are very few, if any, firms in Australia that are large enough to cause injury to a foreign market through dumping, but the converse does not apply. There are hundreds of foreign firms for which the entire Australian market would represent only a small proportion of their production.

In circumstances of world economic recession, it is not surprising therefore that Australia is especially vulnerable to unfair trading practices, such as dumping or strategic pricing, as these large overseas corporations seek to maintain their scale economies and aggregate sales by selling at low prices into any market they can, particularly the Australian market. Unlike many markets for industrial products, Australia is wide open for such trade. The non-tariff barriers which are a feature of so many other countries are virtually non- existent here. I would hope that a reduction in these non-tariff barriers can be achieved by other countries, but until they are there is no point in expecting that, in our more overt way of protection, sharp reductions in tariffs or bounties will be possible or acceptable for Australia.

Many efficient industries are vulnerable in an open market environment because, contrary to the dreams and fantasies of some of the economic rationalists who sit on the other side of this Parliament-I notice none of them are in the chamber at present-the rest of the world does not follow the rules of Adam Smith . Those people opposite think that the rest of the world does follow the rules of Adam Smith and they expect us to do so as well. The result of their expectations or aspirations would be disaster for employment in this country. On the contrary, the real world is comprised of very large firms and even some non- market countries which do not play by the rules of perfect competition and comparative advantage. This, of course, applies particularly to countries behind the Iron Curtain which do not follow those rules. It is possible, indeed highly likely, that a country which ignores this will be disadvantaged in the longer term. Its industries and growth prospects will be predated by larger, but not necessarily more efficient foreign companies.

It is essential that government action be taken in Australia to ensure that our domestic manufacturing industries are given a chance to develop their products and skills, to invest, to become competitive on fair terms and to grow. That is why the Opposition supports this Bill, and it is also why we are critical of the Government's manufacturing policies generally.

This Bill is just so inadequate as an expression of manufacturing industry policy. It provides breathing space for two local companies, but it does not constitute the vitally needed, planned approach to our economic development generally. The two industries which we are discussing are both within the metal trades. Yesterday honourable members would have read of the Metal Trades Industry Association prediction for 1982. The results of this survey came out at the end of last week and have received quite a deal of publicity. The February survey of the MTIA reveals further deterioration of trading conditions and less confidence about the future. The problems include high import competition, low export sales, a lower level of investment and stagnant industry employment. The survey revealed that in February production was down and expected investment was down on the previous year's figures. There must be no doubt as to the cause of this problem. It has arisen as a response to the disastrous mismanagement of the economy which has occurred over the course of 1981 and which of course is continuing to occur during this year, 1982.

We have seen the Government's tight money policy lead to a collapse of demand and investment. We have also seen it lead to enormously high interest rates. The mismanagement of the exchange rate, which went up by over 10 per cent over the course of a year, and which collapsed down again in an even shorter period, has greatly destabilised manufacturing industry. The Government's own message to business, firstly bullish and exaggerated-talking about the resources boom that was with us-is now all doom and gloom. It has also destabilised industry in this country and accordingly has jeopardised employment. Added to this, as if this were not enough, has been the massive uncertainty created by the Government's wild swings on the issue of industry protection. We still await the outcome of the rash of references to the Industries Assistance Commission, which the Government pursued in one of its optimistic moods last year. In all of these respects, we have seen ad hockery and uncertainty run wild, whereas the great need of Australian industry is a degree of certainty and security. Without this certainty, investment for growth is virtually impossible. This is one of the fundamental reasons why manufacturing continues at such a low ebb, in such a malaise, in Australia at present. Instead, a planned approach whereby everyone is aware of and can have some confidence in a national strategy for the re- industrialisation of Australia is essential. The occasional bounty Bill does not add up to that planned approach and that new strategy. It does not achieve our purpose.

Let us take, for example, the drilling bits industry, one of the two industries under consideration in this Bill. Here is an industry in which, because Australia has a large mining industry, a related manufacturing industry can develop. Initially, the appropriate policies were pursued. In 1973 the Australian Industry Development Corporation, a government instrumentality, provided funds to Wepco Pty Ltd, a local company, with the aim of developing a range of percussive bits and hammers. This made a great deal of sense because, if a longer term view were taken, it would readily be seen that Australia could develop expertise in this mining-related area. In addition, since Wepco's drilling bits are made of mainly imported materials, there are subsequent rounds of import replacing development available. Unfortunately, in 1976, after that initiative from the Australian Industry Development Corporation had met with certain success, Wepco was taken over by an American multinational company, Dresser Industrial Inc., based in Texas. As a result, the foreign company acquired the technology developed in Australia with the use of Australian funds.

Often the excuse for allowing these international companies to take over our own companies is that the Australian company is too small, and would not have enough funds to undertake research and development in order to develop in the way that it should. Wepco is a classic case in which the multinational company which came in and took over an Australian company, took over its research and development. This is a tragedy for us. I am not making an objection to this particular set of events. Frankly, I have not had the opportunity to go back and look at the Foreign Investment Review Board report of this takeover. I am not making an attack on the company without the necessary background knowledge to do so. But, surely, it is another example of inadequate forward planning and muddled objective setting in Australian industry policy that we allow this sort of thing to happen.

The rock drills industry in Australia is almost entirely in foreign hands. The level of imports of rock drill bits of all types has grown from $7.8m in 1976-77 to $15.5m in 1979-80. As much as 85 per cent of the drill bit market in Australia is supplied by imports. The remainder is provided by the subsidiaries of foreign companies, which subsidiaries accordingly now fully own and control the technologies involved. Whereas we should have a worthwhile manufacturing industry owned by Australians, with research and development in an area where we have so many opportunities being pursued by Australians, instead the story is such a sad one, as I have just related. What this points to is a failure of Government policy. Australia has lost because of the open door policy taken by conservatives who in recent years, sadly for this nation, have ruled it more often than not for one reason or another. That open door policy of the Government to the takeover of our innovative, small manufacturing industries by multinationals has caused this problem. We have lost because we have not put enough effort into research, development and design of new products. We continue to lose because no effort is made to identify development opportunities and to pursue them in a planned and co-ordinated way.

Australia must make greater efforts to develop other manufacturing activities related to resource projects. It is just one of the opportunities that we must grab and run with. Australian manufacturers should be encouraged to supply a greater proportion of the equipment and materials used by major mining projects. Linking manufacturing to resource development is one of the principal means of spreading the benefits of that development. It is particularly important to the manufacturing States such as Victoria and South Australia. I hope that anybody in Victoria, with the coming State election, who has listened to my remarks will note the different attitude of the Australian Labor Party when compared with that of the coalition parties in the Parliament on this issue.

In both Canada and the United Kingdom, government planning offices have been established to achieve this objective of linking more manufacturing activity to resource projects. In Canada the Office of Industrial and Regional Benefits seeks the maximum possible use of planning skills, project development ability, machinery and materials supplies from local companies. In the United Kingdom an agency known as an Offshore Supplies Office seeks the same objective in relation to North Sea development. I am proud to say that it was a Labour government in the United Kingdom that realised that, with the great North Sea oil development that was taking place, there was not enough flow-over of industrial activity in the manufacturing sector in the United Kingdom and that such a flow into that manufacturing sector required some government involvement.

I will break off for a moment and say that it is quite natural in many ways that overseas companies that are involved in these big projects such as the North Sea oil drilling, because of their personnel-where they come from and where they have been trained-will naturally think in terms of using the products of the countries from which their personnel have come. If the engineers are American, they know the American companies and the American specifications and they tend to go to America for the support services and equipment needed in those projects. Similarly, in this country, the more that we allow our large projects, such as the open cut coal projects run by Utah Mining Australia Ltd, to be in the hands of foreign multinationals, the more the result will be that those multinational companies will look elsewhere in the world for the provision of services and of equipment for the projects. Where we can have Australian involvement, we can have more Australian services and equipment being used. The statistics show this to be the case.

But it is not always possible for Australian companies to be the developers in these great projects and that is why we need an agency such as the United Kingdom Offshore Supplies Office, or the Canadian Office of Industrial and Regional Benefits to stimulate the use of Australian products and Australian services in these great projects. The planning agencies in those countries have been very successful. In contrast in this country we are suffering a balance of payments deficit in part due to the import of machinery and materials for resource development. The coalition Government's rejection of the planning approach which I am advocating, and of the Government's involvement in the form which I am suggesting to the House is advisable, results in our not maximising our opportunities. Job creation ventures and growth are being lost because insufficient effort is being made to maximise local involvement in resource investment. The metal industry still has sectors working at only three-quarters capacity.

One of the principal features of Labor's economic policies is that a management machinery will be established so that Government policy will, wherever practicable, provide an avenue for local companies to supply the needs of the major resource projects. It is very likely that some bird brain on the other side of politics will accuse me of socialism in putting this forward. I will be quite proud if he does so but, of course, in throwing out that word, the Government looks upon it as a dirty word. I do not. Indeed, I have shown by the examples I have given that there are great benefits for the Australian community , for the creation of other jobs, if indeed we pursue such activities. I might say that because of what I would consider-I am sure my colleagues do also-to be some very sensible provisions for the motor vehicle manufacturing industry, one Maximilian Walsh, in today's Bulletin, has suggested that they are the greatest examples of socialism that he has discovered in a long time.

If that is so, so be it, but for goodness sake let us get on with it sooner rather than later. If ever the motor vehicle manufacturing industry required a different policy, it is now. If ever an industry required something better than the export facilitation policies that are being put forward by the Government at present, it is the motor vehicle manufacturing industry. The tragedy of this Government, from the point of view of industry, is that it is ideologically opposed to any form of Government action in relation to resource allocation. While that happens, we will not have a proper spread of the benefits to the Australian people.

As a result of these policies, the Government does not attempt some of the worthwhile innovations which are attempted by even some of the conservative governments overseas. The Office of Offshore Supplies which I mentioned earlier was set up by a conservative government in England. Similarly in Japan, the Ministry for International Trade and Industry has for a very long time defined leading sectors in the economy and pursued rapid development in these sectors through a mixture of government and private sector initiatives. Australia is one of the few countries in the world whose industrial policies have focused almost solely on protective devices, such as the tariffs and bounties we are considering here, and so little on positive development devices, such as research, co-ordinated planning, protection of innovative companies from predation by imports or multinational takeovers, and other forms of creative assistance.

The present Government stands condemned on this issue. The performance of manufacturing under it has been abysmal. In six years almost nothing has been achieved. The levels of imports of manufactures is the main reason that Australia is now under serious balance of payment pressure. The failure of manufacturing employment to grow accounts for a major proportion of our record unemployment problem.

I repeat, the Opposition, in supporting this Bill, takes the opportunity to say what is wrong in other areas of the industrial policy of this country. We support the Bill because it provides continuing breathing space for the industries that it assists, but it is not a long term panacea. However, we are as convinced as we ever have been that unless a completely revamped industry policy is put in place in Australia our manufacturing sector will continue to suffer the malaise identified six years ago by the Jackson Committee to advise on Policies for Manufacturing Industry-a malaise that is still ignored. The Labor Party believes that Australia's progress is dependent on a renewed national development effort. It believes that this effort must be consciously pursued by State and Federal governments acting with the private sector and the trade union movement. We seek a co-operative approach towards an economic and social strategy which will permit a much improved performance, not just in one or two glamour industries, but across a broad spectrum of national development.

In closing, I wish to say something about Labor's strategy which presents an alternative to the one that I have been criticising and under which we are suffering at present. The co-operation that Labor would pursue would be followed through at every level but at its peak there would be an Economic Planning Advisory Council which would have continuous access to Cabinet and have its own staff, thereby ensuring that its business and union members could have an independent and effective role in the making of key decisions at the national level.

One of its primary objectives would be the attainment of a prices and incomes policy in Australia. An anti-inflation strategy is absolutely vital to manufacturing industry-even branches of it such as the two that I have been talking about this afternoon, that are subject to bounty help. Only if wage and price setting can be brought into line with a structure of agreed guidelines can we pursue a more expansionary economic policy without running the risk of incurring even higher inflation levels. This direct approach to controlling inflation is essential. The only alternative, that which has been pursued so unsuccessfully for the last six years, is to keep the lid on the economy forever . It works very poorly and its costs in terms of unemployment, low growth, poor productivity, increasing social and regional divisions--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Would it be too much of a wrench for the honourable member to come back to the Bill?

—As I have explained, Mr Deputy Speaker, I am using this Bill as a means of illustrating the difference between the strategies of the two major political forces in this country. I will come back to the Bill by pointing out that it is only a breathing space measure; that what is more important is the purpose of that breathing space.

SPEECH.PARA: I conclude by saying that if we can achieve the alternative strategy-the seeking of a more co-operative attitude-and gain agreement on wages and price restraint during the breathing space that will be created by this Bounty Bill, it will be possible to allow a stronger growth of the economy, by means of a more expansionary monetary and Budgetary policy, to occur. It will also be possible to achieve lower interest rates and, I hope, through activity in industries such as the two that are the subject of this Bill, to reduce unemployment, which is at such disastrously high levels at this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford), in his address, has taken the usual tilts at the Government's economic and industry policies. I recognise that at this time there is a slow-down in economic activity which, perhaps, is most strongly felt in the manufacturing sector. But when the honourable member talks of policy he does not offer any viable alternative policy. As the honourable member pointed out, the Bounty Acts Amendment Bill is part of the Government's industry policy which is directed towards the encouragement of manufacturing activities which are more specialised , low cost, competitive, innovative and export oriented. That industry policy, in turn, is part of the overall economic policy of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The alternative, such as it is, offered by the Opposition involves, in the industry area, more planning, more control and more smothering bureaucracy, and in overall economic policy a program which would undoubtedly lead to increasing costs and inflation-the worst thing, from the point of view of industry, that could occur. The honourable member should recognise that one of the most important things in respect of industry policy that one can do is achieve an internationally competitive cost position. That is, in fact, just what this Government has achieved. Thereby it has stimulated activity in both import competing and export industries. I agree that there has been some slippage in that regard in recent months. One factor in this was the appreciation of the currency in the period to August-September. That situation has now changed with a movement since then in the other direction. The honourable member had the gall to refer specifically to Labor's policy in respect of the motor vehicle industry . A key passage of that policy states:
In the context of substantial Government support for the industry, it is essential that the Government be involved in the formulation of plans-
Note the small 'p'-in short, planning-

for the industry's future structure. It is also necessary that the Government monitor and regulate to the extent necessary, pricing and component sourcing decisions of the major vehicle assemblers. A Labor Government will establish an Automotive Industry Authority to achieve this planning and regulation of the industry.
Honourable members should note that the statement says 'regulate pricing decisions' of the major companies. One might as well nationalise them straight out.

In this context, and in contrast to Labor's stated policy, the policy of this side of the House involves a plan with a capital 'P'-but within the parameters of that plan the market will determine the outcome. That has already had the effect that motor cars in Germany and the United Kingdom are already being driven around by engines made in Australia. The honourable member for Adelaide, straying somewhat from the subject of bounties, referred to the central feature of the Government's policy in this area, namely, export facilitation. The Government makes no apology for its emphasis on export facilitation. It is a powerful force which at the same time ensures firstly, the continuation of a sizeable industry in Australia and secondly, makes for a more export oriented industry, for cost reduction and for new investment in large scale-one hopes world scale-plants to produce particular components cheaply, while other components that would be high cost components if manufactured in Australia, are imported. It is also a powerful force for rationalisation and amalgamation in the industry. I ask the Australian people to compare these two approaches-a motor vehicle authority planning the industry, overseeing its pricing decisions and in general setting up a smothering bureaucracy to create an industry which would be a high cost island in the whole world economy, as against the proposals to which I have just referred that come from this side of the House. So much for the planning to which the honourable member referred.

He also referred to certain references which the Government has sent to the Industries Assistance Commission. The reference relating to a general reduction of tariffs was made in accordance with the terms of our acceptance of the report of the Crawford Study Group on Structural Adjustment in mid-1979. We said that we would complete the tariff review program then in progress, and after that send the reference. That reference has gone. I recall also that the Crawford study group said that action on that reference was contingent on certain other conditions prevailing, namely, the implementation of the general thrust of an industrial development policy, and a situation where unemployment in the country was not too high-in particular, not higher than, say 5 per cent, which was the figure quoted. At this moment, with unemployment edging higher than that, the Australian people can be sure, and industry can be sure, that the implementation of recommendations in that area will be undertaken carefully and gradually and with regard to the conditions of the Crawford report.

Since the honourable member for Adelaide mentioned the references to the Commission on Budgetary Assistance to Industry, I also refer to them. The bounties which are the subject of this legislation before the House, are a part of that assistance. The main budgetary measures referred to include industrial research and development grants, the investment allowance and the separate reference to export incentives. I stress that there is no intention on the part of the Government to reduce the net cost of assistance to industry. Rather, the Government is seeking to make sure that the assistance that it provides is as effective as possible in meeting the needs of industry. One benefit of this reference will be that it will bring the important issue of better depreciation provisions, which I believe are of key importance in enhancing the competitiveness of Australian industry, under close scrutiny.

I come back more specifically to the subject matter of these Bills-the bounties in respect of drilling bits and non-adjustable wrenches. I make the general point that within the context of our industry policy, which is to promote a more low cost, competitive, export oriented industry, bounties do play a significant role. They are an integral part of this policy. The Government is committed to the reasonable and adequate protection of industry but of course within the long term context of lowering the general level of protection. These Bills are important in that context.

It can always be said that for a number of reasons and in a number of situations the use of a bounty to assist Australian industry in its production and sales in competition with imports is to be preferred. One such case is where Australian production is a relatively small part of the total sales of a product within the country. If a tariff is imposed, then over the whole of sales the level of the price is raised, whereas if the Australian production forms only a small part of that total and if the Australian production is paid a subsidy, then the general level of price is not raised. That assists in other directions. It is particularly important where the product is an input to another manufacturing process-for instance, where a firm is producing yarn which is turned into fabric and subsequently into clothing. If the price of yarn can be kept down, the price of the fabric can be kept down and hence clothing will be cheaper. Yarn production is one area in which bounties are provided.

Another circumstance in which a bounty can be a preferred method of proceeding is where for a short period an industry with low cost potential-the sort of industry suitable to the Australian climate-needs assistance to enable it to break through, so to speak, in competition with imports, into larger scale production and thereafter operate as an efficient, low cost and hopefully exporting industry. A case of such assistance is the drilling bits bounty. The bounty was initiated towards the end of 1979 by an Act of this Parliament eventually passed in 1980. One noted at the time that this was an industry with good potential for development in Australia. It is a highly technological industry and one which could be expanded particularly in the area of drilling bits for exploration use. It needed initial assistance to compete with imports in order to get into larger scale production. That is what the bounty has achieved. It is now before us for renewal. With what has been achieved, it is possible to scale down the bounty to half the preceding rate. That is being done . The Industries Assistance Commission has found that the greater part of the local industry is, with moderate levels of assistance, relatively efficient and its further development is consistent with the objectives of our industry policy . Thus the Commission recommended the continuation of this assistance at half the current rate, the industry having become to a significant degree established , for a further period. After 31 December this year, normal forms of assistance will be given.

Perhaps a third area in which a bounty can be usefully applied is in the context of adjustment assistance. The one certain fact of the industrial scene is that there will be change and the constant need for industry to adjust to change. There is no avoiding it; it is going on all the time. The second industry involved in the measure before the House, non-adjustable wrenches, is such a case. The principal firm involved has undoubtedly improved its market performance since the bounty was originally instituted and is rationalising its operations to adjust to the changing market situations. During this process the payment of the bounty enables it to continue this activity and to establish itself strongly in the market. From 31 December there can be a reversion to normal forms of assistance. Therefore a bounty has been proposed in this case.

I repeat that this bounty Bill is an integral part of the Government's industry policy to foster a more low cost, technologically based, export oriented manufacturing industry. I come back to the point I made at the beginning of my speech. The most important thing that can be done to foster Australian manufacturing industry is to achieve a low cost situation, to contain increases in costs and to establish international competitiveness. We can boost economic activity in manufacturing in Australia only if local producers can gain orders in competition with imports or if they can gain orders overseas for exports in competition with the local manufacturers there and of other countries. That is the most important consideration.

The honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) criticised what this Government has done in its overall economic policy to contain inflation and increasing costs. I repeat that he has not put up any feasible alternative. We heard that the Labor Party, should it ever achieve office, would spend up more in various ways-including so-called job creation schemes at a cost probably of the order of $1 billion per annum. The effect of this spending would be to stimulate inflation and increase costs and this would tend to render Australian manufacturing industry uncompetitive. We are told that Labor would counter this by a so-called incomes policy, an incomes policy no doubt based, as I have heard other honourable members from the other side of the House suggest, on the ' special relationship' which a future Labor government would have with the unions . I suggest that that is just not credible; it is just not believable. I would ask: What special relationship? We have not seen any evidence of it. I think the only special relationship that I am aware of is one under which the unions say: 'We pay the Labor Party money, therefore you will do as we say'. In point of fact there is no credible or believable special relationship. If the Opposition wants evidence of that I suggest it go back to the time when the Labor Party was last in office and when the present honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) was not only the President of the Labor Party but also the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. At that time we had the greatest upsurge in costs and the greatest level of industrial disputation in Australian history. There is no evidence whatsoever of a successful incomes policy based on a so- called special relationship with the unions. As we all know the situation at that time led to a massive undermining of Australian manufacturing industry. That is something which this Government has been obliged to rectify. I repeat that the most important thing to do is to ensure that costs are contained and that we achieve an appropriate degree of international competitiveness. That is the basic element of this Government's general economics policy, as of its industry policy, supplemented by other measures including the bounty Bill now before us.

SPEECH.PARA: The current depressing economic climate with a record number since World War 2 out of work, clearly indicates that something is seriously wrong. The extraordinary number of business bankruptcies, which have gone up steadily for the last six years, to 2,530 in 1979-80, also provides additional evidence that the Government's policies are not working. What is needed is a soundly based industry and business policy which will stimulate balanced growth and enlarge employment opportunities, and which will provide Australia with a firm foundation for prosperous economic growth in decades ahead. Unfortunately, what we get from this Government is a fragmented industry policy which applies bounties, subsidies, tariffs, tax incentives and other financial inducements in an apparently random fashion to various sectional interests. The overall plan for Australia's industrial development has not been spelled out by the Government. Whilst the rationale for each particular form of financial incentive in each particular industry is usually fairly clear, as indeed it is in the case of the Bill before us today, the direction and purpose of the Goverment's industry policy, and its relationship to Australia's future needs, have not been made clear.

In many cases the Government's industry assistance policy appears to have been motivated by electoral considerations and the result has been the channelling of enormous amounts of taxpayers' money into subsidies for inefficient industries. Taxpayers in Australia have been well aware of the extent to which they have been subsidising primary industry over the years but the level of subsidisation of secondary industry is not always fully appreciated. I want to take an example that emerges from a study of these particular bounties contained in the Industries Assistance Commission's report No. 271 on cutlery, industrial knives and hand tools. This report concerns Sidchrome, a division of Siddons Pty Ltd, the producer of over 90 per cent of all locally made non-adjustable wrenches. Sidchrome has been receiving short term assistance as a result of a temporary assistance report in August 1980 which gave a bounty of 11c to certain locally produced non-adjustable spanners for a 12-month period commencing 1 July 1980. This was extended to 31 December 1981. At the same time, Sidchrome received tariff assistance at a rate of 25 per cent for spanners and wrenches from all general rate sources and Taiwan.

Thus Sidchrome, through the combination of the existing long term tariff and the short term bounty, has been provided with an equivalent tariff of about 50 per cent since 1 July 1980. Added to this assistance, Sidchrome was receiving by -law entry on the importation of blanks for spanners from the plant in Hong Kong to 1 July 1980. This had the effect of providing very high effective rates of assistance to certain of Sidchrome's locally produced products. In fact the 1979 IAC report on spanners and wrenches pointed out 'The effective rate of assistance available for the finishing processes on open end spanners exceeds 100 per cent'.

I take Sidchrome only as an example of the level of protection on certain of our manufacturing industries in Australia. For much of the time we are not aware of this high degree of protection for specific industries. What are the benefits to Australia from this massive financial support to Sidchrome? In employment terms the number employed in connection with non-adjustable spanners and wrenches has declined from 457 in June 1973 to 378 in June 1977 and to 279 in June 1980. In terms of Sidchrome's profitability and its production of non- adjustable spanners, measured as the ratio of operating profits to funds employed, it was higher in 1978-79 and 1979-80 than in 1977-78, but was still less than the average profitability of the manufacturing sector in the corresponding period.

The Bill before us establishes a firm timetable for the level of assistance to be given in the case of non-adjustable wrenches. The bounty mechanism also provides for an exact costing of the level of assistance given in the Budget. That is very worth while because at least we know what we are paying for that level of assistance. So in both those respects the Bill is to be commended for setting a firm limit to the amount of taxpayers' money which is being spent on the protection of this industry. It is sadly apparent that in the past assistance has been applied indiscriminately in this respect. Nobody would deny that the restructuring of the Australian manufacturing industry will be a difficult job. But it is about time that we stopped talking about how difficult it is and will be and got on with the job because in the meantime the taxpayers are paying for it.
