TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table the documents containing the terms of the agreement on Australia's participation in the Sinai Multinational Force and Observers. The agreement gives details of the overall size and shape of the Australian contingent and the terms on which it will participate in the peacekeeping force. The documents are in the form of two exchanges of letters constituting the agreement between the MFO Director-General and me, as Australian Foreign Minister. I also table the protocol signed by Egypt and Israel on 3 August 1981 which is the basis for the establishment of the Sinai Multinational Force and Observers and which is enclosed in the first letter from the Director-General. An aide memoire is also attached to the first letter from the Director-General. This document, which is not of treaty status, provides guidelines to governments preparing to assign troops for service with the MFO.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members will be aware that Australia and New Zealand have been requested by the MFO to provide the helicopter element of the MFO aviation support group, and personnel for air traffic control and air field services. The agreement with the MFO states that Australia will provide 99 military personnel and eight Iroquois helicopters. The helicopters themselves will be drawn from No . 9 squadron based at Amberley. In addition Australia will provide 10 staff officers for the Force Commander's headquarters. I had earlier indicated that there was a possibility that Australia might be asked to provide personnel for the MFO military police investigation unit. There is however no longer a requirement for Australia to provide them. Accordingly the total number of Australian military personnel in the Sinai MFO will be 109.

The number of personnel required for the Australian contribution is less than was earlier considered likely. Following discussions with the MFO considerable manpower economies were found to be practical. An important consideration is the number of functions, including provision of fixed wing aircraft and support services, that will be performed by other countries. The Australian contribution to the Sinai MFO will be for two years but this period may be extended by agreement. This is consistent with what has been agreed by the United Kingdom, France, Italy, the Netherlands and New Zealand. It will be for the Australian Government to determine whether to consent to a renewal of the commitment. The agreement, and related protocol, which are binding in international law on Egypt and Israel as well as the MFO, establish the basis for the Australian participation and protect the status of Australian personnel in the force.

In the negotiations with the MFO it was important to ensure that Australia's contribution be integrated carefully with the contributions of the other participating countries and for terms and conditions of operations to be broadly similar. The agreement we have negotiated with the MFO is, on key issues, in equivalent terms to those which the MFO has negotiated with European countries and New Zealand, and maintains Australian sovereignty over Australia's contribution. In addition, the directive issued by the Chief of Defence Force Staff to the Australian commander specifically requires him to consult with Australian authorities if he receives orders which he believes are contrary to, or go beyond, the agreed purposes of the force. I table the directive. There is provision in the agreement for the Australian contingent to withdraw after giving adequate prior notification. What Australia and other participating states would regard as adequate prior notification would depend on the circumstances prevailing at the time.

In his statement to Parliament on 22 October on Australian participation in the Sinai peacekeeping force, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) stated our requirement that no part of the MFO, including the United States component, should have any association with a United States rapid deployment force. The Government has received firm assurances on this matter from the United States Government. Given the importance of this issue, the Government sought and has received written assurances from the United States Secretary of State, Mr Alexander Haig. I table the letter from Mr Haig. Legislation adopted by the United States Congress which sets out the conditions for United States participation states clearly that members of the United States contingent in the Sinai MFO can perform only those functions specified for a United Nations force and observers in the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty, and in accordance with the protocol which established the Sinai MFO. I table the text of this legislation. I repeat, the agreement which was negotiated with the MFO maintains Australia's sovereign control over the Australian military personnel who will be serving in the Sinai.

The Government believes that by contributing to the Sinai MFO Australia can play a small but nevertheless important role in maintaining the momentum of the Middle East peace process. Not only is the Middle East crucial to international peace; it is also a region where Australia has substantial and growing bilateral interests. The Government believes that it is important to support the principle of returning Arab land to Arab sovereignty. It is the Government's hope that, following the return of the final third of the Sinai, the efforts of all countries in the region will be directed towards the wider question of an Arab- Israeli settlement.

Finally, I would like to reiterate the importance the Government attaches to resolving the Palestinian question. As the Prime Minister made clear in his statement of 22 October, a resolution of this issue is the key to peace and stability in the region. Failure to make progress provides opportunities for the Soviet Union and its allies to further their influence in the Middle East. The Government will be doing what it can to support the efforts of countries of the region and others such as the United States to establish a lasting and just peace in the Middle East. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) has made a statement on Australia's participation in the Sinai peacekeeping force and he has tabled some relevant correspondence and documents, but it is worthy of note that the advance party of the Australian contingent has already left Australia. At the initial stage, I should like to talk about the legal situation, which is worthy of comment. In May of last year, the Minister stated that the mandate for the force would be Article VI of Annexe 1 of the Egypt-Israel peace treaty of 1979. That is absolutely incorrect now. Article VI of Annexe 1 prohibits the United States from being a member of any force. There are nine paragraphs in Article VI. In each of those nine paragraphs there are nine references to a United Nations force. The peace treaty is based on United Nations Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338. Resolution 242 emphasises that the acquisition of territory is inadmissible and affirms the guarantees that territory is inviolable and that every state in the area will have political independence. Resolution 338 calls upon the parties to implement Resolution 242 in all respects.

SPEECH.PARA: The framework for peace emphasises security being enhanced in the spirit of the United Nations charter and the presence of international forces. It provides for Egypt, Israel, Jordan and the representatives of the Palestinian people to participate in negotiations on the resolution of the Palestinian problem and that negotiations relating to the West Bank and Gaza should proceed in a certain way. It was further agreed that principles and provisions should apply to peace treaties between Jordan, Syria and Lebanon and that those treaties should be underwritten by the United Nations.

The remarks of the participants, made in September 1978 in the presence of each other, surely can be relied upon even now. The framework provides specific points which will govern a comprehensive peace settlement, with the future of the West Bank and Gaza and the resolution of the Palestinian problems in all its aspects. At that time, President Carter emphasised that the Palestinians would have the right to participate in the determination of their own future and in negotiations which will produce the final states of the West Bank and Gaza. These agreements provide the basis, he said, for progress and peace. The next day, President Carter explained that the documents would be signed by President Sadat and Mr Begin and witnessed by him. He further stated that the documents provided a comprehensive framework by which peace treaties could be negotiated with Lebanon, Syria and Jordan. He then said that the Camp David agreement defined relationships for Israel and her neighbours and the realisation of recognised boundaries, the granting of self-government and the guarantee that the Palestinian people may participate in the resolution of the problem, with these words in quotation marks:
After the signing of this agreement, no new Israeli settlements will be established in this area.

I should like also to refer to the letter written by former President Carter to the late President Sadat and to Prime Minister Begin on 26 March 1979. It has been claimed that this letter is a separate peace treaty. It is an international proposition, apparently, that one can have a peace treaty, as we call the Camp David agreement, but one can apparently ignore it by writing a letter on the same day. I think that it is incredible to have that sort of reliance because, whilst it was written on the same day as the treaty, it in no way forms part of the treaty.

Secondly, and perhaps more importantly in terms of international law, one cannot have an ancillary document to an international treaty which contradicts the basis of the treaty and then claims to be part of the treaty. The treaty provides for the peacekeeping force to be drawn from countries other than the super-powers. The letter states:
The parties have agreed that if no agreement is reached between the parties, they will accept or support a United States proposal concerning the composition of the United Nations force and observers.

So the treaty is contradicted by that letter on two points. The letter envisages not only a non-United Nations force but also, in fact, a force led by one of the super powers. Everywhere else-that is, in the 1978 Camp David Accords, in the 1979 peace treaty and in the key Security Council Resolutions 242 and 338, which are the most authoritative United Nations pronouncement concerning peace in the Arab-Israeli conflict-the reference is to a United Nations force.

Thirdly, and contrary to claims made by the Minister in the past, President Carter's letter is not an essential document which can be seen in conjunction with the 1979 Egypt-Israel peace treaty. There is no evidence to the contrary, as the treaty refers to papers attached to it as 'annexes', 'protocols' and ' maps', and nowhere does it mention the letter sent by Carter to Sadat and Begin. Therefore, there is no legal basis for the Australian Government supporting a non-United Nations force in the Sinai. It makes a mockery of our sovereignty and supposed serious respect for international law when we use a letter written by the former President to the two principal protagonists in a war as the basis for commiting our troops in an area of conflict. How can it possibly be argued that a letter written by one to the other can involve the obligations of a third party? It surely cannot be argued. How can the Minister refer to the treaty, as he did earlier, as providing a mandate for the multinational force when in the nine paragraphs of Article VI there are nine references to a United Nations force and not a single mention of a multinational force? The Minister now tells us that the documents relevant to the multinational force are two exchanges of letters between the multinational force director-general and himself, as Foreign Minister, and that the basis for the establishment of the Sinai multinational force is the protocol signed by Egypt and Israel on 3 August.

It is important that the Minister makes up his mind. Looking at the protocol, one sees that it certainly does not refer to the letter by Carter to Sadat. The protocol refers to the fact that a letter was written-in May 1981, I might add, which was some time after the Camp David Accords-to the President of the Security Council, and, of course, there was an indication that they were unable to reach the necessary agreement, and it then goes on to talk about the various articles of the peace treaty, Articles 4 and 6. So the protocol itself is back to the Camp David Accords.

There is no mandate in our view. Australian forces have been sent to the Middle East because the Americans have asked that we send them. What could the Americans care about the Middle East if it were not for the oil? And what would we care about the Middle East were it not for the Americans? If we cared about the problems of refugees, about repressive government and about peacekeeping initiatives, we would first look closer to home. What about Kampuchea and Pol Pot and the problems particularly immediately to our north between Vietnam and China? Let us look at the chances we might have to take some initiatives in that area and to defuse the tension which certainly exists between Thailand, China, Vietnam and Kampuchea, which have millions of refugees who are likely to come to Australia. In the same process, if we want to talk about the world and how we should solve its problems, let us talk about the refugees, including the three and a half million coming from Afghanistan.

Let us also make it very clear that there is an inalienable right for Israel to exist. It is the only democracy in the sea of Arab theocracies or worse. It has done much to make a fertile area out of a harsh environment. It deserves and is entitled to live in peace. However, the Palestinian question must be settled if there is to be any lasting peace. It is just not enough to say that a Palestinian state already exists and that it is called Jordan.

The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) told Australians that our troops would participate if the Canadians and the British took part. Canada is not having a bar of the peacekeeping force and Britain is sending a platoon to help with administration. A Labor government would foster much closer relationships between Australia and Canada because it appears that we have much to learn from Canada, especially in dealing with the United States.

Let us look at what Australian public opinion is. The Canberra Times said that there was no good reason why Australian forces should go all the way to the Middle East just to prove that we are an ally of the United States. The Sydney Morning Herald stated:
We shouldn't touch the Sinai Force with a forty foot pole. It is simply too much of a risk.

The legal aspects of the force have not bothered the Government. It was not until someone pointed out to the Government that since the Australian soldiers would not form part of a United Nations force they could not be covered by the provisions of the Repatriation Act, that action was taken. So the Act was speedily amended in March to ensure that all Australians serving with any peacekeeping force will be eligible to receive repatriation benefits.

Our force is in jeopardy, and not merely in providing logistic support to a group whose role is to man checkpoints, undertake reconnaissance patrols and set up observation posts. I quote from the United States Senate Joint Resolution of December 1981, which states:
. . . only those functions or responsibilities which are specified for United Nations Forces and observers in the Israeli-Egypt Treaty of Peace.

If that is so and if that is the force's sole task, we must wonder why 600 men of the crack 82nd Airborne Division are to be the United States contribution to the Sinai force, to play the role of policemen. It is a role that could be played by somebody eligible for Dad's Army, but certainly not by the 600 crack troops of the 82nd Airborne Division. The fact that the men of that Division are an integral part of the United States Rapid Deployment Force has been overlooked by the Government. The Minister claimed that assurances had been given by the United States that no part of the proposed Sinai peacekeeping force, including the United States component, would have any association with the Rapid Deployment Force. It cannot be said that a soldier is in the Rapid Deployment Force in one minute and then back in the Sinai peacekeeping force in another, and not say that he is really part of the Rapid Deployment Force because he is trained to the limit to do that job.

In General Haig's letter to the Minister, we were given the assurance that no part of the proposed Sinai peacekeeping force, including the United States component, would have any association with the Rapid Deployment Force. But I make the point that it is part of it-virtually on leave, if one likes to have it that way, but going back into the Force. Our troops, irrespective of whatever legal safeguards the force may have in the imagination of the Americans, will be in a zone where there has been fighting for as long as anyone can remember. There has been continual war in the Middle East. There is no peace there. One- third of all weapons sold in the world last year ended up in the Middle East. Last year alone, the Palestine Liberation Organisation received an estimated $ 100m in arms. There are indications that Lebanon will become the battleground for a fight for the extermination of the PLO and for the destruction of the Syrian forces. The problems between Christians and Muslims in Lebanon have been exacerbated by the Syrians and the PLO. To this explosive mix, the Israelis could well be added because it seems that certain para-military groups want Israel to destroy the Syrians and the PLO.

One hundred and nine Australians will go to the Sinai. We wish them well and a speedy return. When Labor forms the next government, we will immediately review the role of the Australian contingent and exercise the option in the agreement- that is the two exchanges of letters between the Minister and the Director- General-which allows for withdrawal of the contingent after giving adequate prior notification. I hope that when we come to office the situation in the Sinai will be stable enough for us to withdraw the contingent, but we will judge the situation when we come to it. We would seriously consider whether the withdrawal of the contingent would jeopardise the safety of the rest of the Sinai force and, with this in mind, we would act responsibly. Finally, what will it cost, because we have had no estimates from the Minister?

TALK.START.PARA: —About a million.

—About $1m. I thank the Minister for that. Will it, following the return of the final third of the Sinai, direct efforts of all countries in the region towards the wider question of the Arab-Israeli settlement-that is to use the Minister's own words? I sincerely hope it does.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Mr R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give my support to the Sinai peacekeeping force and to this statement, fully aware of the complexities and difficulties of the broader Arab-Israeli problem and recognising that any decision to send Australian troops overseas involves agonising and difficult decision-making. It has been a difficult question for the government but it does not seem to have been a difficult question for the Opposition. The Opposition has seen this as a United States force, which it is not, and it is therefore, by definition, simply wrong. For the Australian Labor Party, that is the beginning and the end of the issue.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the irony of the Opposition's position is that it originally embraced the Camp David Accords and therefore was not opposed to the concept of a peacekeeping force as such. It would have supported an Australian commitment if the force was under United Nations sponsorship. But the Soviet Union said that the United Nations could not do this, and that was good enough for the ALP, no matter what the peacemakers themselves wanted. The Opposition regards this question of sponsorship as the crucial determinant as to whether we should participate in the force. But this is not an exercise in moot law. It is not an academic courtroom debate. It is about an important pragmatic temporary issue of great international and strategic importance to Australia and the world. It is part of an initiative for peace. certainly the original agreement, which this Parliament supported, referred to a United Nations force. This has changed only because the Soviet Union refused United Nations sponsorship.

Let us look at what has not changed. The basic functions of the force, as outlined originally in the protocol of Annex 1, Article VI of the Egypt-Israel peace treaty, have not changed. The basic provisions and implications of the treaty have not changed. The nature of it and its basic thrust have not changed. The attitudes of the signatories to the treaty have not changed. The wider Arab world response to it has not changed. The original signatories, with the same honourable intentions, agreed to the change in the force sponsorship, but without altering in any way the fundamental nature of their quest for peace.

Certainly all signatories to the Treaty would have preferred United Nations sponsorship, and that goes for the Australian Government as well. But we should not forget that each party has agreed to replace a non-United Nations force with a United Nations force should the United Nations change its position on this issue. We should remember anyway that United Nations forces are merely volunteered contributions by states, acting with the consent of the states on whose territory the force operates. That is what is happening with this force. Is not the co-operation of individual states in peacekeeping permitted under the Charter of the United Nations? The fact remains that limited force zones, as a major security aspect of the Sinai withdrawal, do require monitoring.

The status of this force, in relation to the peace treaty of march 1979, is misunderstood. The Carter letter of 26 March 1979 to establish a non-United Nations force was written in the context of the conclusions of the peace treaty and was also registered by Israel at the United Nations Secretariat in accordance with article 102 of the United Nations Charter as a document related to the treaty of peace. Moreover, the content of the letter was re-affirmed in 1981 by the parties in an exchange of letters between Egypt, Israel and the United States, which constituted an international agreement. It has been stated that, according to Article VI, paragraph 8 of the Annex to the peace treaty, the United Nations force was not supposed to include contingents from nations which are permanent members of the United Nations Security Council. However, the 1981 Protocol tabled today provides in the second paragraph:

The provisions of the Treaty which relate to the establishment and functions and responsibilities of the United Nations forces and observers shall apply mutatis mutandis to the establishment and functions and responsibilities of the MFO or as provided in this protocol.

The Carter letter does not contradict basic provisions of the peace treaty. It supplements it by trying to solve a problem which could arise if some of the provisions of the peace treaty were not implemented due to the attitude of the Security Council. Given all this, surely we can recognise that, although this force and its sponsorship is important, we should not forget that it is only an implementing part of the major objective of the Treaty. It is an objective of peace for which the peacemakers should be applauded and assisted by nations such as Australia. Will peace ever be achieved if nations so desirous of peace always leave peace obligations and initiatives to others?

During the many months of debate on this issue the Opposition has raised a number of alarmist and misleading side issues. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) has expressed concern that the Rapid Deployment Force of the United States of America would in some way affect the role of the United States component of this force. In fact a joint resolution of the United States Senate and House of Representatives has specified quite clearly that this will not be the case, as does the letter from the United States Secretary of State, tabled today by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street), which clearly states that there will be no connection and no overlap of responsibilities whatsoever between the Multinational Force and Observers and the RDF. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition and others have also tried to establish that by our participation we are in fact playing an active role in the promotion of war. What a ludicrous proposition. We are contributing a small number of men, 109, to a peacekeeping force to monitor a peace treaty on peaceful territory at the request of two countries at peace. To ask why a force is necessary in those circumstances, as many have done, is to fall for the trap of using our perceptions and values to solve someone else's problems. It ignores the fact that the Sinai is an area of great strategic importance to both Egypt and Israel and has long been a battle ground for conflicts between them.

Israel is a small, insecure nation, surrounded by nations committed to its destruction and for which the sacrifice of captured territory is therefore a very traumatic experience. Given this history, both parties to the Treaty, particularly Israel, require the confidence and credibility of an international monitoring body. Both parties to the Treaty wanted this force. It is a function of peace, not war, that this force is required to perform. It can only perform those functions or responsibilities which are specified for the United Nations Forces and Observers in the Treaty of Peace and in accordance with the Protocol which established the MFO. Any examination of Article VI of Annex 1 of the Treaty should allay any doubts as to this peacekeeping function of the force. Surely the safeguards outlined in the Minister's statement can be accepted by this Parliament.

Opposition leaders have been quick to join in the Western international chorus of condemnation of Israel, particularly her attitude to the autonomy talks, and have used this to question our participation in any peacekeeping force, as if Begin and Israel constitute a major barrier to peace and an incitement to war in the Middle East. It is Israel which has constantly sought peace in this region. It is the PLO, Iraq, Syria, Libya and other nations in the region which have prevented peace. It is they who have not recognised Israel's right to exist. It is they who must now make initiatives for peace. The Minister said as much in the second last paragraph of his statement. Those who say we should not support Israel in this peacekeeping force because Begin is obstinate regarding the autonomy process required by Camp David should remember that it was Begin who said he would not give up any of the Sinai. But what did he do when an Arab nation was prepared to talk peace with Israel? Israel returned all occupied Egyptian land, including Sharm-el-Sheikh and its naval base, the three strategically important airfields in eastern Sinai and the oilfields developed by Israel, all in return for what-for a piece of paper, for the acceptance through normal diplomatic channels of Israel's right to exist.

Surely the lesson there is that other Arab nations should make peace initiatives, even if only recognising Israel's right to exist. The West and the Opposition would do well to emphasise this rather than constantly seeking to isolate and condemn Israel. But in the absence of even this minor concession, is it reasonable for Israel to sacrifice her security further? I think not. After all, no Arab nation has ever sacrificed territory in seeking peace. No Arab nation has come forward saying that it will have the Palestinians; no Arab nation agreed to support an independent Palestinian state when it had the opportunity to do so between 1948 and 1967. Certainly the matter has to be resolved, as the Minister said in his statement. But before criticising Israel regarding the West Bank, Gaza, and Golan Heights, the Iraqi nuclear reactor, should we not expect a more conciliatory Arab attitude towards Israel. I say this simply to indicate that we should support the present peace Treaty but not expect all future peace initiatives to involve concessions only from Israel. It is not correct to assume that the peacekeeping force will incur the wrath of the wider Arab world as a result of the autonomy issue. Saudi Arabia, Jordan and other moderate Arab states have consistently taken the position that Egypt has the right to negotiate for the return of its sovereign territory.

I am not saying that no risks are involved for this force. Of course there is some risk, given the turbulent nature of this region and the presence of terrorists. But it is a risk which should be kept in perspective and not exaggerated and accorded the status of another Vietnam, as some members of the Opposition have falsely done. It is a risk which should also be weighed against the gain; that is, peace between two countries which have spent much of their recent histories fighting each other in an area of the world which is vital to the West, including Australia. Also, when assessing the risks of Australia's involvement in this force, when expressing concern regarding a wider Arab response, it is dangerous to overstate the concept of Arab unity and togetherness, which is often done. This is a myth which has been perpetrated to maintain a rallying point for domestic, unstable Arab regimes; it is a myth that it is only the existence of Israel which prevents the solution of the Palestinian problem and therefore the achievement of Arab unity and integration, and peace and stability in the Middle East. Anyone who knows anything about the complexities of inter-Arab state politics recognises this as a myth. Peace will come only slowly and perhaps only on a bilateral step by step basis, as recognised by Camp David. But to see this force as a stumbling block to future peace in the region ignores the realities of the Middle East.

My other concern in supporting this force centres around the fact that any reading of the Camp David Agreements and any study of the relationships which existed between Carter, Begin and Sadat, makes it quite clear that this is a treaty between three leaders who, with good will and understanding, achieved a peace that they genuinely desired. Those desires may still be present, but the three men are not. This was the kind of relationship which history does not often deliver to us: enemies who became friends through acts of statesmanship in the face of enormous personal and domestic political dangers. My initial support for this force was to ensure that Australia would help this historic, bilateral quest for peace in an area of the world in which disputes had in the past been settled by war and in which in the future, from this example, they may be settled by peace initiatives, even if only gradually and on a one to one basis. My concern now is that the three signatories to that Treaty are no longer on the scene. It is to Mubarak's credit that he has maintained Sadat's position regarding the Treaty. But I am concerned that domestic and regional pressures may crowd him, once the Sinai has gone from Israel. It is essential, therefore, that a credible force be in place to ensure that the provisions of the Treaty are respected and to give both Begin and Mubarak the confidence and respect in the Treaty which others in the region may try to dissipate.

Finally, one should consider what would happen if the West did not support this force and this Treaty. We would simply be pandering to the rejectionist states such as Iraq, Syria and Libya and to organisations such as the PLO and others who are committed to Israel's destruction and a revival of continuous tension and war in a region where two major allies of the West are setting an example of peace through negotiations based on good will, understanding and a recognition of the other party's rights. I am very pleased to be able to support the statement by the Minister. As is the case with the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the men comprising this force go to the Sinai with my best wishes. I certainly hope that our contribution will play a small part in ensuring the success of this very historic peace treaty.

I have the agreement of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition to incorporating these proposals, as published in the Australia-Israel Review of March 1982, in Hansard. I seek leave for that incorporation.
Leave granted.
The proposals read as follows-
ISRAEL'S AUTONOMY PROPOSALS

The following are the Israel Government's proposals for Palestinian autonomy which currently form Jerusalem's basis for negotiations under the Camp David Accords. The text was released by the Israel Foreign Ministry.

In the Camp David Agreement signed on 17 September 1978 between Egypt and Israel, with the United States signing as a witness, agreement was reached on a plan for the solution of the problem of the Palestinian Arabs that includes a proposal for full autonomy for the Palestinian Arabs living in Judea, Samaria and Gaza. The manner of establishing this autonomy, as well as its powers, were to be determined in negotiations between the signatories (Jordan was invited to participate, but did not respond). It was Israel that first raised the idea of autonomy that was later to serve as the basis of the Camp David agreement. For the first time in the history of the Palestinian Arab inhabitants of Judea- Sumaria and the Gaza district, they were offered an opportunity of this kind to conduct their own affairs by themselves. Since 1979, talks have been held for the implementation of this agreement; there were intermissions in the negotiations, but talks were resumed intensively in the summer of 1981, leading to a thorough-going clarification of the positions of the parties. At these talks Israel put forward its proposals with regard to the self-governing authority (administrative council), its powers, responsibilities and structure as well as other related issues. The main points of Israel's proposals, as submitted in the course of the negotiations were as follows:
Scope, jurisdiction and structure of the self-governing authority ( administrative council):

1. The Camp David Accords set forth the establishment of a self-governing authority (administrative council) that will comprise one body representing the Arab inhabitants of Judea, Samaria and the Gaza district, who will choose this body in free elections, and it will assume those functional powers that will be transferred to it. Thus the Palestinian Arabs will for the first time have an elected and representative body, in accordance with their own wishes and free choice, that will be able to carry out the functions assigned to it as an administrative council.

2. The members of the administrative council will be able, as a group, to discuss all subjects within the council's competence, apportioning among themselves the spheres of responsibility for the various functions. Within the domain of its assigned powers and responsibilities, the council will be responsible for planning and carrying out its activities.
Powers of the self-governing authority (administrative council):

1. a. Under the terms of the Camp David agreement, the parties have to reach an agreement on the powers and responsibilities of the authority. Israel's detailed proposals include a list of powers that will be given to the authority and that, by any reasonable and objective criterion, represent a wide and comprehensive range of fields of operation. Without any doubt, the transferring of these powers constitutes the bestowal of full autonomy-in the full meaning of that term.
b. The powers to be granted the authority, under these proposals, are in the following domains:

1. Administration of Justice: Supervision of the administrative system of the courts in the areas; dealing with matters connected with the prosecution system and with the registration of companies, partnerships, patents, trademarks, etc.
2. Agriculture: All branches of agriculture and fisheries, nature reserves and parks.
3. Finance: Budget of the adminstrative council and allocations among its various divisions; taxation.

4. Civil Service: Appointment and working conditions of the Council's employees . (Today, the civil service of the inhabitants of Judea-Samaria and Gaza, within the framework of the Military Government's Civilian Administration, numbers about 12,000 persons).
5. Education and Culture: Operation of the network of schools in the areas, from kindergarten to higher education; supervision of cultural artistic and sporting activities.
6. Health: Supervision of hospitals and clinics; operation of sanitary and other services related to public health.
7. Housing and Public Works: Construction, housing for the inhabitants and public works projects.
8. Transportation and Communication: Maintenance and co-ordination of transport , road traffic, meteorology; local postal and communications services.
9. Labour and Social Welfare: Welfare, labour and employment services, including the operation of labour exchanges.
10. Municipal Affairs: Matters concerning municipalities and their effective operation.
11. Local Police: Operation of a strong local police force, as provided for in the Camp David agreement, and maintenance of prisons for criminal offenders sentenced by the courts in the areas.
12. Religious Affairs: Provision and maintenance of religious facilities for all religious communities among the Arab inhabitants of Judea-Samaria and the Gaza district.
13. Industry, Commerce and Tourism: Development of industry, commerce, workshops and tourist services.

2. The council will have full powers in its spheres of competence to determine its budget, to enter into contractual obligations, to sue and be sued and to engage manpower. It will, moreover, have wide powers to promulgate regulations, as required by a body of this kind. In the nature of things, in view of the free movement that will prevail between Judea-Samaria and the Gaza district and Israel and for the general welfare of the inhabitants, arrangements will be agreed upon in the negotiations, in a number of domains, for co-operation and co -ordination with Israel. The administrative council will, hence, have full scope to exercise its wide-ranging powers under the terms of the autonomy agreement. These powers embrace all walks of life, and will enable the inhabitants in the areas concerned to enjoy full autonomy.

3. Size: The size of the administrative council must reflect its functions and its essential purpose; it is an administrative council, whose representative character finds expression in its establishment through free elections, by the Arab inhabitants of Judea, Samaria and Gaza. Clearly, the criterion for determining the number of its members must be the functions that the council is empowered to perform. We propose, therefore, that the number of members will conform with the functions listed above.

4. Free Elections: Elections to the administrative council, under Israel's proposals, will be absolutely free, as stipulated in the Camp David agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the parties will agree upon the modalities of the elections, as a matter of fact, in past negotiations a long list of principles and guidelines has already been prepared in this matter. In these free elections, all the rights pertaining to a peaceful assembly, freedom of expression and secret balloting will be preserved and assured, and all necessary steps will be taken to prevent any interference with the election process. The holding of an absolutely free and unhampered election process will thus be assured in full, under the law, and in keeping with the tradition of free elections practised in democratic societies. These elections will, in many respects, constitute a new departure in the region around us which in most of its parts is not too close to the ways of democracy, and in which free elections are a rare phenomenon. It is of some interest, therefore, to note that Judea- Samaria and Gaza, under Israel's Military Government since 1967, have exemplified the practical possibility of totally free elections in these areas. In 1972, and again in 1976, Israel organised free elections in these areas based on the tradition and model of its own democratic and liberal tradition and cutsom; voters and elected officials alike concede that these were free elections in the fullest sense. The elections in the administrative council will be organised and supervised by the central elections committee whose composition has been agreed upon by the parties.

5. Time of elections and establishment of the self-governing authority ( administrative council): The elections will be held as expeditiously as possible after agreement will have been reached on the autonomy. This was set forth in the joint letter of the late President Sadat and of Prime Minister Begin to President Carter, dated 26 March 1979, setting forth the manner in which the self-governing authority (administrative council) is to be established, under the terms of the Camp David agreement.

6. Within one month following the elections, the self-governing authority ( administrative council) is to be established and inaugurated, and at that time the transitional period of five years will begin-again, in conformity with the Camp David agreement and the joint letter.
7. Hence, every effort will be made to hold elections without delay, once an agreement is reached, to be followed by the establishment of the self-governing authority (administrative council).

8. Following the elections and the establishment of the self-governing authority (administrative council) the military government and its civilian administration will be withdrawn, as withdrawal of Israeli armed forces will take place, and there will be a redeployment of the remaining Israeli forces into specified security locations, in full conformity with the Camp David agreement. Israel will present to the other parties in the negotiations the map of the specified security locations of the redeployment. It goes without saying that all this will be done for the purpose of safeguarding the security of Israel as well as of the Arab inhabitants of Judea-Samaria and Gaza and of the Israeli citizens residing in these areas.
9. All of the above indicates Israel's readiness to observe the Camp David agreement fully and in every detail, in letter and spirit, while safeguarding the interests of all concerned.
