SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, a number of countries will participate-Norway, Fiji, Colombia, Australia, New Zealand, France, Great Britain, the Netherlands, Italy and, of course, the United States. I understand that Uruguay is available to participate if required. It is a tragedy that it is not a United Nations peacekeeping force. Such a force would have had the total support of the Australian people and would have been able to participate in the peace process that began with the signing of the Camp David Accords and the Egyptian-Israeli peace treaty. I do not want to go over all the matters raised in the debate which took place when the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) announced that Australia would contribute to that force, but I wish to deal with a few matters that have arisen since. Some rather irrational people in our community, and others who seem to have a vested interest in the Camp David process failing, have dragged a few red herrings across the trail. One is that Australian troops would be used to evict Israeli settlers from Yamit when the multinational force went in. Anybody who has been watching television in recent weeks would have seen the heartbreaking scenes that have occurred when Israeli troops have themselves had to evict Israeli citizens from Yamit. One political party, the Tami party, under Mr Abuhatzeira, unfortunately has threatened to withdraw from the coalition over this issue. It is in favour of the Yamit settlers staying there. The Israeli Government has offered $230m-which I think frankly is outrageous-of which each family will get about $250,000 to withdraw from Yamit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who'd be a settler?

—That is right. Who would be a settler? Lots of people would have liked to be settlers in Yamit. It has outraged a lot of Israeli citizens that people should be paid to go out of that area. The simple fact of the matter is that no Israeli government could survive 10 minutes if it permitted Australian troops or any foreign troops to participate in evicting Israelis from Israeli territory. The proposition is nothing short of outrageous. It is hard enough for them to evict their own people; it would be impossible to allow it to be done by foreign troops.

SPEECH.PARA: Vanessa Redgrave's name has been mentioned in this debate. One could hardly ignore some of her statements. As has been said, she is a great actress. Unfortunately, she is a very distasteful individual in all other aspects. She is , to put it bluntly, a nut, an anti-Semite and a member of the Workers Revolutionary Party which aligned with a group in this country, the Socialist Labor League, could have held its annual general meeting in a telephone booth. They belong to the extreme Trotskyist organisations that advocate the violent overthrow of society. It is unfortunate that she has been given some credibility in our community. She has even been disowned by Tony Benn, who has described her as unstable and, as I said before, a nut.

Before she left Canberra she claimed that Australian troops would be blown to bits by the Israelis. To suggest such a load of nonsense is an obscenity. I would hardly imagine that Israel, along with Egypt, would invite the Australians in to keep the peace and then proceed to blow them to bits. What sort of perverted logic would lead one to the weird conclusion that Israel would do that ? It is too absurd for words. All Israel has to do to get rid of the Australian troops is not invite them in the first place. If Israel did not want the peace process to proceed, it need not have withdrawn from the Sinai and it need not withdraw from the last portion of the Sinai on 26 April.

It has been suggested that the Australian troops will be at some risk. From 1976 to 1979, 48 Royal Australian Air Force personnel were in that area and to the best of my knowledge there were no problems. At that time they were patrolling an area and separating combatants. I understand that 109 people going in will be doing much the same work-patrolling borders with helicopters, doing some administrative and communications work, and work of that nature. Nobody can give any unequivocal assurances that nobody will be injured. It is impossible to give that sort of assurance. There must always be some risk. Knowing the factors that operate there, I can only suggest that the risks must be miniscule. Our personnel will not be separating combatants or warring parties as they were from 1976 to 1979; they will be separating people who are trying to bring about a genuine peace between two countries. As someone suggested recently, the greatest danger to them will be getting a bad dose of sunburn down at Sharm el Sheikh. Having just come back from that region, I can agree with that.

TALK.START.PARA: —The odd PLO chap will give them a bit of trouble.

—The honourable member for Swan suggests that the odd bloke from the Palestine Liberation Organisation will give them some trouble. The odd PLO bloke in Sharm el Sheikh will have to be fairly well hidden in the sandhills because it is not the easiest place to hide; they cannot slip across from somewhere else to Sharm el Sheikh.
—There are a few other places, as well.
—As I said before, there is no absolute guarantee but I think the risks are miniscule.

SPEECH.PARA: The two countries, Egypt and Israel, have vested interests in working towards peace, for military, political and economic reasons. It has been suggested that, if Israel and Egypt want to bring about peace, why do they need other parties there. That view fails to understand the geography of the district. In the past, when attacks have been made, they have been surprise attacks. In 1973, when Egypt crossed the Suez Canal and attacked the 600-odd Israeli troops who were on the Bar-Lev line, they were able to break through fairly quickly. However, fortunately, because of the structure of the Sinai, because of the Mitla and Giddi passes, they were not able to get straight through to Israel quickly. That gave Israel the time to regroup its forces and to throw back the Egyptians from that area. However, had they been on the Sinai borders of Israel after the 1948 war, that same sort of strike could have gone straight into the heart of Israel. There would have been no chance of Israel defending itself properly. The other point is that it gave the air force about 40 minutes warning period. Egyptian planes travelling across the Sinai would take at least 40 minutes to reach the present boundaries of Israel whereas if they attacked from the Sinai they would be over Tel Aviv or Jerusalem in a matter of minutes. The point I make is that a period of trust has to develop between Egypt and Israel.

In regard to a change in leadership, we have seen what happened with the assassination of Sadat. There is no democratic process in Egypt as there is in Israel, so Israel needs some sort of guarantee to cover such a situation when there might be a change of leader and a change of heart. That is why this multinational force-preferably a United Nations force-ought to be there; in this period of getting together and working out relations, there is that guarantee that there cannot be a sudden change of heart.

It has been suggested by some, including some Israelis, that after 26 April Egyptians may return to the Arab fold, become militarily aggressive and prepare to attack Israel again. I do not believe that that will happen; I do not believe that that is the object of Egypt. I believe the Egyptians genuinely want peace. I went to Cairo and met and talked with many Egyptians, including the Foreign Minister, Dr Boutros Galli-an outstanding man-who expressed the views of Egyptians. He said that for a whole range of reasons-political, social and cultural-they want a genuine peace with the Israelis. I am totally convinced of the Egyptians' sincerity. They have lost thousands and thousands of young men and have lost enormous economic benefits for all their people during this constant 30-year war. I am absolutely convinced that Egypt wants a genuine peace . I am also sure Egypt knows that if Israel is attacked again after this present withdrawal but then recaptures the Sinai there is no way Israel will ever withdraw for a third time; it just will not happen. In other words, I believe this is the last chance to establish a genuine peace in that area.
I make it clear that I do not agree with everything that the Israeli Government does. I have been very critical of some actions it has taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —Neither do a lot of Israelis.

—Absolutely; a lot of Israelis do not agree. In fact, with a great deal of zest they disagree with many actions. That is the very essence of Israel because Begin, Peres, Shamir and Sharon can argue with enormous zest because Israel is a democracy; they can get up as we can in this House and say the sorts of things that we can. That cannot happen in any of the other Arab countries.
—It has two and a half million potential prime ministers.

—That is right. There is the old story about Eshkol talking to Lyndon Baines Johnson. Johnson said: 'I have a problem. I am the president of 230 million people'. Eshkol said: 'I am the Prime Minister of 3 million presidents'. We must not encourage those hardliners in Israel who do not want to make peace, who would like to have a greater Israel, who would like not to withdraw from the Sinai, who would like not to talk eventually to the Arabs about the settlement of the problems of the West Bank and Gaza. If the Sinai process does not proceed I believe that the chances of convincing those Israelis who are sceptical now would be an absolute impossibility in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me conclude by saying that the next step in the peace process, of course, is to resolve the question of what is going to happen on the West Bank and Gaza. If, as I said before, the Sinai peace process proceeds, I believe there will be encouragement for the Israelis to take a different approach to how they are going to resolve the problem of the West Bank. I am not going to sit in the safety of my home in Gosford and say what decisions people should make in that area. It is for the Israelis, the Jordanians and the Syrians to decide that in discussions between themselves.

There is a lot of talk about Israel's intransigence. What about Arab intransigence? Only one Arab country has recognised Israel. None of the others has made that move. We have heard a lot of talk about how the Palestine Liberation Organisation contains a moderate force and how Arafat will meet with Western leaders and say: 'Yes, of course we recognise that Israel must exist'. But the next day, having convinced the Western leaders that he is a very genuine , sincere and moderate sort of person, in arabic he says exactly the opposite. The only two Arab PLO spokesmen who ever spoke out publicly were assassinated. This is a problem for the PLO. I recognise that problem but it is one which it must resolve itself. It is not a problem for other countries to resolve.

The intransigence of the Arab countries over 30 years is the cause of all their problems. If they had accepted the 1947 partition Israel would now be a country the size of the Gold Coast. But it has been their refusal to accept Israel's right to exist that has led to the present situation. It is up to the Arab countries and the PLO to say: 'We recognise your right to exist; let us get down now to the business of solving the problem of the Palestinian refugees on the West Bank and Gaza'. I believe that ultimately these problems will be solved and a genuine peace will be brought about. Until that time, unfortuately we are left with all we have which is the process before us at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Katter The Hon R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the 12 or 13 minutes I have to speak I would first of all like to say that the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) is regarded by all members of this House as being an authority on this subject and as being totally dedicated and sincere. What is more, he is right in what he says. I suppose my nomination as a National Country Party candidate for the next election will be withdrawn because of what I have just said. However, the honourable member gives a balanced treatment to this problem because of the fact that he knows what he is talking about. It is as simple as that. I would also like to point out that speakers in this debate are primarily members of the sub- committee on defence of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. This shows that they have additional knowledge, they are involved and they are interested in what is an extremely important matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I have set out my address under four headings-the United States of America, Sadat, Lebanon and Palestine. In relation to the United States, who can detract from the efforts made by President Carter to bring about a series of incidents which culminated in the Camp David talks? This was an isolated example of a genuine attempt to achieve peace in a part of the world in which such an objective would seem almost impossible bearing in mind the hazards, the difficulties and the traditional enmities involved. One would feel that the most sterile area in the world to produce a peaceful solution would be anywhere in the volatile Middle East. But President Carter pressed on.

That brings me to my next heading-Sadat. Someone asked me the other day: 'Who would you name as one of the great men in your limited experience who has made a contribution to his fellow men?' That question had me stumped. If we applied that question to the times with which we in this chamber are most familiar, President Sadat would be a real possibility. He had everything to lose-I do not know that he had much to gain-when he grasped the nettle and travelled to Israel . He made the move knowing full well that he would inevitably not only attract the anger of his own people but also would be isolated from them. It is not a very pleasant experience to be isolated from one's own people. But he went to Israel; he pressed on.

I can remember that one of our members got up in our party room-I am going to leak a party secret-and said: 'We have only to set the date because inevitably Sadat is going to be removed from the scene; he is going to be assassinated'. I well remember that occasion. The man who said it was the honourable member for Bradfield, David Connolly, a man who has had vast experience in the Middle East, a man who was a career diplomat and a man for whom I have a great deal of respect. It was obvious that Sadat was at all times subject to the threat of assassination, and it happened in a most brutal way. A great man was removed from the scene.

I come to my next heading-Lebanon. It is remarkable how people can get terribly upset about an occasional death here and an occasional death there. Forgive me for making such a comment on Saint Patrick's day, but a few people also get knocked off occasionally in Ireland. These deaths are terrible and brutal. Deaths and casualties are occurring in other parts of the world as a result of brutal warfare. But in Lebanon it was a case of genocide. Tens of thousands of people have been brutally slaughtered. The statistics are there, if anyone thinks I am exaggerating. I and no doubt the honourable member for Robertson and other people who have been closely watching this evolution of disaster, misery and slaughter, are looking for one thing, and that is the eventual spread of peace-I know this seems an almost impossible dream-to the Middle East.

That brings me to my final heading-Palestine. I am going to combine all the points I have raised in the few minutes I have left. I do not think that any fairminded person would argue or even question the fact that the Palestinians should be settled. But we should not do a deal and say: 'We will settle the Palestinians providing you get rid of the Israelis'. Oh no, that would not be a solution at all. I had the opportunity in Washington to talk to an aide of Mr Atherton. Honourable members many recall that the Atherton round of talks took place prior to the Habib round of talks. Mr Habib is currently visiting the Middle East and making every effort to try to find some solution. One gets a little worried when people say that there is no solution, there is no answer to the Middle East problem. Does one stop cancer research because there is no apparent readily available cure for cancer? Of course not. Who keeps trying on the Middle East problem? It is the United States. It is quite remarkable that anything initiated by the United States comes under fire from certain people. Anything initiated by the United States has to be wrong, it has to be under suspicion, there has to be some ulterior motive, we have to be playing with the possibility of another Vietnam. Never is it suggested that this country is taking an initiative to secure peace, peace which cost the life of Sadat. The media of the United States stands indicted for looking for something to use against the President, whoever he may be, looking with suspicion on any move that is made to support the countries that have true democracy. This attitude is positively sickening.

Let us combine all of these motives. I had the opportunity of having discussions, not with Mr Atherton, but with his second-in-charge in Washington. I then went on to London and had opportunities of discussing matters with Mr Dean who was the expert with the British Government on Middle East affairs. They concurred in this respect: When the Camp David scheme of things eventually reaches its finality, which is a matter of the withdrawal from the Sinai Desert- that is the final act in this drama-then the whole of the resources of those who are genuinely seeking peace in the Middle East should be used in an attempt to find a solution to the Palestinian problem. I suppose that begins with the West Bank. What would we do? The reality seems to pass through this chamber. Many people will not fairly face up to the fact that if we do not have the assistance and co-operation of the United States of America and an assurance that she will come to our defence, then who in hell will come. I would like to know which super power, middle power, little power or any other power will assist us. Has anyone indicated that he is concerned about this country? We then turn to people in high places-I have had that great opportunity-who say: 'Australia is not the sort of country that holds our coat'. They have indicated that they are prepared to stand by and act with the United States in matters that are of world-wide importance and which are associated with the security and defence of the principles which we hold dear. My goodness, the people who stand together to support Western democracy are dwindling away. They are fading out of the picture .

I now deal with the matter of the Sinai Desert and the Multinational Force and Observers. I will confess quite frankly my own feelings about this. I lived in great apprehension that this Government might have decided not to go to the Sinai and turn its back on one of the great episodes of peace in our history. I had the opportunity of flying with our helicopter squadron out of Ismailiya. We flew across the Sinai Desert on the ordinary routine daily inspection tour. It was an experience that I will never forget. We flew across the Sinai and down to the Israeli border. We then flew to the coast and came back along the Red Sea area to Ismailiya. It took us a full day. We flew along the roads and I asked: ' Why are you flying along the bitumen roads?' The pilot replied: 'Because we might have to land and if we have to land we do not want to land on the desert because it is absolutely infiltrated with mines. There are thousands of mines still lying around'. That sort of thing occurs every day. I detected very promptly from the discussions I had with members of the Egyptian Government and with Pierre Hutton, our own Ambassador, that that unit, which was part of a very extensive peacekeeping force, was held in the highest regard. The ability, the dedication and the no-nonsense attitude of these Australian fliers was recognised and respected. So Australia was flying a flag and being held in the greatest repute.

In relation to Australia providing a force to go to the Sinai, what is the alternative? The alternative would be that any lip service paid to peace in the future would be purely that-lip service. We would say: 'We are not prepared to take part in this operation but we want the support and the assistance of the United States. We want to be regarded as a country that is right up to the forefront when it comes to the defence and the offence-if you like-of the democratic group of nations'. I do not want to talk again about Vietnam. I was the Minister for the Army when we wound up the war. I did have something to do with the final stages of that regrettable era. What would have been the result if the so-called Western bloc had stood firm? Maybe thousands of lives would have been saved. What would have been the result if John F. Kennedy had been alive or someone who would have taken decisive and prompt action? Maybe that war would never have occurred. Maybe that terrible tragedy that cost Australian and other lives may never have occurred. We are taking part in the Sinai peacekeeping force and we should be damn proud to be there.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley Mr K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I get on to what I basically want to say about the statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street), I should like to take up a couple of points that were made by Government supporters during their addresses. For example, the honourable member for Perth (Mr McLean), in speaking of the legal basis of the Sinai peacekeeping force, adopted a critical attitude towards the Labor Party for pointing out that it would not support a force which was not within the terms of the original Sinai agreement, which entailed a United Nations-backed peacekeeping force, on the ground that we had permitted the Soviet Union to exercise a veto on us. As I said in the previous debate, I have absolutely no brief for Soviet foreign policy anywhere in the world, let alone in the Middle East. But the simple fact of the matter is that there was never a Soviet veto exercised on a United Nations peacekeeping force in the Sinai. The Soviet Union did not have to exercise a veto because no majority on the Security Council could be found in favour of a Sinai peacekeeping force to necessitate a veto being exercised. I wish that the Government would leave that argument alone, because it is not one that will stand up.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Wentworth (Mr Coleman) claimed that the Labor Party had changed its position in a number of areas associated with the force, one of them being that it is no longer claiming that we did not have the troops to do the task. If the proposition, when we originally discussed this matter, had been what subsequently emerged, we probably would not have put that argument. But if the honourable member casts his mind back to the time, he will remember that the discussion was on the commitment of a battalion or half a battalion-two companies. That being so, I would say that what has eventually emerged indicates that we were correct in our assessment, because the force that the Government is committing is nowhere near that size.

Our opposition to the commitment to the Sinai peacekeeping force remains, but it is to be exercised within the way in which the Labor Party traditionally exercises its opposition when it opposes a commitment of Australian forces overseas by the Government. We are concerned that, once the commitment is made, every support is given to the soldiers while they are there and that they have appropriate legal protection. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) raised some very pertinent points during this debate as to whether the legal protection is actually adequate for the forces operating there. We do question the way the force is being finally prepared, despite the fact that the Government has had very considerable notice for it. Everything is extremely hurried. We have had a hurried amendment to the Repatriation Act. I was aware, from the conversations I had when I was in the Middle East, that the logistics for the force, its location and the way in which it would be deployed, were all being very hurriedly prepared by our officers there. It seems very likely in these circumstances that mistakes will be made. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition referred to certain areas where mistakes may well have been made. The points that he raised must be answered by the Government.

This commitment places Australia in the middle of an extraordinarily complicated and dangerous political area and situation. It is quite true that the force will supervise a disengagement between two parties which wish to be at peace. It is not true that it will be located in an area in which all interested parties, including some interested parties which occasionally use the Sinai, necessarily accept the basis of the peace. It is also not clear what the future course of relations between the two parties will be. It has been quite evident since the ascension of President Mubarak to that position in Egypt that there has been a shift in the Egyptian line. It is quite evident that the Egyptians are attempting to re-establish their relationships, at least with the conservative Arab States, and to assert some degree of leadership in the Arab bloc. That is a situation which we ought to welcome, but it creates a different political situation from that at the time this commitment was foreshadowed.

On the other side, the Israeli side, there has been a distinct change of attitude in Israel since the time of the signing of the original peace treaty. The Israelis have unquestionably, on the other occupied territories, become more strongly opposed to any further concessions of territory-opposition to further concessions possibly even in the context of a possible Arab recognition or mutual negotiations with the Jordanians. I suggest that that will create a degree of tension in some areas of the Camp David process which remain. I shall come to that matter later. This force will oblige us to have views on all these matters. We shall have our profile significantly raised in the Middle East as a result of our participation in this force, and states who have hitherto not been interested in what we have had to say about the general situation in the Middle East will become very interested indeed. We shall be obliged to have a more sophisticated and detailed understanding of the region's affairs than we have had to this point. So far we have not displayed the sensitivity. Nowhere is this clearer than in the Government's rather belated efforts to conform to its original promise to ensure that there should be no connection between the Multinational Force and Observers and the United States Rapid Deployment Force.

Why is it important to have this matter clear? I think that there are two reasons, and neither of them relates particularly to how the Labor Party might feel about the matter. They relate to problems that we confront in that area. The first reason is that other countries in the region with which we are friendly are very hostile towards and fearful of the rapid deployment force. It was quite evident to those of us, both Government and Opposition, who toured the area just after Christmas that in Saudi Arabia, in the emirates and in Jordan, the leaders of the governments that we met saw absolutely no value whatsoever in the American notion of a strategic consensus and absolutely no value in the rapid deployment force. They feared that it would provoke Soviet involvement. They feared that it would destabilise local populations if it were brought into the area and create a situation of difficulty for the rulers. They feared ways in which the United States might use the force.

The second reason why we must make clear the separation of the MFO from the RDF is that the three main parties to this agreement-Egypt, Israel and, of course, the United States-have all in their various ways offered support for the Rapid Deployment Force, including the use of facilities, and have also offered support for the general American strategy in the area of a strategic consensus against Soviet initiatives. Given that situation, it is highly likely that the Arab powers in the area which are not parties to this agreement will be highly suspicious of the nature of the force when it goes into the area. That is why it must be crystal clear that the two forces ought to be separated. So, from the outset, we of the Opposition, anticipating this, have argued that the Americans ought not to commit a unit of the eighty-second airborne division to that force but ought to draw their forces from elsewhere-from other sections of the US Armed Services that are not associated with the Rapid Deployment Force.

TALK.START.PARA: —You must take the word of Congress in that case.

—That is not because we of the Labor Party need to be convinced that the MFO will not be used as part of the RDF. I am prepared to accept a congressional resolution on that matter. The other Arab states in the area, an area rife with paranoia and suspicion, will not be so inclined. Yet when I raised this matter last October, at Question Time, I was blown out backwards by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and nothing was done until a month ago when the Minister scampered about discovering what by then had become a fait accompli and revealed to the Australian Press, despite the fact that it had been raised in the House last October and ought to have been quite obvious to him, that he was ignorant of the fact that a unit of the RDF was going to be used.

SPEECH.PARA: If that is the degree of sensitivity to Middle Eastern issues that is to be associated with this commitment, we shall have some problems here. In this whole process we have been very protective of the American position. We have manoeuvred in precisely the directions which the United States wanted vis-a-vis its European allies. The Europeans, on the other hand, have manoeuvred to incorporate a more broadly-based notion of a Middle East settlement within the framework of their MFO commitment. We had nothing to say on this matter; certainly nothing to say to the Egyptians, the Israelis and the Americans. We must now develop some views. One of the problems with which we are now confronted is that this involvement increases pressure on us to have views on complex matters which will quite dramatically affect our ability to remain on friendly terms with both Israel and the Arabs. Whether we accept responsibility for a broad Middle East settlement-I presume from the Minister's statement that we do-we have definitely accepted a responsibility for what remains of the Camp David process, as we are there to keep the peace between the parties.

What are our views on the outstanding differences associated with the Camp David process? What are our views on the question of automony of the West Bank? Do we accept the Egyptian view that it must have full atonomy, that the Arabs on the West Bank must have that autonomy with no further Israeli settlement in the area, to be followed in five years by an act of Palestinian self-determination? If that is our view, are we going to protest as West Bank Arab politicians become the object of assassination attempts as Arab homes are dynamited or as the Israeli military beats up Arab demonstrators?

When we visited the area we met Mayor Freij, a mayor on the West Bank who, whilst a supporter of the Palestine Liberation Organisation, has called upon that organisation to recognise Israel. He revealed to us the full extent of the extraordinary difficulty he has experienced in co-operating with the Israeli authorities. What are the Government's views going to be on that? What will it say to him? The Government did not have to say anything to him a few months ago but it does now because it is involved in the Camp David process. Or, is the Government going to accept the Israeli view of autonomy, that 30 per cent of the West Bank now belongs to Israel, to be settled at will by Israeli settlers and to be fully incorporated-that is the whole of the West Bank-at the end of the five year period of experimentation within the nation state of Israel? If that is our view, are we to support Israel in the United Nations when it runs into trouble on this issue and needs to be defended diplomatically? We know nothing of this from the Government and we have heard nothing about it from the Government speakers. The Government has put us in it; now it must give us some answers. The Government is now involved and it must make a stand.

What about the question of the Palestinian people? They are supposedly involved in the next stage of the Camp David process. The Egyptians believe that now is the time for the Palestinians to be brought into discussions. They want to involve the PLO, yet Israel will not negotiate on any basis acceptable to the Palestinians and vice versa. What is going to be our stand? This may be more immediate than honourable members think. There is some PLO activity in the Sinai . I would like to know what the Government's instructions are to members of the MFO who might come across a PLO operation. Will they report it or intercept it, taking sides in that continuing conflict which is not strictly related to the particular area of their competence? No public answers have come forth from the Government on this matter.

What about Jerusalem? That question is also involved in current Camp David negotiations. Does the honourable member for Perth (Mr McLean) agree with the Egyptian view that Arab Jerusalem is part of the Arab West Bank of the Jordan, that Arab citizens of Arab Jerusalem should vote in elections for the autonomy council? Israel does not accept this. It regards Jerusalem as part of Israel. What does the Government think about this? Does it agree with the Pope, who has argued that Jerusalem ought to be an international city? We need to know what the Government thinks about this. We did not need to know that a few months ago because we were irrelevant to the process. The Government has now put us right in it; now, what are its views on the matter?

Let us go a step further, because the Minister invites us to when he talks about a general settlement in the Middle East. What are our views in other areas of Arab-Israeli relations? Israel is intimately involved in the situation that is developing in the Lebanon. When we were in northern Israel, on three nights we saw large numbers of Israeli tanks on the backs of trucks moving northward into the border area with Lebanon. It was quite evident to us that at least the option of a massive Israeli attack in the Lebanon was being created by the Israeli military. An attack has certainly been threatened in a certain set of conditions. It may eventually be a justified attack, or it may not, but one thing is certain: Since we have so actively raised our profile in the area, the nations in the area are going to want to know what we think about the matter.

If honourable members do not think that is going to be asked of us, I refer them to their own Government's response to the Israeli annexation of the Golan. This is one matter on which I did agree with the Government in its Middle Eastern policy. But its opposition to the Israeli action was in contrast to the past record of the Government, when it very rarely said anything about any development in the Middle East. When the Israelis annexed the Golan, the Australian Ambassador went straight into the Israeli Foreign Ministry to express the Australian protest. That is a signal of what we can expect in the future. We are going to be obliged to have views on these issues. These views will embarrass us in our relations with the Israelis or they will embarrass us in our relations with the Arabs.

We on this side of the House have said that Australia ought to have an opportunity to speak to all sides and to have our views taken seriously by all sides. That was the reason for our opposition to the MFO commitment. We did not want to involve Australia in that process because we do not believe that the sorts of circumstances in which we are going to be involved as a result of this commitment are going to enable us to make that serious contribution. We have lost a substantial amount of our standing in the Arab world. That will not produce any retaliation, but the Arabs take us as a less serious and independent power than they once did. I think in terms of peace in the area and in terms of the sort of contribution we could make to it, that is a very great shame indeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Falconer Mr P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is debating the tabling of certain documents by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) relating to Australia' s participation in the Sinai Multinational Force and Observers. Those documents consisted of two exchanges of letters constituting the agreement between the MFO Director-General and the Australian Foreign Minister, the protocol signed by Egypt and Israel on 3 August 1981, which was the basis for the establishment of the Sinai multinational force, and also an aide-memoire, which is attached to a letter from the Director-General.

SPEECH.PARA: I consider that this statement is the latest action in a very serious attempt by the Government to inform the Parliament and the Australian people and to promote debate on this issue of Australia's participation in a multinational force in the Sinai. I compliment the Government and the Minister for Foreign Affairs in particular on the manner in which they have encouraged debate on this issue. Whatever the views of honourable members about the final decision reached by the Government, I believe that all honourable members should acknowledge that the Minister has taken very deliberate action to canvass in this House the issues involved and to encourage public debate even before the Government eventually decided its position on the issue.

Clearly the decision, which was announced by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) on 28 October last year for Australia to participate in a multinational force, was influenced by the discussions which preceded it in this Parliament, in the Government members party room and in the public arena. Certainly I had to be satisfied on certain questions before I was happy about our participation in the multinational force. In the end I was happy to support a commitment to such a peacekeeping force if several strict conditions were met.

These conditions were, in fact, met and spelt out in the Prime Minister's statement and they reflect the manner in which the Government has listened to the public debates on the matter. For example, our participation was made conditional upon the force being a truly international one. The international size of our commitment was to be maintained so that there was no question of it involving more and more personnel over time. The structure of the force has been clearly spelt out and the responsibilities of Australian commanders are defined. Moreover, I would not have been happy about our involvement without the clearly expressed wish on behalf of both Israel and Egypt for an Australian participation, not just for reasons of presentation but for the strict and basic reasons concerning the legitimacy of the force and our right to be there as part of it.

An important element of the Prime Minister's statement last October was the emphasis he gave to the need to accommodate the aspirations of the Palestinian people. I think we should dwell on this matter because some of the critics from the Opposition would be well advised to examine that part of the Prime Minister' s statement with great care. I suggest that it represents the greatest shift in the policy of any Australian government towards an acceptance of the claims of the Palestinian people that we have ever had from any spokesman for any government in Australia. Furthermore, I submit that such a shift in emphasis would not have been possible without an Australian commitment to a peacekeeping force which would help guarantee the security of Israel's southern border.

I refer in this respect to the speeches which have been made by the honourable member for Robertson (Mr Cohen) both at the time of the Prime Minister's statement last October and today in this House when he spoke on the statement by the Foreign Minister. The honourable member for Robertson pointed out the desperate need of the Israeli people to be assured that the rest of the world was prepared to play a part in guaranteeing Israel's security. Only by some practicial demonstration of a willingness by the international community to guarantee Israel's borders could the Israelis even begin to feel confident about entering into negotiations on matters concerning Judea, Samaria and the Golan Heights. In my view, Australian policy would not have reflected a shift towards an acceptance of the rights of the Palestinians without at the same time ensuring that we were giving a definite commitment to a process of peace in the Middle East. The only workable commitment to a process of peace in the Middle East is in the form of the Camp David Accords. If they fail, no other process will even begin to operate in the Middle east.

I should like to draw attention to what the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) had to say when he spoke in the debate last October. Most of what he had to say constituted, frankly, a justification for Australia's involvement in a multinational peacekeeping force. There is no doubt in my mind that he personally supports the Government's decision in this matter. However, he stated in this House that he supported the Australian Labor Party policy because that policy reflected the results of public opinion polls. It should be noted that at the time the honourable member for Wills seconded the Caucus resolution which determined the Labor Party's official attitude, none of the four national public opinion organisations in Australia had taken any polls on the issue. It is clear that the official policy of the ALP was forced upon the honourable member for Wills by the internal power situation of the party. In particular, the official ALP policy reflects the influence of the attitude of the socialist Left faction, particularly in Victoria, which is adamantly anti-Israel in its policies and rhetoric. This attitude was reflected in the speech of the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Milton) on this subject. He has openly declared his adherence to the socialist Left. His attitude on this issue was to require Israel to give away all her negotiating points in the Middle East without offering any accompanying guarantee of her right to live within internationally accepted and secure borders.

No doubt some risk is associated with the Government's decision. I want to comment on that. None of us who support this policy of participating in the multinational force should do so in any sort of adventurous spirit without considering our responsibility to the servicemen whom we are committing to the Middle East. While it is essentially a peacekeeping force to supervise the handing over of territory from one friendly power to another, we must acknowledge that in view of the instabilities in the Middle East it still involves some risk, however small. Every honourable member who supports the decision to participate in the peacekeeping force must be prepared to accept responsibility for that risk.

As I mentioned earlier, I had some queries that I needed to have settled in my mind before being prepared to support an Australian commitment. Frankly, I developed substantial doubts, particularly after the Israeli air attack on Beirut last year. My view then was that this Israeli action, which even her friends found hard to justify, raised the temperature in the region so much that there was a substantial risk that any peacekeeping force would be a target for armed elements in the region outside the control of both Israel and Egypt. I also questioned the need for such a force if in fact both Egypt and Israel agreed upon a withdrawal procedure. That point was eloquently answered by the honourable member for Robertson, as I have already mentioned. Israel needs to be assured that the rest of the world cares about her security if she is to accept encouragement to enter into further negotiations on other issues.

There has been much criticism of the reluctance of Prime Minister Begin of Israel to enter-indeed, of his opposition to entering-into negotiations on the West Bank and about settlement policies involving Israeli communities established on Arab land. Frankly, my preference would have been for Mr Perez of the Israeli Labor Party to have won the Israeli election last year. In my view there would have been a greater chance of a fresh approach to negotiations with a new government in power in Israel. However, Mr Begin did win, although very narrowly, and he is Israel's Prime Minister with whom the world must deal. He won in a democratic election. We must not take his apparent reluctance as the last word on this subject as far as negotiations on other matters are concerned. Let us remember that the late President Sadat, who was welcomed in Israel as a harbinger of peace, was in the 1973 war condemned by Israel as a warmonger and as a threat to international peace. Prime Minister Begin of Israel only a few short years ago was saying adamantly that while he was Prime Minister he would not give up one inch of the Sinai. Now he has signed away the lot. An international guarantee of the security and integrity of Israel's right to exist is the key to greater Israeli flexibility on West Bank and Palestinian issues.

I submit that our participation and the participation of other democratic nations in a peacekeeping force would give us greater leverage in persuading the Israeli Government to be more forthcoming on these negotiations than we would have if we were not involved in such a peacekeeping force. I strongly recommend that the Government use the influence that it will have with Israel as a result of our participation in this force to encourage Israel to enter into meaningful negotiations on these other issues. Both the Israelis and the Palestine Liberation Organisation say publicly that they will never recognise the other, but privately many Israelis and many PLO activists give other assurances. It appears that neither wants to play this last card of recognising the other before being assured that the other side will make a concession simultaneously. Obviously, the world must encourage both sides to have the confidence to take this step. One important and essential element of that is to ensure that Israel has the right and is recognised internationally as having the right to live within secure and well-defined borders.

I want to deal with the contention which is obviously the key, as I understand it, to the Opposition's argument; that is, that this force should have been a United Nations force and if it were a United Nations force they would be prepared to support it. Perhaps we would all prefer it to be a United Nations force. Nonetheless I suggest that it would not give it any greater legitimacy than the present structure has. Let us ask ourselves: What is so morally superior about a United Nations force? Certainly it is desirable, but if we are looking at legitimacy and the moral right of a force to be in place, why is it any more superior? Did our armed contingent in Zimbabwe, for example, which served so effectively and I thought with bipartisan support in the supervision of elections in that country, lack legitimacy because if was not a member of a United Nations force? Certainly that contingent faced some risks, albeit minimal , because the country contained at least three competing armies and other armed elements and only weeks before that country had been fighting a vicious and cruel civil war. None of us, in committing our troops to that country, albeit for a peaceful operation, could have been certain that they would not face attack from an uncontrolled guerilla group in the country. Did the Opposition oppose our involvement in that exercise on the basis that it was not a part of a United Nations force? Indeed, I suggest that apart from the Commonwealth connection, that part of Africa impinges less on our direct international interests than does the Middle East.

Let us consider also the Papua New Guinea contingent which went to Vanuatu in 1980 when that country's security was threatened by rebellion on Santo. Any one who is familiar with the situation knows that the Papua New Guinea force could not have got there without Australia's help in terms of our skilled technical personnel who were on secondment to the Papua New Guines force at the time. The support of the Australian Government was canvassed and was sought specifically for that involvement. Did the Opposition rise up in condemnation because the Papua New Guinea force which went there, with our blessing as I understand it, was not a United Nations force?

Let me turn to the matter of our participation in the Korean war. That ostensibly was as part of a United Nations force. Was our participation in the Korean war any more moral than would otherwise have been the case because it was formally approved by the United Nations? I doubt that those who have suffered any misgivings about the appropriatness of our involvement there are terribly impressed by the fact that the allied forces in Korea had the United Nations imprimatur. It appears to me that what the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and the Opposition spokesmen are saying is that they will agree to our participation in the Sinai force if it has the backing of the United Nations. But it depends on a number of factors outside our control. I submit to this House that if we have an agreement which is acceptable to the major parties directly involved, namely Egypt and Israel-we have been requested by them to participate-and if it is a matter on which hinges the whole success of any future negotiations, we have a responsibility to consider very seriously any request to participate in such a force. I accept that there may be some element of risk, however minimal, with our participation but I believe that Australia, as a responsible member of the international community with an interest in ensuring that the peace process in the Middle East continues, is successful and develops in other directions and encompasses many more aspects of the Middle East problem, and as a responsible nation in good company with others, should participate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morrison The Hon W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid that the honourable member for Casey (Mr Falconer) and the Government have failed to answer one very vital question about the force, and that question is: What is the force going to do? I will go back over some of the arguments and some of the justifications that were presented previously by this Government. In a statement on 22 October 1981 the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . as the text of the Treaty makes clear, that complete withdrawal is conditional on the existence of a peacekeeping force which will supervise both the Israeli withdrawal from the Sinai and the implementation of security arrangements agreed on in the Treaty.

Further on in that statement the Prime Minister established as the main argument for the force the need to ensure that Israel's withdrawal from the Sinai is being carried out in accordance with international commitments. I stress the point that the force 'will supervise the Israeli withdrawal' because-and I have not heard any Government supporter consider this question-less than two weeks after the Prime Minister's statement the Israeli Prime Minister pulled the rug completely from under the position of the Prime Minister and of the Government. In addressing the Israeli Cabinet early in November Prime Minister Begin stipulated-and I want Government supporters to listen to this carefully:
No country should label its participation as the supervision of Israel's withdrawal from occupied territory.

Here we have a proposition in which the Prime Minister stated explicitly to the people of Australia that the main purpose of our going into the Sinai is to supervise Israel's withdrawal and the Israeli Prime Minister saying that no country should label its participation as supervision of Israel's withdrawal. He was talking not only about Australia. There also happened to be European powers which in fact had great difficulty in getting Israeli acceptance on Israeli terms for the involvement of European forces in the Sinai peacekeeping force. The main argument presented by the Government and by the Prime Minister has been denied by the Israeli Government itself. Either the Prime Minister believed what he said at the time he said it or else he has misled this House and this Parliament. Prime Minister Begin's ex cathedra statement has not been mentioned and I must confess that in the statement today by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) there is no reference at all to the justification for Australian participation in the Sinai peace force. We had a whole lot of housekeeping details in submissions and in the attachments but the basic proposition of what the Australian force is going to do there has been cut out of all statements by the Government.

We have had an opportunity in the last couple of days of having a talk with a very senior representative of the British Government. This question was posed to him: What is the role and responsibility of the peacekeeping force? He could not answer. At least he was honest. He could not answer except to say that both sides had expressed an interest in it and that the United States was anxious that it should take place. But this whole question of conformity with Annex 1 of the Camp David Accords indicated throughout that there would be a gradual withdrawal of Israeli forces and as that withdrawal took place the peacekeeping force would move in. I quote from Article I of Annex I:
As Israeli armed forces withdraw, United Nations forces will immediately enter the evacuated areas to establish interim and temporary buffer zones . . .

All through Annex I, which is the basis for the commitment of the force, is this argument of phased movements of the peacekeeping force as the Israeli forces withdraw. What has happened is that the Israelis have insisted that this does not take place in contradiction and in contravention of the Camp David Accords. They have said quite explicitly that the peacekeeping force will not be allowed to be put in place until the Israelis have withdrawn in their own way. So all the argumentation, all the references in Annex I of the Camp David Accords have been completely by-passed. I return to the basic question which I ask of the Government: What is the main job of the Australian contingent as part of the peacekeeping force? The argumentation before of the Prime Minister was that it is to supervise the Israeli withdrawal. This is demonstrably not the case. That was the proposition which was put to this Parliament and to the Australian people. So we have a situation in which the Australian forces are going in to carry out a responsibility that is no longer relevant. The Australian force is going into one of the most difficult areas of the world, and as the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley) pointed out one of the most dangerous and volatile areas in the world, with no justification that has been spelt out by the Government.

I would like on this occasion to quote my good friend and colleague, one of the Government supporters, who put forward a view but unfortunately as a Government supporter he was not able to influence the final decision of the Government. In a paper he wrote last year he said:

With its southern flanks fully secured by the Force (particularly by virtue of the US presence in the Force), Israel would be more likely to engage in serious negotiations, and to make serious concessions for the purposes of solving the West Bank, Gaza, Old City of Jerusalem and the Golan Heights issues . . .
That is the argumentation that he then proceeded to attack, and this is his answer to that proposition:

Nothing in recent history supports this view. If anything, it seems likely that the more secure Israel feels to the South, the more free it would feel to take military action against, for example, the PLO and Syria.

That analysis has been effectively brought to fruition because that is precisely what is going to happen. We have seen that the Begin Government has deliberately torpedoed the United Nations Security Council Resolution 242 which is the very basis of the introductory or preambular statement to the Accord. That resolution simply calls for the withdrawal of Israeli forces from the territories occupied in the 1967 conflict. We have seen the expansion of the Israeli settlements on the West Bank, in defiance of the Accords. We have seen the annexation of the Golan Heights on 14 December 1981. We have seen the assertion of sovereignty by Israel over the whole of Jerusalem. We are talking about the whole concept of peace in the Middle East. We are talking about a need to attach ourselves to the Camp David Accords. But one of the major partners has quite deliberately set out -and this has been going on for some months, in fact years-on another course. On re-election Prime Minister Begin stated explicitly to the Knesset what he intended to do. He stated quite explicitly that he was going to annex the Golan Heights. He stated quite explicitly what his attitude was to the city of Jerusalem, and he has gone on and on. I quote one more statement which was made to the Knesset on 5 August 1981. In all of the discussions about Camp David and Australia's involvement which have taken place since then, we know what Prime Minister Begin's aims, objectives and accomplishments have been. He said that the autonomy agreed upon at Camp David means neither sovereignty nor self- determination. He is re-writing Camp David for his own benefit. He said that the autonomy agreements set down at Camp David are guarantees that under no condition will a Palestinian state emerge in the territory of Western Yeretz Israel. These statements are in direct contradiction not only of the spirit of Camp David but also in fact of the articles of Camp David. Australian forces are being sent by this Government to participate in what is called a peacekeeping force. The argument is that it will be a contribution to peace. But when one of the partners has shown by its actions that it is flagrantly opposed to both the spirit and the words of the Camp David Accords, what chances of success are there? I must confess that I have to agree with the very pessimistic account given by a member of the Government in a very closely reasoned and closely analysed piece. He finished up by saying:

To conclude. By becoming part of the Force, we place ourselves hostages to fortune, in that we can be affected by events that we can neither predict nor control and we subject ourselves to risks that cannot be calculated.

I thoroughly agree with that statement. That is precisely what we are doing. As the honourable member for Swan has pointed out, by our participation we are now placing ourselves in a situation in which we have to respond and we have to take a public position on all the issues of the Middle East. I do not think the Government is capable of carrying that through to its logical conclusion because it is an area, a part of the world, where the complications are manifold. We have introduced a new notion into our foreign policy. I do not suppose the challenge will hurt the Government very much but, given its past performance, it is certainly going to fall down on it. Our basic concern is that we are putting our forces there without any real justification explained to the Australian people. The justification that we have given in the past has been negatived by the Prime Minister of Israel. He stated quite explicitly that he would not put up with the justification that the Prime Minister explained to the Australian people and to the Parliament. To argue that this will contribute to peace in the Middle East is fallacious. I think the propositions put forward by the Government member bear very close study. Certainly I would agree with the propositions. I turn now to the only point of a policy matter that was made in the statement this afternoon, which was of assurances that were supposed to have been received from the United states on the question of the relationship between the MFO and the rapid deployment force. The Minister stated:
. . . our requirement that no part of the MFO, including the United States component should have any association with a United States rapid reployment force.

He stated 'any association with a US rapid deployment force'. That was the proposition put by the Prime Minister back on 22 October 1981. Now, as the honourable member for Swan has pointed out-he pointed it out last year-the unit that will be going into the Sinai is a unit of the rapid deployment force. In the statement the Minister has stated that Australia has insisted that the US component should not have any association with the United States rapid deployment force. I have quoted from the Minister's statement. How can the Government possibly argue that it should have no association with the rapid deployment force when a unit of the 82nd Airborne Division, which is the tooth group, a front line of the rapid deployment force, is to be part of the peacekeeping force? There are a number of issues on which I feel the Australian people have been misled. They have certainly been misled on the main arguments put back in October 1981 by the Prime Minister about the justification for Australia's participation. That has been torpedoed by Prime Minister Begin. The whole notion of peace in the Middle East has been torpedoed by the present Israeli Administration because everything that is intended to be achieved by the Camp David Accords has been beaten by the Prime Minister of Israel.

When we come to a statement that there should be no association between the rapid deployment force and the MFO we find that one of the units of the rapid deployment force is the United States component in the MFO. I believe that the Government has still a great deal to explain. I will state quite deliberately that this Government, as in past adventures such as Vietnam, has deliberately misled the Australian people. Regrettably, we cannot change the decision that has been made. The Australian forces are off to the Sinai. We wish them well and we wish them all a safe return. But, regrettably, it is the basis of a Government policy that the Opposition strongly opposes.

TALK.START.PARA: —In entering a debate like this, having listened to other speakers, one is always impressed by the fact that most speakers approach the issues that are raised in the Parliament in terms of their preconceived commitments and preconceived attitudes towards the Middle East. I suppose that being the case-I am certainly not exempt from that-I approached this debate on the basis of one who has had within my own Party and in the Parliament a long standing commitment to the right of the State of Israel to exist within safe and secure borders. But, despite that commitment and having recently visited the whole region of the Middle East for some five or six weeks and having participated in discussions with political leaders in a vast range of countries which included Iraq, Jordan, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates, Syria, Israel and Egypt, I came back more than ever convinced that it was no longer good enough for Australia as an important middle-power to commit troops to any part of the world, particularly to a region in which we have never been a nation exerting a major influence. We have never sought to exercise a major influence there and we should not commit troops, until such time as we have thought through the foreign policy objectives in which we are involved when committing those troops.
—Oh!
—If the Minister at the table finds that statement--
—I look at 1915 and 1941.
—If I can say this to the Minister: The history of Australia is a history of committing troops overseas, in the Boer War, in 1914-1918 War--
—The Sudan.

—The Boxer Rebellion.

—And the Boxer Rebellion, all on the basis that we were asked by a super-power. On every occasion we had not thought through the foreign policy implications. In the last war there was a threat to Australia in which we were involved and we are still paying the penalty for our involvement in Vietnam because we did not think through our foreign policy objectives on that occasion. I do not believe, and I do not accept the view, that we responded to a request from Israel or that we responded to a request from Egypt in this matter. We responded to the pressures of the United States of America that is why again we have a commitment, in which our foreign policy objectives are, I might say again , far from clear. I put it to the Minister that it sounds easy to say 'what we are about is securing the peace'. But if one goes, as I have with my colleagues, to the various states, the view of peace and how it is obtained in Saudi Arabia, the view of peace and how it is obtained in Israel, the view of peace and how it is obtained in Iraq or Egypt, are all quite different. If we are to have troops in the Sinai, if we are to have a commitment in that area militarily, we have raised the expectations. There is no doubt about this because it was expressed very firmly to the delegation of which I was a member, by no less a person than the Prime Minister of Egypt. He said: 'Now that you have a commitment in this region, we believe you will have a continuing political involvement.' That involves, I believe, a degree of maturity and sophistication in the determination of foreign policy objectives which has certainly not emerged in this debate nor from anything the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) has said.

SPEECH.PARA: It is all very well for the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Minister to say that the Government's objective in committing troops to this region is to secure the peace. In the Middle East I sat at a table with a group from this Parliament led by a senior Minister who has acted as Foreign Minister on a number of occasions. A senior Arab politician who holds a position of some importance in his own country asked-as he was entitled to do-why we were committing troops to the Middle East. He was expecting some reservation to be expressed about our involvement in the Camp David process, certainly about our commitment of troops to the region. The answer given, presumably on behalf of the Government, was that we had sent troops to the Middle East as part of the Camp David process in order-I quote from a note that I made in my diary at the time-'to secure the return of Arab lands to Arabs'. One can get away with that sort of statement in private on some occasions but will not ultimately be able to say one thing when speaking to the leaders of the Arab world and another when speaking to a state such as Israel. I have no doubt as to what the reaction of the Prime Minister of Israel would have been to such a statement. If the Government of Israel has made anything clear in terms of the Camp David process it is that in that regard it did not want any commitment from Australia.

Let us follow this line of reasoning a little further. What is the position of this Government? I say at the outset that I do not believe that the Camp David process is dead. It is not dead because at least two powers are seriously involved in negotiations. But it is in great jeopardy because the views of Israel and Egypt as to autonomy and what it means differ greatly. Similarly, their views about the future of a Palestinian State are diverse. As a result of this commitment, it will no longer be possible for the Government or the Foreign Minister to skate around the problems of the Middle East by the use of generalities. I refer to some of the problems that have been raised by the honourable member for Swan (Mr Beazley). The Australian contingent is a nominal force and I do not believe that it is under any great military threat. Probably the average Australian serviceman faces greater threats when he is involved in exercises such as 'Kangaroo 81' or any other exercises with which the Australian military forces occupy themselves. But what is the Australian peacekeeping force to do if it has brought to its notice the fact the there are Palestinian Liberation Organisation insurgents operating in its region? Is it to report the fact? Is it to take action to try to secure and apprehend the offenders or is it to ignore the problem? They might seem like simple questions, but given the complexity of Middle East politics they raise very serious political questions which have to be answered. Up till now it was easy for us to say that our policy on the state of Israel was that we believed-it has certainly been my position-in its right to exist within safe and secure borders. There is no question about that. I see that the honourable member for Phillip (Mr Birney) is nodding his head. But as a result of the commitment which we have now made I ask him-because it is a difficult question to resolve-about what borders are we talking. That is the question that we will be asked. Are we talking about Israel's borders of 1948? Are we talking about the borders of 1967, or about those of the present? The government of Israel has strong views about its borders. It has recently annexed the Golan Heights. There are strong arguments in support of that action. Those who represent the Arab viewpoint also have strong feelings about it. I ask the honourable member for Phillip, the Minister for Science and Technology, (Mr Thomson), who is at the table, and the Minister for Foreign Affairs, who say that we support the right of Israel to exist within safe and secure borders, whether those borders include the Golan Heights. Do they include the city of Jerusalem? These are the questions which we as a parliament have now to consider and face. I submit that it is no longer of any use, or a positive contribution to this debate, to indulge in the exercise in the rhetoric that we have had in this House today. In my view it does not really matter what the socialist left in Victoria, or some sections of it, might think, what the Labor Unity group might think or what certain groups within the Liberal Party of Australia might think. What is important is that this nation, as a nation, should have a set of clearly defined objectives in regard to where we are going in the Middle East. I do not believe that we know. There is as much division within the Government on the issue as there is in any branch of the Labor Party. Australian society is clearly divided. Obviously, a great deal of further consideration and discussion is needed. I believe that great things have already been achieved in this area. The Camp David Accords constituted a major step forward. If I was given cause for hope on my recent tour it was in the strength and the commitment that I found in Egypt. One honourable member has already mentioned it but I reaffirm it . I believe that that commitment means that Egypt sees itself not only as a major power in the Arab world, one that is concerned to recognise Israel, but also as one that is aware of the history of the Jewish people and the problems that involved the founding of the Jewish state. It approaches those problems with some sensitivity and sees itself as capable of interpreting to the rest of the Arab world Israel's very real fears about its own security.

Two things distinguish Israel from every other state in the region: Not only is it a viable political democracy but also every Israeli knows there is no war Israel can afford to lose. That has coloured their attitude, not merely to the peacekeeping process, but also to the whole question of how to resolve problems. Therefore, some time must elapse for a new set of relations to be capable of emerging in this trouble spot. I submit that in this situation Australia had an alternative role to play, that of an important middle power. We are not seen by any nation in the region as a super-power. Nor are we seen as one which could not act as an honest broker.

My concern is that by acting in a way which would suit the short term objectives of the present Amercian Administration we find ourselves in a situation in which our capacity to act as an honest broker in the region has been to no small extent significantly mitigated. I believe that, given the complexities that are involved in that situation, it would have been better for Australia, for the State of Israel and I think for the moderate Arab States if Australia had maintained its role and its capacity to act as an honest broker rather than yet again climbing aboard the American gravy train and accepting its objectives for this area. Ulti- mately I will be more interested in hearing a speech from the Minister for Foreign Affairs in which he outlines in some detail the answers and the views that this Government has to the very real and detailed problems that confront every nation in the Middle East that is concerned to effect a lasting and permanent peace in that region. to date we have been able to survive with glib generalities. That is no longer an option.
