TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1982 is to make a wide variety of changes to the tariff rates applying to many industries in our country. Sixteen broad categories of goods are involved in the changes. Some of them are very small, such as the wheelchair industry which employs only 55 workers, and some are very large such as the textiles, clothing and footwear industries, which employ about 120,000 workers.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to these changes which indirectly and directly have an important bearing on the lives of many tens of thousands of Australians, the Bill provides for other amendments. The first to which I would like to draw attention involves changes to preferential tariff rates for certain goods from developing countries . The second category involves some additions to the list of goods accorded special preferences under the South Pacific Regional Trade and Economic Cooperation Agreement. The third category is the addition of electric soil heating apparatus to the list of goods agreed to under the New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement.

The Opposition will not oppose the Bill because we believe that its provisions are all aimed at desirable objectives, in particular the maintenance of employment in a wide variety of manufacturing industries in Australia and also the encouragement of freer trade with our close neighbours, the countries of the South Pacific Forum, including New Zealand. However, while we do not oppose the Bill we take particular objection to the decision of the Government to impose a tariff duty on the importation of wheelchairs. It is not that the Australian Labor Party is opposed to the retention of a wheelchair manufacturing industry in Australia; on the contrary, we believe it is highly desirable that the capacity to make such items locally be maintained. However, the effect of a tariff is to raise the price of imported wheelchairs as well as to enable higher prices to be charged for locally produced wheelchairs. Where wheelchairs are provided free of charge by the Government, such an impost does not disadvantage those who must use them, unless they are taxpayers like the rest of us. We are then left to pay the taxes on these wheelchairs.

Not all wheelchairs needed by Australians are provided free of charge. What is more, the scheme which provides free chairs is so inadequately funded by the Government that hundreds of people are missing out on provisions to which they are entitled. Those who must pay for their wheelchairs as a result of import tariff duties can contribute as much as $300 a chair to the Government coffers. The Labor Party believes that this tax on wheelchairs is an abomination. This particular tariff change was introduced into this House during 1981, the International Year of Disabled Persons. This matter was raised by the Opposition on 2 June last year when the wheelchair tariff was first put before this House as part of the Customs Tariff Validation Bill. At that time we pointed out that the tariff proposed by the Government was significantly higher than had prevailed before 1 January 1980.

I turn to the history of this matter. Prior to 1980, many imports of wheelchairs came from the United Kingdom at a preferential tariff rate of 15 per cent but on 1 January 1980 this preference was abolished so that the tariff immediately jumped from 34 per cent to 36 per cent. The Government sought Industries Assistance Commission advice on this issue and, following a report from the IAC, the present arrangements were decided upon by Cabinet. In the first year, duty of 30 per cent is to be maintained with a reduction to 25 per cent in the second year and 20 per cent thereafter. Still we do not get down to the old preferential rate of tariff of 15 per cent. I repeat: All of these rates are higher than the original British preferential rate.

When the Opposition objected to this tax on the disabled-I emphasise that it was a tax on the disabled, first introduced in the Year of Disabled Persons-the response we received from the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore), who out of courtesy is in the House and I acknowledge that, was as I will read. I am sure that he will be ashamed when I remind him of the words he used which were:
I know that the Australian Labor Party has a bleeding heart from time to time, but the relevance is to industry.

I think we can introduce measures which are both relevant to industry and which show that we have a bleeding heart, from whatever side of the Parliament we come . I believe that it is indifference that allows the present tax on wheelchairs to continue and the Minister should stand condemned while he allows it. I am sure that after he has heard my words he will go away from this chamber much more resolved to change this tax, much more resolved to get rid of his indifference on this matter.

The fact that this measure provides a degree of protection to industry does not excise all of its possible impacts. There is an alternative way of assisting industry which ensures that the prices of goods do not rise. This technique was recommended by a minority of the IAC commissioners who provided advice to the Government. It is to provide a bounty or subsidy for local production instead of a tax on imports. I readily admit that, although I mentioned that taxpayers are paying for the wheelchairs provided to the disabled free of charge, with a bounty those taxpayers will, unless we manage to get a little more efficiency into the wheelchair manufacturing industry, be paying somewhat more because the bounty would be payable not only in relation to wheelchairs which are going to those who receive them free of charge but also in relation to those wheelchairs for which people are being charged at present. So, a bounty lowers the price of a good; a tariff raises it. I believe there is a strong case to be made out for a bounty to be payable on wheelchairs to lower the price of wheelchairs rather than having this extra tariff, over and above what was payable, applied to wheelchairs so that the poor unfortunate people who are obliged to use wheelchairs have to pay an extra amount into the coffers of the Government.

Already we have bounties in Australia for the production of penicillin. The Government seems to have understood the logic in that case. Not surprisingly, Government Ministers have also understood it for agricultural tractors. Another of the Ministers now present in the House, the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson), is a National Country Party Minister. He would readily remember that bounties are payable on tractors but not on wheelchairs. Why not wheelchairs? At the end of my speech, I will move an amendment to the motion that the Bill be read a second time, setting out the concern we have which is shared by organisations such as the Australian Council for the Rehabilitation of the Disabled. My amendment will also suggest the Government consider replacing tariffs with a bounty. The cost of such a scheme would be only about $250,000, since the bulk of wheelchairs are imported. Furthermore, much of this $250,000 would be offset by the reduced public cost of wheelchairs which are already provided through hospitals and the Aids for Disabled Persons Scheme. In other words, the Government could avoid this inequitable situation at very little cost at all.

Having indicated this particular and important objection to the Government's decision as provided by this legislation, I want to conclude with some more general remarks about industry protection policy of which this Bill is an important part. The protection debate has a very long history in Australia. One of the principal purposes for establishing the Federation of Australia was the desire to create a free trade zone or a common market among the six colonies which had been established in 1900. Since Federation the notion of free trade zones has been extended both in Australia and overseas. In Australia, the public has accepted that there are vital mutual benefits to be gained from developing trade with the various small island nations of the South Pacific. Substantially, free trade has been achieved in relation to the products of those nations through the South Pacific Regional Trade and Economic Co-operation Agreement. Similarly, substantial liberalisation of trade has been achieved in respect of New Zealand under the New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement which may be replaced shortly with a closer economic relationship. But we have had no announcement on progress reports on that.

The Australian Labor Party fully supports these developments. We are as aware as anyone of the benefits of trade. Recognition of these benefits, however, does not lead inexorably to the conclusion that Australia can maximise its well-being by throwing itself open to entirely free trade. Such a step seems to be favoured by many in the National Country Party and Liberal Party ranks. We read of their 'impertinent' and 'modest member' groups respectively. I prefer to call them economic and social illiterates. I notice that the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Spender) is sitting on the front bench in distinguished company. I gather that he is at least a visiting member of the 'modest member' group. I trust that is the case, because I am just about to send a letter to every manufacturing industry in the electorate of North Sydney to make sure that they are in no doubt of where his allegiances lie. I refer to those who are involved in that group as economic illiterates. I believe if they notice the consequences of their actions they can also be classed as social illiterates. I notice that the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton) has come into the chamber. He is, of course, a much more distinguished and open member of the 'modest member' group and I certainly make that charge about him.

It is more instructive to consider the views of the head of the world's most important free trade zone than to consider the views of the honourable member for North Sydney or the honourable member for Mackellar when it comes to this matter. That zone is, of course, the Commission of the European Communities-that is the European Economic Community. The President of the Commission of the European Communities, Mr Gaston Thorn, visited Australia recently and among other engagements addressed the National Press Club in Canberra. You, Mr Deputy Speaker, would realise that my remarks about free trade are relevant to the Bill before us which deals with Customs tariffs. I want to quote what President Thorn said about the common agricultural policy. He said:

. . . we do not spend money on agriculture in order to conquer foreign markets by means of subsidised exports. We do it to guarantee a reasonable standard of living for the eight million people who work on our farms. For us this is a social and political necessity.

President Thorn went on to explain that while unemployment in Europe exceeds 10 million, it is 'just not a realistic option' to reduce assistance to agricultural industry. He pointed out that 'all the industrialised countries protect and subsidise their farmers'. It can be seen from these remarks that there is no delusion in Europe about the need for protection of jobs in agricultural industry.

Since Australia is one of the countries which lose export opportunities as a result of this situation-of course, what is happening in the EEC is repeated in the United States of America and Japan because of protectionist policies in those countries-where is the logic in exposing our 1.2 million manufacturing jobs to unrestricted import competition? This is not to argue against the need for restructuring, for concentrating on those things that we do well. But there are too many in the Government ranks in particular who are suggesting that there should be a blind acceptance of the nonsense in so many cases being put up to us by the Industries Assistance Commission whereby we can phase out-that is the kind of phrase-so many jobs just because they are in industries which are ' uncompetitive' or 'inefficient', without any application to the great challenge of deciding where the new jobs should be found. I am not suggesting that those new jobs are not to be found elsewhere. But what I am suggesting is that leaving it to the free market economy like the ideologues on the other side of this Parliament are doing, does not create those new jobs. In particular where is the logic in this when our balance of trade and current account is in chronic deficit and our unemployment level is the highest in post-war history?

It is interesting to note that the average nominal tariff in Australia is only 15 per cent. Admittedly in Europe it is lower than that-it is 6 per cent. But this disparity is not as great as many, including the honourable member for Mackellar who is a great advocate for lowering tariffs across the board, would suggest. This disparity is not as great as so many who seek a drastic reduction in tariffs seem to believe and in the context of world wide restrictions on Australian exports is not, in the current circumstances, at all unreasonable. Moreover, it must also be made clear that non-tariff barriers, such as government procurement preferences, restrictive labelling and specification standards, delays in import licensing and so on, are far more significant in many overseas countries than they are in Australia.

We do not have a free trade world. The gradual liberalisation of our trade remains a vital objective and one which must be given particular priority in relation to countries in our region. In addition, of course, the Labor Party is aware that manufacturing industry can be revitalised in Australia and can be subjected to greater import competition as a result. We are particularly aware that productivity improvements in such circumstances are essential for ultimate growth without extensive inflation. But, in accord with the findings of the Crawford inquiry, and in accord with the views of the European Communities Commission President, whom I quoted earlier, such a process must be pursued directly before employment is threatened by reduced protection, particularly at a time of high and rising unemployment.

The Government's decision to refer to the IAC a reference on ways of achieving a general reduction in protection is completely at variance with the sensible attitude which I assert I have just given to this House. This is no time to be considering general reductions in protection, particularly because the various industry reviews, in many cases, have only recently been completed and in some cases have yet to be implemented. A substantial degree of adjustment is already under way in the manufacturing sector. Considerably more can be expected from decisions on the motor vehicle industry, the textiles, clothing and footwear industry, and some of the decisions made in this Bill.

This structural change is now occurring in a very depressed environment. Despite being a beneficiary of orders placed by the resources industries, the metal trades industry is now expecting much slower growth in 1982 than it enjoyed last year. Honourable members do not have to take my word for this. I ask them to look at the Metal Trades Industry Association report which was given at the end of last week. The report was given publicity at the weekend and in the early days of this week. This is the experience also of many other industries. For example, the chemicals industry faces a very bleak future. Despite this more depressing condition, considerable changes are being made. In 1982, 41.3 per cent of metal trades firms were engaged in company restructuring compared with 29.1 per cent in the previous year. In some sectors, such as white goods, virtually every company was involved in restructuring in 1981. I welcome the restructuring that took place in that industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was a good example.

—Yes, I agree; that was a good example. Together I hope we can achieve similar restructuring in other industries, but I do not believe that by just using the tariff mechanism that can be achieved. Clearly, there is little need for further cuts in protection to induce change on occasions. All of our eggs should not be put in what I call the sticks basket-the negative basket of just cutting tariffs. Cuts in protection at this time are likely to discourage investments and lead to deindustrialisation rather than to restructuring. The Opposition is firmly committed to providing manufacturing industry with a secure environment in which growth is a central objective of the change which must occur.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill, like the Bounty Acts Amendment Bill, about which I had something to say earlier today, is consistent with the objectives that I have outlined, but it alone is not sufficient to achieve growth. Only Labor's co-operative industry and expansionary economic policies can achieve that aim. As the Bill stands, however, we support it, except with the qualification that I mentioned earlier. I now return to that qualification, namely, to the matter raised concerning the Fraser Government's tax on wheelchairs. I move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'whilst not opposing this Bill, the House- (1) expresses its concern that the Customs duties imposed by this Bill in relation to wheelchairs will maintain the high cost of these necessary aids for the disabled, and

(2) calls upon the Government immediately to review its decision in relation to wheelchairs with a view to replacing the tariff arrangements provided in the Bill with a bounty scheme for local producers'.
The honourable member for Burke (Dr Theophanous) will second the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Theophanous Dr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment. I wish to make some general remarks about the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill. The Opposition is very concerned about the problem of wheelchairs for invalids. Actually, we were rather puzzled at the Government's behaviour in bringing in this provision during the International Year of Disabled Persons. Anyone who has talked to representatives of disabled persons groups will know that they are not happy with the Government's initiatives in this area. In a sense I believe that this further provision adds insult to injury. There is absolutely no reason for this provision. We again call on the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore) to reconsider the provision on humanitarian grounds and to do something about it. We will be pressing as hard as possible for a change in these provisions as far as wheelchairs are concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the remainder of the Bill, although we have in general supported tariff changes, I want to comment on the tariff philosophy of this Government. As the honourable member for Adelaide (Mr Hurford) has mentioned, the Government 's tariff philosophy is really very much tied up with its general economic philosophy. The Government uses tariffs as the only form of industry policy. Anyone who knows anything about what is going on in the Government ranks will know that honourable members are very divided over this issue precisely for that reason. They do not really have a coherent industry philosophy, particularly a manufacturing industry philosophy. They simply use the tariff philosophy. Some Government members want to strengthen the tariff, some want to weaken it and others want to keep it as it is. I believe this is a totally discredited way of approaching the whole question of the manufacturing industry.

The tariff is merely one possible means of ensuring a healthy manufacturing industry. To think that somehow by progressively reducing tariffs, through the use of the tariff and the quota, as the Industries Assistance Commission appears to think, the Government will force some kind of restructuring on the Australian manufacturing industry-increases in efficiency, the kinds of amalgamations of industry that are required and so forth-is simply nonsense. The Treasurer (Mr Howard) admitted in an in-depth article in the National Times the other day that economics is an inexact science. What we have to recognise in relation to the IAC is that it is full of economists who have a one value orientation and bias in relation to that inexact science. Their orientation and their bias lies away from protection and is an attempt to ram efficiency down the throat of Australian manufacturing industry through the use of the so-called private enterprise or free market mechanism.

I would have thought that with the disastrous consequences of this kind of dogmatic approach to the market mechanism that we have seen in the United Kingdom, Europe and every day in the United States of America we would have at least learned that this mythical creature-the free market and all its supposed mechanisms that are supposed to work wonders-does not exist. If government intervention in the form of tariffs or other forms of government intervention were removed this would have been exposed as a myth by now. However, we find that the so-called experts of the IAC are wedded to that philosophy and approach . The Treasurer's remark about economics as an inexact science is proved in the bias and the economic principles which this group of economists has adopted in its recommendations. Indeed, in the various reports that it has produced, including a report about the likely state of the Australian economy in the 1990s , one can see quite clearly the presuppositions that they have. They are the presuppositions of Friedmanite economics, which we totally reject.

One cannot hope to restructure industry simply by adjusting tariffs. One must have a policy which uses the tariff as one means in an overall strategy to change the face of manufacturing industry. No one doubts that such changes are urgently needed at present. Although the Government pretends that it is protecting manufacturing industry, it is gradually being run down. Although some members on the Government side are holding the line to some degree in relation to tariffs and quotas, the fact is that we are seeing a progressive rundown of protection and, at the same time, we are seeing no positive policy to restructure industry or to help it develop.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely correct.

—As my colleague suggests, that is clear and correct, and anyone who represents an electorate in which manufacturing industry plays a primary role will know that that is true. We have, therefore, a situation in which we need a much more comprehensive and positive approach. Whenever we suggest to honourable members opposite such a positive approach on manufacturing industry, what do they do? They rave about government intervention. They talk about intervention as though it is something weird and monstrous. The fact is that intervention involves a rational planning process with respect to manufacturing industry. This kind of process is absolutely essential if we are to get anywhere with the development of manufacturing.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me point out to honourable members opposite what the alternative is if we run down our manufacturing industries. Unemployment will go through the roof. It is already disastrous. It will reach shocking proportions if manufacturing industry continues to be run down. This does not mean that we shall protect every and any industry whether or not it is efficient. Of course not. We need restructuring in industry, but we need that restructuring to be done in a planned and guided fashion, and to ensure that workers in industries which are not sufficiently efficient will be moved into new industries in which they will be able to use their skills or be retained in new skills, so that we can continue apace of employment in manufacturing industry. We have heard nothing from the Government in relation to these matters. We have only heard about the great debate in the Liberal Party between those who maintain that we should reduce tariffs and those who maintain that we should keep tariffs at their present level. These two are pseudo alternatives. We need something extra. We need considerably more extra. We need to think in terms of a planning policy in which protection has an important role.

Let me say something about what that role would be in a coherent manufacturing policy. We need something other than protection being given to companies without any conditions, without any strings attached, so to speak, as is the case with the present Government. After a big debate in its party room, it decides to give a certain level of protection and it gives that level without any conditions being set. What we would do as a government is insist on new and efficient methods in those industries. We would make protection conditional on restructuring, on steps towards restructuring.

TALK.START.PARA: —You wiped them out the last time you did it.

—We certainly did not wipe out any industry in the way in which this Government has done. This Government has wiped out manufacturing industries in the last five years under the pretence that it is still protecting them. This Government has been taking a totally dishonest approach to the whole matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Protection can be used as an effective weapon. I agree with those who say that protection should not be entirely free. It should be earned by companies. They should be required to show that they are taking steps to be more efficient, that they are restructuring, that they are introducing new levels of technology, and that they are investing in new modes of production. But all that is not happening now under current policies. All we are getting is, from time to time, tariff proposals put before the House-some to reduce tariffs and some to increase them-but we are not getting in any way a coherent manufacturing policy. This is just one aspect of the Government's general incoherence in relation to its economic policy. The nonsense that has been spouted by the Treasurer in the last few days indicates he has not learned a thing from the Lowe by-election. He has not yet recognised, even, that there is an economic crisis in this nation and that part of that crisis is in manufacturing industry. He has learned none of the lessons. He is trying to tell us, as he did last week, that everything is roses. It is a totally dishonest approach. He obviously does not even read the newspapers. We have heard nothing from the Minister for Industry and Commerce ( Sir Phillip Lynch) about what will happen to manufacturing industry, except the policy on the car industry which came out recently and which will be a disaster for that industry. There are no proposals to help those who will lose their jobs in the car industry by creating new jobs in other areas of manufacturing industry.

It is time that we used a great deal more rational planning in our approach to the whole economic system, in particular to manufacturing industry. Here the tariff can be a very important weapon. It can be very positive in protecting our industries, and that will have to continue for some time-not unqualified protection, but protection which is coupled with a principle that we want movement towards greater efficiency, that we want to encourage investment in new machinery, and that we want to be able to be internationally competitive in these industries. The idea that simply by reducing tariffs one can make industries internationally competitive has been rejected all over the world. The reason why many Australian manufacturing industries are not competitive has to do with fundamental planning and structural factors about the origin of those manufacturing industries and has very little to do with the whole question of whether one reduces tariffs.

While we support the Bill in general, we call on the Government to produce a coherent strategy on manufacturing industry and on the question of protection, and we shall not be put aside by the fact that the Government constantly leaks stories to the newspapers about fights in the Liberal Party. It is about time that the Government decided on a policy, and brought it before the House, on the question of protection and tariffs as a whole. Secondly, we oppose the provision in the Bill in relation to wheelchairs and urge the House to support the Opposition's amendment. We urge the Minister to think again about this issue and to accept the Opposition's amendment.

Original question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I continue the remarks that I commenced last evening. Because of the time constraints applying then and now, I have only limited time in which to make one point which I have been anxious to develop. That is the difficulty of the Australian Broadcasting Commission, operating in the very creative field of broadcasting and production for the benefits of Australia, being subject to the dead hand of the Public Service Board. The Dix report of the Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission addressed its mind to that factor and talked about a new management structure. I made the point last evening, as one who was closely associated with the creation of the commissions now administering Telecom Australia and the postal services, that it is very important to break away from this dreadful problem of public service domination of wages and terms and conditions of employment. In other words, if one is in the creative aspect of production of material, particularly for broadcasting or film, one needs to have people who do not have that sort of weight on them.

SPEECH.PARA: I am in support of what the ABC Staffs Association said when it appeared before the Dix Committee. The proposition was put forward: Why not do something such as the British Broadcasting Commission charter provides? It has the right to fix its own remuneration and terms and conditions of employment. That is fair enough . But, in looking at the tragic record of the Australian Broadcasting Commission , we see that, despite the fact that there might have been legislative encouragement to say that it had some autonomy, in fact it did not. I think it is important to realise that the Dix Committee also recognised that in the structure of management we need to have as commissioners, in my view, at least one staff member from the technical side and one from the production side. They are the real genus of the ABC's activities. It is not much good surrounding the ABC with a whole lot of well-meaning people who are not involved in the day-to- day difficulties.

Let me make the point again: The Public Service Board has a very sad record in industrial relations. In fact, it seems to have a vested interest in strikes or stoppages. If one looks at the Professional Radio Employees Institute of Australasia dispute, which stopped the whole airline industry in Australia, and one then notes the indictment of the Public Service Board by the arbiter appointed by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, one can almost accept that it was determined to guarantee that the officers of the PREI were not going to get wage justice. This is the point that I was trying to develop last evening.
If honourable members look at the Dix report, they will see the analysis that, whilst the staff is certainly of some mixture, 60 per cent are program-related. The Dix Committee makes this point:
Therefore the ABC as a broadcaster should be aligned with other broadcasters.

I think that is the point of what we are about. We then come to the question of what happened in this Parliament in 1976. The late Eric Robinson introduced legislation to amend the Broadcasting and Television Act. In the course of his speech on that he indicated that it would enable the Commission to have:
. . . greater flexibility in its staffing arrangements. In future-
Said the Minister:
creation or reclassification of positions within the Commission, and the determination of salaries or salary ranges, will no longer require the approval of the Public Service Board . . .

Now, what a myth that was. That was a statement made by the Minister in November 1976. It must astound the Parliament to find that, on 1 December 1976, the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) wrote a letter to the same Minister saying:

Following the decision last night to allow the Broadcasting and Television . . . Amendment Bill to proceed in its present form, I think it is highly desirable that the ABC fully understand the Government's position on the question of co- ordination of pay and conditions of staff throughout the Commonwealth sector, which passage of the Bill will not in any way alter.

In other words the Commission will now still be obliged to do whatever the Public Service Board indicates. As the Staffs Association submission says, from then on the General Manager of the ABC just did whatever he was told to do by the Public Service Board. It created frustration and all the problems that anyone associated with statutory corporations experiences in trying to compete, if I may use that word, with the private sector when dealing with the public and also in getting the most talented people. It did nothing for the benefit of the ABC. The rigidity of the Public Service Board is notorious.

I have led up to this argument. There was a long case to assist the engineers in the ABC. They had some parity some time ago with those who were called the operating officers. The operating officers had gone ahead of the engineers because the Public Service Board, for some reason or other, determined their salaries in a fashion that left the engineers behind. It is deemed that the engineers were left behind because of the wage indexation position.

In summary, after a long case which was completed last year, in October, Mr Booth, the Public Service Arbitrator, gave some form of justice back to the engineers and increased their salary to bring them up to some form of parity. They received about an 18 per cent increase in salary. In fact they needed a 32 per cent rise to get them back to where they were in 1974. Now, because of the metal trades decision that was made in December of last year, I might add, not October, further offers of salary increases will be made by the Public Service Board. It has in fact offered increases to the operating officers. That is fine. They are entitled to it. But, in the process, the Board will deny any further increase to the engineers, which again creates disparity and guarantees that the Commission will face difficulty in being able to function effectively. I make very clear the fact that 70 per cent of program faults are technical ones. Since colour television was introduced in 1974 no routine maintenance has been carried out in this area. There are only 411 engineers now as against a staff requirement of over 700. In the last six weeks, eight have left. Who would want to stay in an organisation where one cannot even get salary justice?

When the ABC wrote to the Department of Industrial Relations and asked: 'Can we not give an increase to the engineers?' the answer from the Department of Industrial Relations was: 'No, you cannot.' What does it mean if the Act says one thing and the Department of Industrial Relations says: 'No, you are not going to do that'? Does the Government really want the ABC to function in this form? The answer is that it certainly does not. Does it want to give wage justice to people who have the skills, training and expertise to do it? It certainly does not. Why is it that the dead hand is still applying to the ABC? It is about time the responsible Minister urgently intervened in this case, as of tomorrow, and asked that these people be given the same salary justice as the others are getting. He should tell the Public Service Board and the Department to operate effectively in this field.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Dix Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission is the most comprehensive review of the ABC that has ever been undertaken. Over the years a number of inquiries have been held into the operations of the ABC. I suppose in many respects it was prudent that this particular inquiry took place at the end of 50 years of operation of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. It is a most extensive report and it is very comprehensive.

SPEECH.PARA: If there is any one criticism of it-I do not lay blame on the Committee itself- it would be this: At this time in the development of the electronic media in Australia, perhaps something even more than just this inquiry into the ABC should have been undertaken. I believe we have reached the stage where we are on the verge of many new technological developments and where there will be major changes in the structure of broadcasting and telecasting in Australia in the coming years. At this stage Australia does not really realise exactly where it is in terms of that development. I suppose after those millions of dollars and all those hours that were spent on the inquiry it is a little late for me to come in here and say that even more work should be done on the future of the media in Australia.

Let us look at the situation of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Lionel Bowen) specialised in his speech in one particular area of the ABC's operation. I suppose that is fair enough, because the Dix Committee report is an incredible document. It is certainly one of the biggest reports that I have seen on any statutory body in Australia. In the few brief minutes that I have available to me, I too would like to touch on some of those aspects of the report.

I suppose most of the publicity that has been gained for this report falls into two areas. They concern the name change of the Australian Broadcasting Commission and the establishment of a national broadcasting organisation and, indeed, the right of the ABC to accept commercial sponsorship for its programming in the future. In terms of the name change for the ABC, I suppose we could argue that it is desirable to have established a national broadcasting organisation. I would agree with the Dix report that the Australian public knows , recognises and respects the ABC as its national broadcasting organisation. In this respect obviously the name 'Australian Broadcasting Commission' must stay. Although, as I say, we might be able to argue to widen the horizon of the national broadcasting organisation, I do not think we should forget the respect that has built up over the 50 years of the ABC's existence in Australia. I suppose if we do want to widen the scope of the Commission, if we do want to change the commissioner structure of the ABC, if we want to separate particular aspects of the ABC's present operations and, for instance, establish a separate authority for the orchestras and a separate authority for education, a case for doing that too can be argued. But basically I believe that the charter and aims of the ABC should remain as they are.

In terms of commercial sponsorship provisions that have been recommended by the Dix Committee to the ABC, I am afraid I am really in two minds. If we examine what has happened in overseas commercial sponsorship of public broadcasting organisations, I think we can probably understand that attitude. It is true that the Australian Broadcasting Commission at the moment does undertake a number of joint productions. The ABC has gone into partnership with overseas broadcasting corporations and, indeed, some private organisations in the production of programs. That has worked very well. From a close examination of what has happened in the United States of America in commercial sponsorship of public broadcasting, I think we probably do have room to be fearful of what could happen to the ABC.

I think Dix is perfectly right inasmuch as he argues that if we were to open the ABC to some corporate sponsorship it would not mean that every 13 minutes there would be a commercial break of 90 seconds plugging everything from cornflakes to new motor cars. That would not be the situation at all. But it would mean that substantial sums of money could be poured into that organisation for the production of television programs. I know the friends of the ABC and a number of private citizens have brought to the fore their fear that the very independence of the Australian Broadcasting Commission could be brought into question if that situation were allowed to exist; that if an organisation such as, say, the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Limited were prepared to lend or give substantial sums of money to the ABC for commercial productions, BHP or similar organisations could be subjected to major criticism in future programs and in fact an analysis in the current affairs area of the Australian Broadcasting Commission could even be left out because of that criticism. That may or may not happen but the risk is always there. I think it would be very dangerous for this Parliament to give an open cheque to the ABC to start taking commercial sponsorship for its programs unless we do have a complete guideline as to exactly how that commercial sponsorship will operate and exactly what might be involved in allowing that corporate sponsorship to come to the Australian Broadcasting Commission.

I am sure that not one person in this House would like to think that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Commission might be subjected to these sorts of commercial pressures if such sponsorship were undertaken. I do not really think that the commercial sponsorship of the Commission would be the panacea for all its ills. It is true that over the years the ABC has been subjected to financial cuts by the Government. Perhaps that is fair enough. But I think if we analyse just where those cuts have happened, how the ABC management has adopted those cost-cutting measures, we will see that perhaps all is not well in the state of Denmark in terms of the ABC's operations at the moment.

I am sure that other honourable members who are sitting in the House tonight could cite examples of just what has happened in the ABC. I think one of the classic cases occurred in Brisbane, when the cuts were first made and everybody from the gardener to the security officers were immediately fired. The ABC then went out and hired a private security firm for a weekend during which it was undertaking a major pop concert promotion on its station. I understand that the cost of providing that private security service just for that weekend amounted to more than the total wages of the gardener, the concierge and the security people in the ABC for a full 12 months. This illustrates the calibre of some of the decisions that were made within the Australian Broadcasting Commission.

I turn my mind back to those very early days when I first entered this Parliament in 1976. If any honourable member were to examine my maiden speech he would see that I mentioned the Australian Broadcasting Commission in that speech and reminded the House of the very grave difficulties that the Commission faced in its management structure and the calibre of its middle management as long ago as that. Dix has confirmed exactly what I said in those days. In fact, the classic quote from his report is when he describes the management of the ABC as the mediocre directing the activities of the mediocre. That is probably right. I think in many ways the ABC management structure is a bit like Topsy, it just growed. Incompetence has developed within the ABC management structure. In some areas of the ABC we have almost a degree of nepotism and many of the decisions which have been made, especially over the last 10 or 15 years, have not been good decisions.

I thoroughly agree with the Deputy Leader of the Opposition when he says that if we are to clean out the whole structure of the ABC the first thing we should do is to look at getting it away from the Public Service Board structure. How a creative organisation such as the ABC, a broadcasting organisation that can, in theory, be the finest of its kind in the world, can operate under the present circumstances frankly is beyond me. The fact that that Public Service structure is there, the fact that creative personnel are restricted by that structure, can really mean only that the ABC can never reach its true potential. I am sure that we are all aware of very talented people who have gone into the ABC and I guess in many respects have served their apprenticeships there, but then have gone on to the commercial organisations or have left the whole industry completely and utterly disillusioned and gone into another industry altogether. It is essential that we get that Public Service Board restriction completely away from the organisation and that we give the ABC management the right to hire and fire its staff in order to get rid of the incompetence, to start getting a proper management structure there, to get rid of the nepotism. Let us get the thing down to a finely honed organisation that can start producing some of those programs which we know the ABC is particularly capable of producing.

Another aspect of the Dix report that is of particular interest to me is the fact that Dix stated in the report that there must be a complete revision of the accounting structure of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. On reading that, I was interested to note that he came up with certain suggestions and applied most of his recommendations to the physical cost of ABC programming. But if we are to restructure that financial system we will probably have to go a little further than that. I am sure I am not the only member of this House who realises some of the very great difficulties which have existed within the Australian Broadcasting Commission. Because of the 13 1/2 years I spent in the media I have a very close relationship with many members of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. I saw successive Ministers about a situation that developed in my home State of Queensland, a situation which was commonly referred to as the Hunt case. It went through the courts about 18 months or two years ago. I believe that to a great extent this whole matter was given a certain amount of whitewash . It had to do with the letting of contracts; it had to do with the appointment of staff; it had to do with the claiming of expenditure. I am sure that the results of that left many people within the organisation not particularly happy with what went on at that stage.

It is that sort of doubt about the physical day to day management of the ABC that must make a great number of us worry about what is happening within that organisation. It must make us pose the questions of whether the ABC structure is completely and utterly rotten as it exists now. Whether management personnel were getting kitchens and extensions put on to their homes, whether carpets were being borrowed from prop areas to be put in certain homes, whether the sons of certain staff members were being hired by the Commission I suppose was for the court to find out. We all know the result of that. But that really indicates the way in which the ABC has been allowed to develop under the present system. I believe that is really what Dix should be all about. I believe that the whole organisation should be completely and utterly cleaned out. Frankly, I believe that the Australian Broadcasting Commission is almost at a stage where we have to start again. If we can start again, if we can get that structure right, if we can get the staffing right, I believe that we will have one of the finest broadcasting organisations in the world. The ABC has proved over the years that it is capable.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Passports: Department of Foreign Affairs-Coal Industry-Pensions-Aviation: Cross Charter Arrangements-Housing-Citizenship Ceremonies: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs

PROCTEXT.PARA: Passports: Department of Foreign Affairs-Coal Industry-Pensions-Aviation: Cross Charter Arrangements-Housing-Citizenship Ceremonies: Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mountford Mr J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members might recall the issue which I raised last night but on which I was unable to conclude my remarks because the debate was interrupted. I wish briefly to raise the matter again in relation to the issue of passports by passport offices in Australia. If a married person wishes to travel overseas the issue of a passport is contingent upon that person having the passport application endorsed by his or her spouse, or if the couple are separated, upon the applicant signing a statutory declaration stating that he or she does not have any financial obligations to his or her former spouse. There is no provision on that statutory declaration for the applicant to declare a financial obligation to children of that former marriage.

SPEECH.PARA: I have confirmed with the passport offices at Sydney and Canberra that the position that I have set out is correct. However, when speaking with a senior officer for the policy division of the Department of Foreign Affairs I was informed that the opposite applied, that is, that the statement on financial obligations to a former spouse also included maintenance obligations paid in accordance with a court award to the former spouse on behalf of their children. I have a specific case in my electorate involving a lady who came to my office and complained to me that her husband had received a passport from the Sydney passport office to travel overseas. He had signed a statutory declaration stating that he had no financial obligations to her as the former spouse. But he omitted to say that he did have financial obligations towards two children of their former marriage. A Family Court order does exist for maintenance to be paid by that husband to those two children through the former spouse, that is, through the former wife.

I think the matter needs to be clarified. This gentleman may have made a false declaration. The Department needs to clarify the situation by altering the wording on the forms that are offered to people who apply for passports. I would like the matter to be referred to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street). I ask him to clarify the discrepancy between the view of the Department and the passport offices and to give clear directions to the Department's policy division and the passport offices on the interpretation of the statutory declaration forms. I would like him to advise me whether as a result of these investigations and clarifications the person who signed the statutory declaration has indeed falsified a statutory declaration form.

This is only one case that has come to my attention. Obviously this happens hundreds or even thousands of times every year through the passport offices in Australia. In fact, I can recall that some years ago when I intended travelling overseas I certainly had to get the authority of my wife on the form before the passport would be issued, and I think that is correct and proper. If, however, the marriage has broken up and there is a legal separation surely the situation should prevail in which the applicant has to complete a statutory declaration not only to the effect that there are no financial obligations to the former spouse but also that he has no financial obligations to children of that marriage, particularly when those financial obligations are the result of a decision of the Family Court or indeed of any of the courts of the States of this land. I would like that clarification from the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKenzie Mr A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been prompted to speak in the adjournment debate because of a telex I have which indicates that it is not uncommon for bulk carriers to remain for four or even five months off New South Wales coal loading ports before they are loaded. For example, ships that came in in November 1981 are only now being loaded. They face demurrage charges of about $ 10,000 a day and sometimes higher. I know of one case in which a company now faces demurrage costs which are higher than the actual value of the coal cargo that was taken out. This is not the only problem with the coal industry. I think many people in Australia believe that the coal industry is booming, that it is a major resource development. But the reality is that it is facing very serious difficulties indeed. It is showing declining investment. It is showing deferral and perhaps termination of projects. It is facing huge wage rises, uncertain markets and seriously reduced profits.

SPEECH.PARA: Last year 60 per cent of New South Wales coal companies either made a loss or a very small profit. The biggest problems are associated with industrial disputes, shipping delays, wages, declining productivity and State and Commonwealth tax takes from the industry. Let us look at some of the imposts on the industry in New South Wales in recent years. Rail freights have gone up by 80 per cent in two years, the last rise being 25 per cent in one hit. Port loading charges went up by 47 per cent in the last year. Royalties in New South Wales have gone up by 800 per cent over the last 10 years. Super royalties are being introduced on coal by the New South Wales Government, to my knowledge for the first time in this country. In addition, the New South Wales Government has moved to take over private coal rights without any guarantee of adequate compensation for the owners. Let us have a look at the situation in New South Wales vis-a-vis Queensland. The Joint Coal Board figures that were released some weeks ago showed that for the 1981 year New South Wales coal exports increased by 1.3 per cent whereas Queensland's exports increased by 39 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was that-39 per cent?

—Queensland's exports increased by 39 per cent. If I may turn to the coal industry in Queensland, it also has been hit very hard by other imposts from governments. Front-end payments of many millions of dollars for infrastructure, royalties and rail freight charges have imposed a tremendous disability and liability on coal companies.

SPEECH.PARA: I invite honourable members to look at the wage increases in this industry. I have to return to the position in New South Wales where the responsible Minister offered and agreed to an award increase of $63 a week to the combined coal mining unions. That was the highest bid that the unions looked for. It is my understanding that they would have been very happy with a much lower wage increase. To the coal companies it represents an increase of more than $120 a week when overtime, shift allowances and penalty rates are included. The average wage for miners on the South Coast is in excess of $800 a week to which has to be added 28 per cent to allow the companies to pay pay roll tax, compensation insurance, facilities and all the rest of it. The Federal Government has moved to impose an extra levy of $1 on exports and this is at a time when the industry can ill afford to meet that impost. In fact, the $10m that is budgeted for as a result of the export levy will not be achieved by the Federal Government this year because of lower production levels and because of shipping delays.

The coal industry is the largest industry in Australia. It is helping to maintain Australia's balance of payments. It is worth about $2 billion. Last year it was worth $1.6 billion. However, the industry now faces huge cost pressures and market uncertainties. In addition, unionists must realise that they are pushing their own self-destruct button because strikes and excessive pay demands are not only jeopardising the Australian industry but also their own jobs as buyers of Australian coal will continue to look to other countries for more reliable suppliers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Free Mr R.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very touched, listening to the remarks of the honourable member for Calare (Mr MacKenzie), and I know that the miners in Lithgow whom he represents will be very interested to hear his remarks. This evening I want to refer to the enormous groundswell of concern and resentment among age pensioners as a result of a number of ill-considered and provocative statements by a number of Ministers over the last seven months. Those statements quite deservedly have led to a wave of bad publicity for this Government. I guess that the Sunday Telegraph of 6 September last year was a fair sample when it ran the headline of 'Pension Blitz: Crackdown on old folks' life savings'. The lead paragraph stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government this week plans launching an all out-blitz on pensioner' s savings.

These statements, while they lead to a public relations disaster for the Government, still fall neatly into the same pattern that has been used by this Government habitually when it has been planning to introduce an unpopular measure. The process has been to fly a kite for a while, test the wind, back off for a while, repeat the process and then finally move in for the kill. The whole process began in August 1981 when the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) representing the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) said:

It has become evident that there is a growing practice of avoiding income for pension purposes, or even more commonly for pensioner fringe benefits. There is no essential difference, so far as the general community effect is concerned, between this and tax avoidance. It is, quite simply, the welfare face of the income rigging coin.
We shall therefore be moving during the Budget session of Parliament to tighten up the relevant legislation to prevent income avoidance for pension purposes . . .

Nothing happened. A follow-up statement from the Government suggested that it might have its proposals ready for March but, instead of legislation, pensioners were treated to a tirade of abuse from the Minister for Industry and Commerce ( Sir Phillip Lynch), a person who appears to delight in scaring old people. The latest headlines have again suggested that the Government may be backing off before moving in for the kill. The Sunday Telegraph of last Sunday carries the headline 'Fraser Backs Off Pension Blitz'. The article begins:
The Fraser Government is to defer its crackdown on schemes used by rich people to get the pension.

Again, it is part of the process of flying the kite, then backing off and finally moving in. As the Opposition has said, the fact that pensioners are living longer ought to be a source of national pride. It ought to lead to Government action to provide our senior citizens with security and comfort in their old age. Instead, the scrooges in this Government prefer to talk of blitzes, crack-downs and millionaire pensioners. To listen to these scrooges one would think that pensioners are living off the fat of the land. In fact, the reverse is true. When the present Prime Minister (Mr Malcom Fraser) won government in 1975 on the promise that the real value of pensions would be preserved, the pension stood at 23.2 per cent of average weekly earnings. Now, its value is down to about 21.6 per cent of average weekly earnings and, unless the tax threshold is raised, an increasing number of pensioners will pay tax on their social security benefit and other income as inflation continues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Disgraceful.

—As my colleague has said, it is disgraceful. No wonder there is concern and resentment among pensioners. No wonder the 24,000 pensioners in Lowe last Saturday showed how they felt about this Government. Here is how one old-timer, as he describes himself, feels. I quote from his letter to me:

SPEECH.PARA: I was 66 before I applied for the age pension and I worked and paid taxes all my life and I went to work at the age of 12 and worked with tax deductions till I retired at 66. I swore allegiance three times and I am unaware that I am a burden to the tax-paying worker. I was told that my tax deductions were for my old age. I have never been a bludger in my life and I think that some of the MPs should look elsewhere instead of picking on the old pioneers who earned their pensions from the sweat of their brows and not insult those that always had the interests of their country at heart and did all they could to live up to the first verse of our National Anthem. This is not a whine, but something that most people have forgotten-people who can't and won't understand, but think only of themselves.
I would like this Government for once to think of the people who are now old, who built this country, who worked hard and who are entitled to security and comfort in their old age.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier this week we read reports in the Press of statements made by the Australian Federation of Air Pilots expressing concern at the operations of cross charter arrangements between Qantas Airways Ltd, Australia's international airline, and other international airlines. It was probably timely that this particular situation was brought to the attention of Australia, especially in light of the fact that the international civil aviation policy review which was promised last year did not happen, especially in fact that there has been, to their credit, some loosening up of the operations of Qantas, Australia's international airline. Certain information has come to me concerning some of the concerns of the Australian Federation of Air Pilots.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation that evolved concerned arrangements between Qantas and the Indonesian international airline, Garuda Indonesian Airways, on cross charter operations between Denpasar in Bali and Darwin and between Denpasar and Port Hedland in Western Australia. I think it only right that I bring to the attention of the House the arrangements that have been made in those cases and indeed to the one particular situation that evolved. The incident happened on 17 January 1982 and concerned the flight plan for the Garuda operation from Denpasar in Bali to Darwin on the QF/GA joint flight on that day. The aircraft arrived in Darwin's control zone at a distance of 45 miles from the point of touchdown. In fact it called up on VHF at 45 miles and at that stage had in fact penetrated controlled air space by about 60 miles. In other words, other aircraft in that area were not made aware of the presence of the Garuda flight and opposite direction traffic could, I suppose, theoretically have been placed on a collision course.

The meteorological conditions for Darwin on that day required 60 minutes of holding fuel for thunder-storms and low clouds and with normal minimum fuel the endurance for the aircraft would have been about 268 minutes. On examination of the flight plan-I have a copy of that flight plan-it was revealed that the endurance was in fact 233 minutes. Indeed, it has been reported on very good authority from the Department of Transport people in Darwin that that DC9 aircraft arrived in Darwin with only about six minutes of fuel remaining. That is a very serious operation indeed.

If we look at the Denpasar-Port Hedland operation, perhaps it is even more frightening because the aircraft used on that route is an F28, also on cross- charter to Qantas. That aircraft operating between Port Hedland and Bali frankly , to my knowledge, does not meet our Australian safety standards. For example, that particular F28 aircraft does not have a ditching certificate, does not carry life rafts and has only basic flight instrumentation. I suppose part of the problem is the fact that Garuda is not a carrier recognised by the International Air Transport Association. Further reports-these have yet to be confirmed-indicate that certain passengers have boarded their DC9 aircraft and have been allocated seats without seat belts. Indeed, it has been brought to my attention that in another case a person sat in a seat on that flight and not only were there seats without seat belts or buckles but also seat belts that were in existence had to be tied in a knot in front of the passenger. This was the required safety standard. Obviously, when we enjoy one of the greatest safety standards in civil aviation in the world, we should express concern at this sort of situation if it is developing. This is at a time when Trans Australia Airlines is technically bankrupt and Ansett Airlines of Australia is complaining that the traffic has declined in Australia. Why should our national carrier make arrangements with other foreign carriers in a situation such as this when TAA has excess DC9 capacity and is not filling it to the utmost and when Airlines of Western Australia have F28s fully available for that operation? Why should we go to a foreign carrier and undertake cross charter arrangements from those carriers? I have discussed the matter with the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt). Thank goodness a major investigation of this situation is being undertaken by his Department and, indeed, Qantas. We cannot afford for a moment to let Australia's air safety record be impinged upon. Nor can we afford to relax our vigilance while the present situation remains.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr D.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer tonight to the subject of housing and to the many thousands of Australians who are struggling either to purchase a home, or to continue to live in one that they have bought in the last few years. In the course of that struggle they are finding it extremely difficult, because of soaring interest rates, to keep up their repayments. As we all know, interest rates are at the highest level in this country's history and likely to rise even further. The Fraser Government's total mismanagement of the economy, in regard to taxation and housing especially, is an absolute disgrace. If the economy continues to be managed in this way one needs little imagination to see Australia heading towards bankruptcy. That could well happen unless something is done to reverse the draconian policies that the Government has pursued for six years and is continuing to pursue.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to quote a letter from a constituent in Seaford, in the southern part of my electorate of Isaacs, because it typifies the position of so many thousands of Australians. The writer, after introducing herself, says:

We are a young couple who have only moved into our first home in July. We were so proud that we had finally made it . . . We had not even paid our first payment on our dream home when the news came through on the interest rate increase-another $21 a month over one year a nice penny, over 25 years, enough to make us cry. Everything is going up and our dream of a house and a family is being shattered, really shattered.
The letter continues:

From this letter it sounds like we have driven ourselves into a corner and gone in over our heads with debts. No we haven't. We bought an average three bedroom home, we pondered and mused before doing so, really throwing around our finances and worked on the figures. Yes, we could cope. Then came Medibank increases, electrical, gas, rates, food, clothes, everything has gone up since then and there is talk of interest rates going up again. We are honest and hard working people, but the way things are going my husband will have to get a second job. As for starting a family, we just simply couldn't afford it. We are becoming increasingly more disillusioned and bitter in the way the little person has to pay for everything. I have written to the Treasurer and Housing Minister and all I have received back was a letter, so patronising and offering absolutely no real answers. We need answers and something to look into the future for, some hope, because frankly life looks pretty miserable for us and many other people in the same position as us.

That typifies the situation of so many Australians. Once again I ask the Government to revise its economic policies, in regard to housing and interest rates especially, because they are crippling many people, particularly those who are least able to afford it. I make this petition to the Government most sincerely tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Mr M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the House once again to a serious problem affecting my electorate and various other electorates in New South Wales. It was referred to earlier by the honourable member for Calare (Mr McKenzie). It relates to bottlenecks in coal shipping which have been causing absolute disaster to both the profitability of the New South Wales coal industry and the earnings of coal miners generally. The honourable member for Calare quite properly pointed out the enormous delays in the shipping of coal and mentioned some that were of up to five months duration. As I understand it, delays of four months are very common. I want to draw the attention of the House to the fact that today it was announced that exports scheduled from Newcastle, Port Kembla and Balmain next month have in fact been totally abandoned by the coal companies. They are unable to get their ships into the loaders as a result of continual disruption. Another factor is the failure of the New South Wales Government to complete even one major addition to the coal loading capacity of the State since it came into office almost six years ago. It has cancelled the building of the proposed Botany Bay coal loader and produced a situation in which very little additional capacity for export exists in New South Wales. The monumental disruption that is caused at coal loading points by unions which in many instances are closely associated with the Communist Party of Australia has resulted in a disastrous pile-up of ships, particularly outside Newcastle but also off Port Kembla and Balmain. The cancellation means that earnings from the contractual exportation of about two and a quarter million tonnes of coal, worth some $120m, have been lost to this country because of an incapacity to export if from New South Wales ports.

SPEECH.PARA: This is an incredible situation. It is all the more incredible when it is recognised that last year in Queensland, for example, according to a recent Joint Coal Board report, the volume of exports increased by some 39 per cent, whereas New South Wales exports increased by a little over one per cent. There is an evident difference between the approach of the New South Wales Government and that of the Queensland Government to the question of getting the product to the market place. Apparently there is a commitment in Queensland to meet contractual obligations and allow the coal mining industry to earn profits so that those who work in the mines can share in them. In New South Wales the failure to provide facilities and, in fact, the actual restraints imposed on coal mines-as in my electorate, where the New South Wales Government refuses to allow the transport of coal by road to the new coal loader, which is not yet open; we keep waiting in hope, requiring that it be taken entirely by rail-will impose an immense cost burden on the industry and bring about the closure of some mines. There were reports in my electorate today that two mines were scheduled for closure. I am glad that the coal company involved has said that at this stage it is not its immediate intention to close them, but there is no doubt--

TALK.START.PARA: —They will be.

—As my honourable friend says, it will happen if the New South Wales Government does not get off the back of the coal industry in that State. Unless it does something positive to assist the industry instead of, by its indolence, preventing the export of its products, there will be mine closures and unemployment in the coal mining areas of the State and, I fear, in my electorate . It is about time the New South Wales Government did something positive to correct this disaster, which today is being evidenced by the cancellation of one whole month's shipment of coal. It means that Australia is no longer internationally regarded as a reputable supplier.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Uren The Hon T.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 17 November 1981:

(2) If so, can he say whether this report indicates that material is available in Japan for building 20 plutonium-type atomic bombs each year and that to do so would not require the construction of new reactors if changes were made to the operating method of the existing Tokai reactor owned by the Japan Nuclear Power Corporation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Street The Hon A.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) My attention has been drawn to a document entitled Japan's Independent National Defence and Its Potential which was referred to in the Japanese Diet on 30 March 1981 by Mr Tetsu Noda, a member of the opposition Socialist Party. Mr Noda said in the Diet that no mention is made in the document of where it was prepared. He also said that it must have been prepared by the Japanese Government, about ten years ago. Government representatives from the Japan Defence Agency denied in the Diet any knowledge of the report and also denied that the Defence Agency has ever conducted research on the development of nuclear weapons or on delivery systems for nuclear warheads.

(2) The document includes a statement that, if the operation of the Tokai-1 nuclear power station at the Tokai plant of the Japan Atomic Power Company were to be converted to producing plutonium for military purposes, the annual production of plutonium would amount to about 240 kilograms. The document includes a further statement that such a level of production would permit the manufacture of about 20 nuclear weapons.

The Tokai-1 nuclear power reactor has been subject to IAEA safeguards since September 1967. Since December 1977 the safeguards arrangements have derived from an IAEA safeguards agreement (IAEA document INFCIRC/255) covering all peaceful nuclear activities in Japan. This agreement was concluded pursuant to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty (NPT), which Japan ratified in June 1976. Japan's ratification of the NPT means that it accepted a legally binding commitment not to manufacture or otherwise acquire nuclear weapons or other nuclear explosive devices. Japan's NPT-safeguards agreement with the IAEA provides for verification that nuclear material in Japan's nuclear industry is not diverted to non-peaceful or explosive purposes. Moreover any significant change in the operating method of the Tokai-1 nuclear power reactor would be reported by IAEA nuclear safeguards inspectors.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 February 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the major changes that constitute the sweeping reform of Williamstown Naval Dockyard that were announced this year by Mr Newman as Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence.

(2) How does his Department intend to separate the customer and the shipbuilder , as advised in the Hawke Report, while Williamstown Naval Dockyard remains within the control of the Navy and the Department of Defence.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Killen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The reform of Williamstown Naval Dockyard announced by Mr Newman as Acting Minister for Defence on 20 January 1982 is to cover two main areas. These are management and work practices.

The Government's position is that in both these areas demonstrated success, or otherwise, in improving productivity will determine whether follow on destroyers will be built at Williamstown or elsewhere.
Management changes will include:
Streamlined machinery within Department of Defence for executive control.
Strengthened and restructured management in the dockyard.
A civilian General Manager and some new supporting staff.
New procedures to cater for special shipbuilding problems.
Concerning work practices, we are seeking a major rationalization jointly with the Australian Council of Trade Unions.

(2) Separation between the customer and the shipbuilder will be achieved by arranging that in future ships are built under the terms of a formal written agreement closely resembling a commercial contract. The General Manager and the Chief of Naval Materiel will be the signatories representing respectively the shipbuilder and the customer.
