ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of the Capital Territory: Special Arrangements for Disabled Persons

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Capital Territory, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of the fact that 1981 is designated as the International Year of Disabled Persons, what special arrangements has his Department made to assist disabled persons.

(2) Do any special arrangements made include (a) increased employment of disabled persons and (b) improved access for disabled persons to any building or other facility occupied by his Department; if so, what are the details.
(3) What budgetary allocations were made in 1980-81 to facilitate any special arrangements for disabled persons in his Department.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the honourable member to the general reply to Question No. 458 which appeared in the weekly Hansard of 10 June 1981, but would add the following comments:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Special arrangements were made by the Department of the Capital Territory in 1981 to assist disabled people, including the setting up of an IYDP Secretariat for the Australian Capital Territory. The Secretariat was staffed by officers of my Department and carried out a range of functions including the servicing of the Australian Capital Territory Advisory Committee for IYDP appointed by my predecessor in mid 1980, advising voluntary organisations in the matter of IYDP project funding, and the taking of measures to promote the 'Year' generally throughout the local community.

(2) (a) With regard to employment of disabled people, there was more than 100 per cent increase in the number of disabled people absorbed into the Australian Capital Territory work force in 1981 compared with figures for the previous year , results which can be attributed in no small degree to the thrust provided by the Australian Capital Territory's spokesman for the campaign, IYDP Advisory Committee Chairman, George Colman.

The Department of the Capital Territory worked closely with the Public Service Board on employment for disabled people and currently is involved in a pilot study which could be extended to other parts of the Service.

(2) (b) Improved access for disabled persons to Departmental premises and to facilities in Canberra generally is a matter of some concern to my Department. The Department of Housing and Construction's access program has included an extensive survey of government offices in Canberra which has received my Department's full support. That work is ongoing.

A range of projects undertaken by my Department in 1981 to mark IYDP included large scale modifications to government-owned homes occupied by disabled tenants , the construction of special gardens for disabled visitors situated within our National Botanic Gardens, the allocation of a number of government owned cottages to organisations caring for disabled groups and improved access for disabled people to a number of sporting and recreational areas in and around Canberra.

The Department produced a brochure showing the city location of 193 parking bays set aside for the exclusive use of disabled drivers. A brochure highlighting picnic and recreation points catering for the special needs of disabled people will shortly be released by my Department.

(3) No special budgetary allocations were made in 1980-81 for Departmental IYDP projects. In addition to public sector expenditure on IYDP (in the Australian Capital Territory it is estimated to have been in excess of $1.6m) the Australian Capital Territory community benefited from two special grants made to the Australian Capital Territory Advisory Committee for IYDP in January 1981: a grant of $50,000 for the children under the Children's Service Program, and $26, 000 from the Community Development Fund for other projects and general administration. Additionally, the non-government Australian Capital Territory Planning and Co-ordinating Committee for IYDP received two community grants both also from the Community Development Fund, to fund its operations, $18,000 in mid 1980 and a further $23,000 in January 1981.

(3) There have been no new or extended benefits for the wives of disability pensioners.
(4) There are an estimated 78,500 wives in receipt of wife's pension only from the Department of Veterans' Affairs.
(5) Forty per cent of such pension is considered in assessing pension under the income test applicable to the service pension.
